questions.text: Interstitial fluid volume is best measured using a combination of which two dyes?
questions.solution:
Interstitial fluid volume is best measured using a combination of inulin and Evans blue.

Interstitial fluid is measured indirectly. Interstitial fluid volume = ECF - plasma volume.

  • Best measure of ECF: Inulin
  • Best measure of Plasma Volume: Evans Blue (T1824)

questions.text: Alcoholic liver disease is suspected in a patient presenting with abdominal pain and vomiting. Which among the following makes the diagnosis of alcoholic liver disease unlikely?
questions.solution:
An AST: ALT <2 makes the diagnosis of alcoholic liver disease unlikely. 

Alcoholic liver disease is characterised by significant alcohol consumption, often with elevated gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT).In alcoholic liver disease (ALD), usually the AST: ALT is > 2:1. This is because there is a deficiency of pyridoxal 5'- phosphate which is a cofactor for the enzymatic activity of ALT. Therefore, ALT levels fail to rise and there is a reversal of the AST: ALT ratio.

GGT is commonly used in patients with alcoholic liver disease as a marker of excessive alcohol intake. GGT is present in many tissues, including the kidneys, pancreas, and liver. It is mainly derived from the liver and this is often used as a marker of hepatobiliary diseases. Chronic alcohol consumption leads to the induction of hepatic microsomal GGT which leads to a rise in GGT in alcoholics.

Laboratory investigations in patients with alcohol-induced liver dysfunction:

  • AST (SGOT) and ALT (SGPT) elevations that do not exceed 400 IU/L.
  • AST/ALT ratio of >1.5.
  • Serum bilirubin >3 mg/dL. 

Option B: Prothrombin time (PT) is prolonged in alcoholic liver disease due to the decreased synthetic function of the liver.

Option C: Platelet counts are often reduced early in alcoholic liver disease, which is reflective of portal hypertension with hypersplenism.

Option D: Serum total bilirubin may be either normal or elevated in cases of advanced alcoholic liver disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to your clinic with complaints of stiffness of the joints in her fingers for the past 6 years. Identify the hand deformity shown in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the swan-neck deformity, which is seen in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

Swan-neck deformity is hyperextension at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint and flexion at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is characterized by symmetric polyarthritis with pain, stiffness, and swelling of the fingers being the early symptom. It mainly involves the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints.

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Subluxation of the 1st MCP joint with hyperextension of the 1st IP joint. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man exercises at a high altitude. Which of the following changes would occur in him?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, there will be a rise in urinary bicarbonate levels if a person is observed exercising at a high altitude.

Adaptation at High Altitudes:

  • The work capacity is reduced at high altitudes and this reduction is in direct proportion to the decrease in O2 uptake.
  • Immediate exposure to low PO2 at higher altitudes stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors, and this stimulation increases alveolar ventilation.
  • This immediate increase in pulmonary ventilation upon rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of CO2, reducing the PCO2 and increasing the pH of the body fluids causing respiratory alkalosis (not metabolic - option A). This raised pH inhibits the brainstem respiratory center and opposes the increased ventilation. So, respiratory alkalosis will hinder maximal exercise effort.
  • To compensate for this respiratory alkalosis, kidneys reduce hydrogen ion secretion and increase bicarbonate excretion. This reduces plasma and cerebrospinal fluid bicarbonate concentration and brings the pH towards normal. It removes the inhibitory effect of alkalosis on respiration. Hence, fall in blood bicarbonate facilitates the exercise effort.
  • Lactic acid levels increase which causes extreme fatigue. When there is insufficient oxygen (at high altitudes), most of the pyruvic acid is converted into lactic acid, which diffuses out of the muscle cells into the interstitial fluid and blood.

questions.text: Preconceptional use of ______ leads to reduced incidence of neural tube defects.
questions.solution:
Pre-conceptional use of folic acid reduces the incidence of neural tube defects and folic acid is the commonly used active form of vitamin B9.

Folic acid deficiency is implicated in neural tube defects like spina bifida, encephalocele, and anencephaly.

As per the Anemia Mukt Bharat Program, during the period of pre-conception up to the first trimester, women are advised to have 400 μg of folic acid tablets daily to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

Note that, non-pregnant, non-lactating women of reproductive age (20–49 years) who are not actively planning a pregnancy in the short term should receive 1 iron and folic acid tablet containing 60 mg elemental iron + 500 μg folic acid.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a primary endpoint in phase 1 studies?
questions.solution:
Efficacy is not a primary endpoint in phase 1 studies. Phase 1 studies are generally done in healthy volunteers. Efficacy can be a secondary endpoint in some studies where patients are recruited.

The primary endpoints are:

  • Safety
  • Tolerability of single/multiple doses
  • Pharmacokinetic parameters 

The primary endpoint denotes the purpose of the study for which it is primarily designed. The secondary endpoint denotes the measure of the valuable outcome of the study design.

questions.text: The lower part of vagina is derived from _______.
questions.solution:
The lower part of the vagina is derived from the urogenital sinus.

The upper part is derived from paramesonephric duct or mullerian duct, and the uterus develops from the two paramesonephric ducts on either side which unites to form single uterus.

questions.text: The components of Meigs syndrome include:

choices.text: Ascites + pleural effusion + malignant ovarian tumor
Ascites + pleural effusion + benign ovarian tumor

questions.solution:
Meig's syndrome refers to ascites and pleural effusions that accompany a benign ovarian tumor.

Meigs syndrome is mostly caused by ovarian fibroma. CA-125 levels may also be elevated. As it is a diagnosis of exclusion, a workup should be done to rule out malignancy. Exploratory laparotomy with surgical staging is the treatment of choice. Conservative surgery (salpingo-oophorectomy) is done. The clinical features resolve on resection of the fibroma.

Pseudo-Meigs syndrome, which presents with ascites and pleural effusion in association with benign tumors of the ovary, other than fibromas (E.g. Thecoma, Granulosa cell tumor, Brenner tumor) and Leiomyomas.

Pseudo-pseudo Meigs syndrome is a manifestation of SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus) defined by ascites, pleural effusion, and elevated CA-125 levels.

questions.text: A 4-year-old unimmunized child presented to pediatric OPD with fever, sore throat and difficulty in swallowing. On examination, the following picture is seen. What is the causative organism of this condition?
questions.solution: The formation of pseudomembrane on the posterior pharynx is a characteristic feature of diphtheria. The causative organism is Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: The organ of Rosenmuller is a remnant of the _______.
questions.solution:
The organ of Rosenmuller, also known as epoophoron, is a remnant of the mesonephric tubule in females.

The mesonephric tubules give rise to the following structures and remnants:

  • Females: epoophoron and paroophoron
  • Males: efferent ductules (ductuli efferentes or vasa efferentia), lobules of the head of the epididymis, and paradidymis.

questions.text: Von Gierke’s disease is due to the deficiency of _________.
questions.solution:
Von Gierke’s disease occurs due to deficiency of enzyme Glucose 6-phosphatase.

Glycogen storage disease type I (GSD I), or von Gierke disease, is the most common of the glycogen storage diseases. 

Clinical manifestations result, directly or indirectly, from:

  • Inability to maintain an adequate blood glucose level during the post-absorptive hours of each day
  • Organ changes due to glycogen accumulation
  • Excessive lactic acid generation
  • Damage to tissue from hyperuricemia
  • In GSD bleeding and infection risk from blood cell effects

questions.text: Which is the shortest-acting muscle relaxant?
questions.solution:
Suxamethonium (succinylcholine) is the shortest-acting muscle relaxant.

It has a rapid onset (30–60 s) and short duration of action (typically less than 10 min) due to rapid hydrolysis by butyrylcholinesterase (plasma cholinesterase or pseudocholinesterase).

questions.text: A child is born with the abnormality shown in the given image. What would you recommend for the mother in the next pregnancy?

choices.text: 400 μg of folic acid after confirmation of pregnancy

questions.solution:
The given image shows spina bifida, the most common neural tube defect (NTD). 4000 μg of folic acid periconceptionally is given to prevent NTDs in subsequent pregnancies.

The normal dose of folic acid in pregnancy is 400 μg (0.4 mg). However, the history of a previous pregnancy with an NTD raises the risk of another NTD in subsequent pregnancies. An increased dose of folic acid is therefore given prophylactically during the periconceptional period to prevent NTD in the next child.

Folic acid (daily dose):

  • Routine dosage to all normal pregnancies: 400 μg (0.4 mg)
  • Dosage for women having a previous child with NTD: 4000 μg (4 mg)

questions.text: The most common drug which causes physical dependence is ________.
questions.solution:
Heroin is the most common drug which can cause physical dependence.

Physical dependence is defined is a condition where withdrawal of a drug after its prolonged use causes physiological and emotional illness, often referred to as the withdrawal syndrome. Neither physical dependence nor withdrawal symptoms occur with hallucinogens. Although it is necessary to note that a user can develop a psychological dependence on the insight-inducing experiences of episodes of hallucinogen use. Hence, all 3 hallucinogens - ketamine, LSD, and Phencyclidine (PCP) does not cause physical dependence.

According to the world drug report 2019, released by the United Nations office on drugs and crime (UNODC), the most common drugs used across the world (in decreasing order) include:

  • Cannabis
  • Opioids
  • Amphetamine and prescription stimulants
  • Ecstacy
  • Cocaine

Among the opioids, the commonly used group of drugs are opiates which include drugs like opium, morphine, and heroin.

 

The prefrontal cortex powers the ability to exert self-control over impulses. This is also the last part of the brain to mature, making teens most vulnerable. Shifting balance between this circuit and the circuits of the basal ganglia and extended amygdala make a person with a substance use disorder seek the drug compulsively with reduced impulse control.

questions.text: A woman is admitted to the hospital for the management of breast cancer. The tumor is 3 cm in size with ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes. There is no distant metastasis. The TNM staging of tumor is ______.
questions.solution:
The TNM staging of the tumor is T2 N1 M0.

  • Tumor size 3 cm: T2 
  • Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes: N1
  • No distant metastasis: M0

Points to remember

  • In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is taken into consideration. For example, in a 6 x 2 cm lump, 6 cm is taken into account, and the tumor is classified as T3 (>5 cm).
  • Skin involvement does not include nipple retraction and skin dimpling.
  • Any contralateral lymph node involvement is considered as distant metastasis.
  • If 2 lumps are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger lump.
  • If lumps are present in both breasts, separate staging is done for both the lumps.

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of carcinoma breast

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered a benign condition and not included under Tis.

Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)
  • p: pathological (histological) staging
  • y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)
  • r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

  • m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

questions.text: What is called the ‘heart’ of a randomized control trial (RCT)?
questions.solution:
Randomization is the heart of an RCT and in this step, study and control groups are allocated. It helps in eliminating bias and allowing comparability. It is done after consent is obtained.

Related Pearl: Randomized Control Trials

Randomized controlled trials are a type of experimental studies.

General Design of an RCT

Steps of an RCT

  • Drawing up a protocol
  • Selecting reference and experimental population
  • Randomization
  • Manipulation or intervention
  • Follow-up
  • Assessment of outcome

Types

  • Clinical trials
  • Preventive trials
  • Risk factor trials
  • Cessation experiments
  • Trial of etiological agents
  • Evaluation of health services

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient with a history of smoking presented with a painless palpable mass in the parotid region. The biopsy of the mass is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical presentation and histopathological slide showing epithelial elements with lymphoid infiltration are suggestive of a Warthin tumor (papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum) of the parotid gland.

Warthin tumor is the second most common salivary gland neoplasm. It is seen in elderly male smokers. It is a benign, well-encapsulated cystic tumor.

The gross appearance of these tumors shows round to oval encapsulated masses, easily palpable in the superficial parotid. Transection reveals a pale grey surface punctuated by cleft-like spaces filled with mucinous or serous secretions.

Histologically, the tumor shows epithelial and lymphoid elements. The epithelium typically consists of a double layer of oncocytic epithelial cells, with an inner columnar layer and an outer cuboidal layer.

Other options:

Option A: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is poorly encapsulated infiltrative carcinoma involving minor salivary glands, commonly the palatine glands. Histology shows tumor cells, organized in a cribriform growth pattern, resembling Swiss cheese. The image is shown below.

Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary gland, commonly affecting the parotid gland. Many are associated with a balanced t(11;19)(q21;p13) chromosomal translocation. Histology shows mucinous, intermediate, and squamous elements, with small to large mucus-filled vacuoles. Image is shown below.

Option D: Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms. The parotid gland is most commonly involved. They are benign tumors that consist of a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells. Image is shown below.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: Bryce sign is seen in_______.
questions.solution:
Bryce sign is seen in laryngocele.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cavity within the larynx developing in the saccule. Patient presents with a neck swelling that is soft and compressible. On compressing the swelling, there is a gurgling/hissing sound (Bryce sign).

questions.text: Which of the following diseases shows the iceberg phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Tuberculosis shows the iceberg phenomenon.

The iceberg phenomenon of diseases is not shown by diseases such as tetanus, rabies, and measles.

The iceberg phenomenon refers to the concept that only a fraction of cases of a disease are visible or reported, with a larger "hidden" burden below the surface. Once a patient is diagnosed and treated, the impact of underdiagnosis or hidden cases on individual treatment outcomes is minimal. Treatment effectiveness depends more on factors such as drug efficacy, patient adherence, and healthcare delivery rather than the overall prevalence of the disease in the population.

Iceberg phenomenon is shown by:

  • Polio
  • Influenza
  • Rubella
  • Mumps
  • Japanese Encephalitis
  • Diphtheria
  • Hepatitis A and B

Note: Rubella shows a large number of subclinical infections. Thus, it is considered to show the iceberg phenomenon.

questions.text: Which of the following is a leading cause of diarrheal death in children?
questions.solution:
Rotavirus is a leading cause of diarrheal death among children in the developing world.

 

Vaccines for rotavirus: RotaTeq and Rotarix gien orally.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman came with complaints of abdominal pain, shortness of breath, and vomiting for a few hours. She is on ovulation induction therapy for infertility.  Her sonogram of both ovaries is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the sonogram showing enlarged ovaries meeting in the midline having large cysts are suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. 

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is an iatrogenic complication seen during the luteal phase or early pregnancy. It is seen in patients taking ovulation induction therapies for infertility more common in FSH/LH therapy than clomiphene or pulsatile GnRH therapies. 

The pathogenesis in OHSS is the increased vascular permeability leading to a fluid shift from intravascular to extravascular space.

They often present with shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and gastrointestinal disturbances like nausea, vomiting, and oliguria. Abdominal pain occurs due to ovarian enlargement and accumulation of peritoneal fluid. Increased vascular permeability and loss of fluid, protein, and electrolytes into the peritoneal cavity cause ascites and result in hemoconcentration. Hemoconcentration causes hyperviscosity and leads to hypercoagulability. Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, leukocytosis, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion can be associated with OHSS. 

This condition can be prevented by

  • Withholding hCG in a cycle if there are more than 20 follicles on ultrasound and E2 level rises to 3000 pg/ mL.
  • Albumin 5% infusion in 500 mL lactated Ringer’s solution during and after oocyte retrieval
  • Dopamine agonist cabergoline 0.5 mg daily for 8 days starting on day 1 of hCG.

OHSS is primarily managed with general supportive care. Paracentesis is performed to ameliorate abdominal discomfort and relieve respiratory discomfort.

Other options:

Option B- Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is the most common endocrine disorder of the reproductive age group. Patients with PCOS present with menstrual irregularities, hirsutism, acne, infertility, etc.

The ultrasound examination image shown below is of PCOS showing enlarged ovaries with multiple cysts. 


Option C- Hyperreactio luteinalis is a condition in which one or both ovaries develop multiple large theca lutein cysts. They are commonly seen in gestational trophoblastic disease, multiple gestational pregnancies, and other high HCG states. Most of them resolve spontaneously after delivery. Surgical management is only required if it is complicated by torsion or hemorrhage. 

The below image shows bilaterally enlarged ovaries with multiple theca luteal cysts as in hyperreactio luteinalis.


Option D- Hematometra is a condition in which menstrual outflow obstruction traps the blood and distends the uterus.  A large uterus can compress the urinary bladder, and rectum causing urinary retention and constipation. blood may get infected and lead to pyometra causing fever and leukocytosis.

The below ultrasonographic image shows a smooth, symmetric hypoechoic enlargement of the uterine cavity suggestive of hematometra.

questions.text: Which proton-pump inhibitor should be avoided in a patient on warfarin anticoagulation?
questions.solution:
Omeprazole should not be used in a patient on warfarin therapy as it decreases the metabolism of warfarin. 

All proton-pump inhibitors (PPIs) are metabolized by hepatic P450 cytochromes, including CYP2C19 and CYP3A4, and may interfere with the metabolism of the other drugs. They inhibit the metabolism of clopidogrel, diazepam, and phenytoin.

Note: There is disagreement among different authors regarding the PPIs and their interactions with the metabolism of other drugs.

  • Goodman and Gilman mention that lansoprazole and rabeprazole along with omeprazole and esomeprazole interact with the metabolism of warfarin.
  • Katzung and various online sources agree that lansoprazole and rabeprazole do not or minimally interact with warfarin metabolism.
  • All of them agree that pantoprazole does not or minimally interacts with warfarin metabolism.

questions.text: The numerator of perinatal mortality rate includes ___________.

choices.text: Early neonatal death of fetus > 1000 g

questions.solution:
Early neonatal death of fetus > 1000 g is included in the numerator of perinatal mortality rate .

Perinatal mortality rate is described as late fetal and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000 grams at birth expressed as a ratio per 1000 live births weighing over 1000 grams at birth.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male complaints of a weak urine stream and frequent urination in small amounts for the past month. He often feels lightheaded and has low blood pressure. Which of the following alpha-blockers will you prefer to give him?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and tamsulosin should be given to this patient as it has the least effect on blood pressure. 

It is an α-blocker that has more selectivity towards α1A/1D when compared to α1B receptors. The vasodilatory effects are mainly attributed to the blockade of α1B receptors present on blood vessels.

The relief of BPH symptoms is mainly due to the blockade of α1A receptors present predominantly in the prostatic stroma. It lacks the apoptotic effect on prostatic cells that is seen with terazosin and doxazosin.

Related Pearl: Benign prostatic hyperplasia treatment

  • Static component: 5 alpha-reductase inhibitor [eg: Finasteride]
  • Dynamic component: Alpha 1 blockers [eg: Tamsulosin, terazosin etc]

questions.text: Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of:
questions.solution:
Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with development of dilated cardiomyopathy.

Alcohol and its metabolites (especially acetaldehyde) have a direct toxic effect on the myocardium which leads to the development of dilated cardiomyopathy.

Toxins associated with heart muscle diseases
Alcohol
Cobalt
Lead
Mercury
Catecholamines (as in individuals with pheochromocytoma)
Carbon monoxide
Lithium
Hydrocarbons
Arsenic
Cyclophosphamide
Doxorubicin and daunorubicin

questions.text: A patient reports that he feels like the room is spinning when he rises from the lying position or when he turns his head. He has no history of loss of consciousness. Which of the following could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the symptoms, the most probable diagnosis is benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).

  • BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo and the episodes are brief (<1 min) and are always provoked by changes in head position.
  • The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal.
  • The Epley maneuver is done to reposition the crystals into the macula from the semicircular canals.

Epley's maneuver is performed to reposition the crystals into the macula from the semicircular canals. Most people are cured after this maneuver, but some may require repeats. 

The Epley's maneuver consists of five positions:

  Head and neck Body position
Position 1 Head turned 45° To lie down in a head-hanging position
Position 2

The head is turned so that the affected ear is facing up at 90° rotation

 -
Position 3 The whole body and head rotated away from the affected ear in a 90° rotation face-down position -
Position 4 Patient is moved to a sitting position and head still turned to unaffected side by 45° Brought to sitting position
Position 5 Head turned forward with chin brought down 20° -

questions.text: Which of the following structures are involved in the unhappy triad?
questions.solution:
The unhappy triad of O’Donoghue consists of injury to

  • Anterior cruciate ligament (A)
  • Medial collateral ligament (B)
  • Medial meniscus (C)

Related Pearl: Unhappy triad of knee joint

It is also called as – O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triangle. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to lateral blow to the knee. It is characterized by injury to: 

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

Image: Unhappy triad injury in MRI (after O'Donoghue) of the knee joint (PDW SPIR). Left to right: Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament, rupture of the medial collateral ligament, and inner meniscal tear (here complex rupture of the posterior horn).

questions.text: Which of the following IPC sections deals with miscarriage of a woman without her consent?
questions.solution:
IPC 313 deals with the causation of miscarriage of a woman with child (and/or quick with child) without her consent. Only the person causing the abortion is liable to punishment. 

Other options:

Option A: IPC 315 deals with the intent to prevent a child from being born alive or to cause its death after birth. The pre-requisite associated with this IPC is that the fetus must be in an advanced stage of development that would make it sufficiently capable of leading an extra-uterine existence. The offender is liable to punishment consisting of imprisonment for up to 10 years.

Option C: IPC 312 deals with the causation of criminal abortion (no therapeutic indication to do so) with the consent of the pregnant woman. Both the pregnant woman and the abortionist are liable to punishment. 

Option D: IPC 314 deals with the death of a pregnant woman from an act intended to cause miscarriage. In such a case, the abortionist/offender is liable to punishment including imprisonment of at least 10 years and a fine of up to 2 lakh rupees. If the act of miscarriage was undertaken after conducting a prenatal sex determination (female fetus confirmation), the offender is liable to life imprisonment and a fine of up to 2 lakh rupees.

questions.text: A young woman has a fear of getting into elevators since birth. She prefers stairs over elevators. She is also scared to use public transport. What is this condition known as?
questions.solution:
This woman with a fear of elevators and public transport, but prefers stairs over elevators from where she can escape easily has agoraphobia.

Agoraphobia is the anxiety that occurs when one is in a public or crowded place, from which a potential escape is difficult, or help may not be readily available. example crowds, public places, or public transportation.

It is more common in women. It leads to severe restrictions on the individual’s travel and daily routine.

Option A: Claustrophobia - Fear of closed spaces

Option B: Aerophobia - Fear of flying 

Option D: Ailurophobia - Fear of cats

Note: Specific phobia is the most common type of phobia. Agoraphobia is not a specific phobia and is classified separately under anxiety disorders.

Some special terms:

  • Acrophobia: Fear of heights
  • Agoraphobia: Fear of the places from where easy escape is not possible
  • Xenophobia: fear of strangers
  • Zoophobia: fear of animals
  • Claustrophobia: fear of closed spaces

questions.text: Methyltetrahydrofolic acid gets accumulated in deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Accumulation of methyltetrahydrofolic acid is seen in vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 acts as a cofactor of methionine synthase, an enzyme involved in the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from methyl-tetrahydrofolate. Hence, in vitamin B12 deficiency methyl-tetrahydrofolate accumulates leading to functional folate deficiency known as the folate trap.

 

The conversion of 5,10-methylene-THF into 5-methyl-THF (methyltetrahydrofolate) is an irreversible process. The major source of tetrahydrofolate for tissues is 5-methyl-THF. The only way to make further use of 5-methyl-THF and to maintain the folate cycle is by the vitamin B12-dependent remethylation of homocysteine to methionine by the methionine synthase enzyme.

Decreased activity of methionine synthase in vitamin B12 deficiency results in the accumulation of methyltetrahydrofolate, which cannot be used, resulting in a folate trap. The folate cycle acts as the link between the functions of folate and vitamin B12, and deficiency of vitamin B12 can cause a functional deficiency of folate.

Note: Since vitamin B12 is also linked to the regeneration of methionine from homocysteine, its deficiency can result in hyperhomocysteinemia as well. This in turn increases the risk of atherosclerosis, hypertension, and thrombosis.

questions.text: The structure marked in the cadaveric image given below, arises at the ______.
questions.solution:
The marked structure can be identified as the superior mesenteric artery, as it lies anterior and superior to the left renal vein. The superior mesenteric artery originated from the abdominal aorta at the level of the lower border of the L1 vertebra, about 1 cm below the celiac trunk. 

Branches of the superior mesentric artery:

  • Jejunal branches
  • Ileal branches
  • Middle colic artery
  • Right colic artery
  • Ileocolic artery
  • Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery

Clinical note - Nutcracker syndrome:

  • The compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery, appears in the sagittal plane, as if a nutcracker is crushing a nut (left renal vein).
  • This condition is called nutcracker (left renal vein entrapment) syndrome.

questions.text: A medical student is giving her histology exam. She got the following slide in the exam. What could the structure be?
questions.solution:
The above histology image shows Glomerulus.

Glomerulus is a rounded tuft of anastomosing capillaries lined by fenestrated endothelium. Blood enters the tuft through an afferent arteriole and leaves it through an efferent arteriole. It is supported by the mesangium containing mesangial cells and a non-cellular mesangial matrix.

The glomerular capillary wall is the filtering membrane and consists of fenestrated endothelial cells, basement membrane, and visceral epithelial cells called podocytes, which contain foot processes.

The image given below shows the histology of the glomerulus.

Option A: Leydig cells also known as interstitial cells of Leydig are present in the interstitial connective tissue between seminiferous tubules.

Testis contains numerous seminiferous tubules separated by connective tissue in between. Seminiferous tubules are lined by several spermatogonia cells which produce spermatozoa, and Sertoli (sustentacular) cells which have a supportive function. 

The connective tissue in between the tubules is made up of Leydig cells, collagen fibers, fibroblasts, macrophages, mast cells, blood vessels, and lymphatics. Leydig cells are large, round, or polyhedral cells with eccentric nuclei. They are lightly stained and often have a foamy appearance. They secrete testosterone upon stimulation by luteinizing hormone from the anterior pituitary.

The image below shows seminiferous tubules and Leydig cells.

Option B: Islets of Langerhans makes up the endocrine part of the pancreas.

Islets are characterized by secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers, and containing numerous fenestrated capillaries. There is a delicate capsule around each islet. They are paler than the surrounding exocrine cells, as they have less rough endoplasmic reticulum.

The Islet of Langerhans is mainly composed of three types of cells:

  • α or A cells- located peripherally and secrete glucagon 
  • β or B cells- located centrally and produce insulin 
  • δ or D cells- scattered between beta cells and secrete somatostatin

The image given below shows the Islets of Langerhans.

Option C: Hassall's corpuscles are small rounded structures present in the medulla of the thymus. Each corpuscle has a central core of degenerated epithelial cells and macrophages surrounded by concentrically arranged epithelial cells. The degenerated cells ultimately give pink staining hyaline mass. The function of the corpuscles of Hassall is still not known.

The image given below shows Hasssall's corpuscle.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common malignant tumor involving the parotid gland?
questions.solution:
Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor, while pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the parotid gland.

Histological classification and incidence of tumors of salivary glands:

Benign Tumors Incidence Malignant tumors Incidence
Pleomorphic adenoma 50% Mucoepidermoid carcinoma 15%
Warthin’s tumor 5–10% Adenocarcinoma (NOS) 10%
Oncocytoma 1% Acinic cell carcinoma 5%
Other adenomas 5–10% Adenoid cystic carcinoma 5%
Basal cell adenoma  1-2% Malignant mixed tumor 3–5%
Canalicular adenoma 1%  Squamous cell carcinoma 1%
Ductal papillomas  - Other carcinomas 2%

NOS: Not otherwise specified.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: During your casualty rotation, you accidentally injure yourself while suturing a patient. You had taken the full schedule of hepatitis B vaccination during your first year of medical school. Which of the following markers will you get measured to determine the need for HBIG administration?
questions.solution:
The need for administration of hepatitis B hyperimmune globulin (HBIG) in a previously vaccinated individual can be determined based on anti-HBsAg levels. It is the marker for determining the efficacy of hepatitis B vaccination.

The complete hepatitis B vaccine schedule consists of three intramuscular doses at 0, 1, and 6 months.

Post Exposure Prophylaxis:

The prophylaxis can be done using the hepatitis B vaccine or hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG).

Vaccination status of the exposed person Recommended prophylaxis
Unvaccinated HBIG (0.06 mL/kg) and initiate hepatitis B vaccine series
Known responder to previous vaccination (anti-HBs titer>10 mIU/mL) No action required
Non-responder to previous vaccination (anti-HBs titer <10 mIU/mL) HBIG: 2 doses (1 month apart) OR HBIG: 1 dose + initiate hepatitis B revaccination.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

questions.text: A 45-year-old man underwent emergency surgery following a road traffic accident. The surgery was performed under general anesthesia. Two days later, he developed features of respiratory failure. Which of the following types is likely to be present in him?
questions.solution:
The features of respiratory failure in the perioperative period of this patient is most likely due to lung atelectasis. Type 3 respiratory failure is most likely to be present in him.

Type 3 respiratory failure is also known as perioperative respiratory failure.

After general anesthesia, there is a decrease in functional residual capacity due to a reduction in muscular tone. This leads to airway closure and the collapse of the dependent lung units.

Atelectasis can be treated by frequent changes in position, chest physiotherapy, upright positioning, and control of incisional and abdominal pain. Non-invasive positive-pressure ventilation may also be used to reverse regional atelectasis.

Related Pearl: Types of respiratory failure

 

Type Name Mechanism Associated conditions
I Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure Alveolar flooding and subsequent intrapulmonary shunt physiology. Sepsis, gastric aspiration, pneumonia, near-drowning, multiple blood transfusions and pancreatitis.
II

Hypoxemia with hypercapnia

 Results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively. Drug overdose, brainstem injury, sleep-disordered breathing, severe hypothyroidism, myasthenia gravis, Guillain-Barre syndrome and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
III Peri-operative respiratory failure Results from lung atelectasis. After general anesthesia.
IV Shock Results from hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles in patients with shock Cardiogenic shock.

questions.text: True labor pain includes all except _____
questions.solution:
True labor pains are not relieved by enema.

Features True labor pains False labor pains
Cervical changes (dilatation and effacement) Present Absent
Pain Lower abdomen and back, radiating to the thighs Lower abdomen only
Show Present Absent
Bag of water Formed Absent
Relief with enema No Yes

questions.text: The transdermal patch of the cholinesterase inhibitor,  _________, is available for use in Alzheimer's disease.
questions.solution:
The transdermal patch of the cholinesterase inhibitor rivastigmine is available for use in Alzheimer's disease. It can be applied for over 24 hours. Transdermal delivery reduces the fluctuation and avoids direct gastric irritation effects associated with oral formulations. 

Tacrine use is obsolete because of its association with hepatotoxicity. (Option A)

Donepezil and galantamine transdermal formulations are under development and yet to be available in the market. (Options B and D)

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with acidity, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss for the past few months. Her symptoms are not relieved by taking antacids. An endoscopic evaluation shows ulcers on the second part of the duodenum. Which of the following conditions should be suspected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of symptoms not improving with antacids, associated diarrhea, and the unusual location of ulcers are highly suggestive of Zollinger Ellison syndrome.

Zollinger Ellison syndrome (ZES) is peptic ulcer disease caused by unregulated gastrin release from a neuroendocrine tumor/gastrinoma. Gastrin hypersecretion stimulates gastric acid secretion. This leads to peptic ulcers that occur at atypical sites like the duodenum and jejunum and are refractory and multiple.

The clinical presentation of ZES is very similar to that of peptic ulcer disease. The features which help in suspecting ZES include:

  • ulcers in unusual locations- the second part of the duodenum and beyond
  • ulcers refractory to medical therapy
  • associated with diarrhea
  • ulcers presenting with complications like bleeding and perforation
  • ulcers not associated with H. pylori or NSAID ingestion

Abdominal pain is the most common complaint in these patients. However, diarrhea can occur due to acid-induced injury to the small intestine mucosa, inability of the intestinal tract to absorb large volumes of fluids secreted by the stomach, inactivation of pancreatic lipase by low pH, and precipitation of bile salts. The unique characteristic of acid-induced diarrhea is that it is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions. 

Patients of ZES often have associated diarrhea and involvement of the esophagus (esophagitis, ulceration, or stricture).

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: The predominant subtype of muscarinic receptor in the heart is _______.
questions.solution:
The predominant subtype of muscarinic receptor in the heart is M2.

The receptors in the autonomic nervous system (ANS) are of 2 types:

  • Muscarinic
    • 5 Subtypes - M1, M2, M3, M4, M5
  • Nicotinic
    • 2 Subtypes - Nm(Neuromuscular junction), Nn(CNS, Ganglion, Adrenal glands)
Receptors in Parasympathetic system Subtype Found in
Nicotinic Nm Neuromuscular junction
Nn CNS, ganglia, Adrenal gland
Muscarinic M1 CNS, Ganglia, Salivary, and gastric glands
M2 Heart
M3 Smooth muscles, secretory glands, eyes - pupils, and blood vessels
M4 CNS
M5 CNS

questions.text: Which among the following options describes the chest x-ray image?
questions.solution:
The chest x-ray image shows "coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart, which is seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

  • "Coeur en sabot" is due to cardiac apex elevation as a result of right ventricular hypertrophy. The cardiac silhouette has been likened to that of a boot (“coeur-en sabot”).
  • The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries.
  • The aorta is usually large.

Image: Boot-shaped heart or Coeur-en-sabot

questions.text: The given image shows the oral examination findings of a chronic smoker. Identify the lesion shown.
questions.solution:
The given image with a white lesion of the tongue in a smoker is suggestive of leukoplakia, a pre-malignant lesion of the oral cavity. 

 Leukoplakia:

  • WHO defines oral leukoplakia as a white patch that cannot be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other disease.
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia occurs due to the reactivation of Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) infection and usually occurs in association with immunodeficiency due to HIV infection.
  • Clinical presentation (OHL): HIV-infected patient presenting with white corrugated plaque over the lateral border of the tongue, which cannot be rubbed off. 
  • Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity. The management includes the elimination of associated etiological factors and biopsy of the lesion.
  • A photographic record of the lesion is useful for long-term follow-up.
  • Specific management includes surgical excision or ablation with laser or cryotherapy can be done.

White lesions of oral mucosa:

  • Lichen planus
  • Discoid lupus erythematosus
  • White spongy nevus
  • Candidiasis
  • Leukoplakia

questions.text: A pediatrician suspects vesicoureteric reflux in a girl with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. What is the investigation of choice to confirm this condition?
questions.solution:
Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) is the investigation of choice for vesicoureteral reflux.

Recurrent febrile urinary tract infections in a child should raise the suspicion of an anatomical defect like vesicoureteric reflux as the cause. Compared to other investigations, a VCUG provides more anatomic information.

It can demonstrate

  • Vesicoureteral reflux
  • Duplex collecting system
  • Ectopic ureter
  • Paraureteral (bladder) diverticulum
  • Bladder outlet obstruction
  • Signs of voiding dysfunction, such as a spinning top urethra

questions.solution:
The membranous part of the male urethra appears stellate in transverse section, which is represented by 2 in the image.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with chest pain on the left side radiating to the arm and jaw on the same side. Cardiac troponins are found to be raised. What is the diagnosis based on this ECG?
questions.solution:
The given ECG is of posterior wall MI.

The ECG findings in posterior wall MI include,

  • Reciprocal ST depressions in leads V1 to V3. Posterior wall ischemia is indirectly recognized in this way
  • Tall and broad R waves (>30ms) in V2 and V3
  • Dominant R waves (R/S ratio > 1) in V2
  • Upright terminal portions of the T waves in V2 and V3
     

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, a child presents with abdominal pain. On examination, vitals are stable and tenderness is present in the left lumbar region. What is the investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with abdominal pain and tenderness in the left lumbar region following a road traffic accident is suggestive of blunt renal trauma. The investigation of choice is contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) in a hemodynamically stable patient.

Blunt trauma is the main cause of renal injuries and is self-limiting. Radiological investigations are indicated when there is gross hematuria, shock in combination with microscopic hematuria, pediatric renal trauma, and penetrating injuries.

CECT is the investigation of choice. It assesses the extent of the injury, showing laceration, extravasation, surrounding hemorrhage, and vessel injury. It also shows non-renal injuries and effectively stages renal pedicle injuries. Arterial occlusion will manifest as rim enhancement of the normal renal contour.

Blunt trauma is mostly treated conservatively. Most penetrating injuries require surgical renal exploration.

Absolute indications for surgical intervention in renal trauma are

  • Massive hemorrhage
  • Renal pedicle avulsion (grade 5 injury)
  • Expanding, pulsatile, or uncontained retroperitoneal hematoma

Relative indications are

  • Large laceration of the renal pelvis or avulsion of the ureteropelvic junction
  • Bowel or pancreatic injuries
  • Persistent urinary leakage, postinjury urinoma, or perinephric abscess 
  • Complete renal artery thrombosis of both kidneys 
  • Renal hypertension

Exploratory laparotomy is recommended in stable patients with penetrating renal injuries.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) kidney Injury Scale

GRADE  

 INJURY DESCRIPTION
I

Contusion

Microscopic or gross hematuria, urologic studies normal
  Hematoma

Subcapsular, nonexpanding, without parenchymal laceration
II

Hematoma

Nonexpanding perirenal hematoma confined to renal retroperitoneum
  Laceration

 <1 cm parenchymal depth of renal cortex without urinary extravasation
III

Laceration 

>1 cm depth of renal cortex, without collecting system rupture or urinary extravasation
IV Laceration

Parenchymal laceration extending through the renal cortex, medulla, and collecting system
  Vascular

Main renal artery or vein injury, with contained hemorrhage
V Laceration Completely shattered kidney
  Laceration   Avulsion of renal hilum, which devascularizes kidney

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady presents to the gynecology OPD  with complaints of mass descending per vaginum for the past 6 months.  On examination, she has a grade 3 uterovaginal prolapse and a decubitus ulcer over the prolapse. Which of the following is a cause for this decubitus ulcer and treatment?

choices.text: Venous congestion and reduction of the prolapsed part into the vagina and daily packing with glycerine and acriflavine

questions.solution:
Decubitus ulcer seen in prolapsed organs is due to venous congestion and local circulatory changes and not due to trauma, friction.

Treatment includes the reduction of the prolapsed part into the vagina and daily packing with glycerine and acriflavine. Acriflavine is an antiseptic agent while glycerine is a hygroscopic agent.

It has a clean edge. It usually heals within one or two weeks with this treatment.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 2-year-old child and complains that he has not begun walking or talking. On examination, there is microcephaly, fair hair, light-colored skin, and blue eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 2 year old child with poor development of milestones and feautures like microcephaly, light hair and skin, points to the diagnosis of Phenylketonuria (PKU).  

Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an inborn error of metabolism seen due to a defect in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (classic phenylketonuria) and less commonly, due to a defect in BH4 synthase (non-classical). These defects result in the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. The patient develops clinical features due to elevated levels of phenylalanine metabolites and decreased levels of tyrosine. The excess phenylalanine in the blood is metabolized to phenylpyruvate (positive ferric chloride) and phenylacetate (mousy odour) which are excreted in the urine. Infants appear normal at birth and gradually develop symptoms of hyperreflexia, seizures, hypopigmentation, low IQ, hyperactivity, and tremors.

Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria:

  • Mental retardation
  • Failure to walk or talk
  • Seizures
  • Hyperactivity
  • Tremor
  • Microcephaly
  • Failure to grow
  • Deficiency of pigmentation (fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes)

Management phenylketonuria include:

Guthrie test is a screening test that shows with absence of growth of Bacillus subtilis.

Tandem mass spectroscopy is the investigation of choice.

The ferric chloride test is positive with the development of a transient blue-green colour.

A diet low in phenylalanine and supplementation of tyrosine can prevent the mental retardation of PKU.  They should avoid aspartame which is an artificial sweetener containing phenylalanine. Sucralose is an artificial sweetener that is safe to use in PKU as it does not contain phenylalanine (Option D)

Other options:

Option A: Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes. Symptoms include albinism with vision problems like strabismus, photophobia, nystagmus, impaired vision/blindness or astigmatism. Neuropsychiatric manifestations are not seen.

Option C: Alkaptunuria is an inborn error of metabolism due to the deficiency of an enzyme homogentisate oxidase, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in connective tissue resulting in ochronosis. Due to the oxidation and polymerization of homogenetic acid, it shows a characteristic blackening of urine on standing for a long time or black stain in diapers. They often present in the third to the fourth decade of life. 

Option D: Type I tyrosinemia is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. Children present with mild mental retardation, liver failure, and hypoglycemia. Urine typically has a boiled cabbage odour. Boiled cabbage odour can also be found in cases of hypermethioninemia.

Related Pearl: Phenylketonuria

  1. BH4 - tetrahydrobiopterin (or sapropterin, a synthetic form of BH4)

questions.text: An intern was asked to give an intravenous injection to a vein in the cubital fossa. All the following are true about the cubital fossa, except _________.

choices.text: Musculocutaneous nerve is one of the contents
Radial nerve enters the fossa laterally
Median cubital vein forms the roof

questions.solution:
All the above statements are true about the cubital fossa, except the musculocutaneous nerve is one of the contents.

The cubital fossa is a triangular depression present in the anterior side of the elbow joint. The boundaries of the cubital fossa include:

  • Medially: Lateral border of the pronator teres.
  • Laterally: Medial border of the brachioradialis. (option A)
  • Base: Proximally by an imaginary line joining the epicondyles of the humerus.
  • Apex (pointed downward): Joining of the lateral and medial boundaries.
  • Roof: Skin, superficial fascia containing median cubital vein (option D) joining the cephalic and basilic veins, lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, medial cutaneous nerve of the forearm, bicipital aponeurosis, and deep fascia.
  • Floor: Brachialis and supinator muscles.

The contents of the brachial fossa are (from medial to lateral side):

  • Median nerve
  • Brachial artery, terminating into radial and ulnar arteries
  • Biceps brachii tendon with the bicipital aponeurosis
  • Radial nerve enters the fossa laterally (option C) in the groove between the brachialis and brachioradialis

Clinical significance:

  • The median cubital vein is the most commonly preferred vein of choice for intravenous injections. 
  • Auscultation of the brachial artery in front of the elbow helps in measuring the blood pressure.

questions.text: The most common pneumoconiosis in the world is _________.
questions.solution:
Silicosis is the most common pneumoconiosis in the world.

Silicosis is caused by inhalation of crystalline silica (e.g., quartz). Individuals involved with the concrete work, sandblasting, stone carvers, and jewelers using chalk molds are at high risk.

Pneumoconioses encompass a group of chronic fibrosing diseases of the lung resulting from exposure to organic and inorganic particulates, most commonly mineral dust.

questions.text: In triage, immediate treatment necessity is indicated by which color code?
questions.solution:
Red color indicates the need for immediate treatment/first priority.

Triage is used to classify the priority of treatment.

It is carried out at the site of the disaster to determine the priority for immediate medical attention, transportation, and admission to the hospital.

Triage includes rapid classification of the injured based on their injuries and the chances of survival with prompt medical intervention. It provides maximum benefit to the greatest number of injured in a disaster situation. It lessens the burden on medical facilities.

The internationally accepted four-color coded system is used commonly:

  • Red - First (I) priority; Immediate attention or transfer; Critical, but likely to survive if treatment is given early
  • Yellow - Second (II) priority; Urgent, Critical, likely to survive if treatment is given within hours
  • Green - Third (III) Non-urgent; Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days
  • Black - Last (0) Unsalvageable; Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help

START triage scheme – Simple Triage And Rapid Treatment

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: What is the recommended dietary allowance of folic acid for a 5-year-old child?
questions.solution:
The recommended dietary allowance of folic acid in a 5-year child is 150μg.

questions.text: A patient developed a loss of sensation over the root of the penis, following laparoscopic hernia surgery. Injury to which of the following causes this?
questions.solution:
Loss of sensation at the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum is suggestive of an injury to the ilioinguinal nerve. It is most commonly injured within the inguinal canal in hernia repair due to traction or thermal injury.

The iliohypogastric nerve (Option B) carries the sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve in the right iliac fossa rarely causes sensory disturbances, as the suprapubic area has a rich nerve supply from other sources too. If the nerve is severed above the anterior superior iliac spine, it can lead to the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal resulting in a direct inguinal hernia. The iliohypogastric nerve can also get injured following appendicectomy.

Injury to the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve (Option C) results in loss of sensation in the skin of the scrotum of males, and loss of sensation of the mons pubis and labia majora in females. 

Injury to the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve causes hypoesthesia over the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament.

The medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh (Option D) is a sensory branch of the femoral nerve. Injury to this nerve leads to loss of sensations over the areas supplied by this nerve, which include anterior-medial aspect of the thigh and knee.

questions.text: AIDS-defining malignancies include all except :
questions.solution:
Melanoma is not an AIDS-defining malignancy.

AIDS-defining malignancies are those cancers that a human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infected person is at a high risk of developing. When a HIV-infected person develops one of the AIDS-defining malignancies it suggests that he has AIDS.

AIDS-defining malignancies include the following: 

  • Kaposi sarcoma - It is a multicentric neoplasm of vascular origin and has strong association with HHV - 8.
  • Non-Hodgkins lymphoma and
  • Invasive cervical cancer. 

Given below is the image of kaposi sarcoma:

Note : The FDA has approved pomalidomide, a thalidomide analogue to be included in treating adult patients with AIDS-related Kaposi's sarcoma after failure of highly active antiretroviral therapy and Kaposi's sarcoma in adult patients who are HIV-negative.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasms found in patients with HIV infection

Infections

  • Protozoal and Helminthic Infections
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal Infections
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial Infections
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral Infections
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

 

One-liners about HIV

  • Sexual contact is the least efficacious yet most common mode of spread of HIV infection
  • ELISA is used for the detection of antibodies against viral proteins. This is the most sensitive and the best screening test for the diagnosis of AIDS.
  • Western blot is the most specific or the confirmatory test for HIV.
  • Candidiasis is the most common fungal infection in patients with AIDS.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) chorioretinitis exclusively in patients with CD4+ T cell counts less than 50 per microliter.
  • Toxoplasma gondii causes encephalitis and is responsible for 50% of all mass lesions in the central nervous system.
  • John Cunningham virus (JC virus) is a human papovavirus that causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.
  • Persistent diarrhea in AIDS is caused by Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli, or microsporidia.
  • AIDS-dementia complex is the most common neurological manifestation of HIV infection.
  • Inflammatory myopathy is the commonest skeletal muscle disorder in HIV.

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text: A young woman presents with skin rashes shown in the image below. She also complains of  easy bruisability and bleeding from gums. Her CBC report revealed platelet count 15,000/µL, normal RBC and WBC counts. Her peripheral smear was normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is immune thrombocytopenic purpura.

The given image showing petechiae and the clinical scenario are suggestive of a bleeding disorder. CBC shows isolated thrombocytopenia and peripheral smear does not reveal any hemolysis. Hence, the other conditions are ruled out. 

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is an acquired disorder with autoantibodies against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It can either be primary (idiopathic) or secondary to autoimmune conditions like SLE or infections like HIV and hepatitis C.

It presents with features of mucocutaneous bleeding. CBC shows isolated thrombocytopenia and peripheral smear does not reveal any hemolysis. 

Acute ITP Chronic ITP
Common in children Common in adults (females > males)
Associated with an antecedent viral infection Not associated with antecedent infection
Spontaneous remission within 6 months in most cases Spontaneous remission is not usually seen

Other options:

Options A and B- HUS and TTP are microangiopathies. They are associated with hemolysis which is not seen in this patient.

Option D- DIC is a coagulopathy usually associated with sepsis and the peripheral smear shows fragmented RBCs.

questions.text: The most common triggering factor of the given condition is ________.
questions.solution:
The given image shows characteristic target lesions of erythema multiforme. The most common triggering factor is herpes simplex virus infection.

Erythema multiforme is best regarded as a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity. It most commonly occurs following an infection or drug intake.

It presents clinically with a spectrum of macular, papular, or urticarial lesions, as well as the classic acral iris or ‘target lesions’.

Target lesions are less than 3 cm in diameter, rounded, and have three zones:

  1. Central area of dusky erythema or purpura
  2. Middle paler zone of edema
  3. Outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge

Lesions may involve the palms and the trunk. Lesions in the oral and genital mucosal membranes are associated with erosions.

The common triggers are

  • Herpes simplex infection
  • Mycoplasma infection
  • Bacterial infections
  • Fungal infections
  • Vaccinations
  • Malignancy - carcinoma, lymphoma, leukemia
  • Drugs - sulfonamides, rifampicin, penicillins, hydantoin derivatives
  • Miscellaneous - lupus erythematosus (Rowell Syndrome), sarcoidosis, polyarteritis nodosa

The image below shows target lesions.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with coccidioidal meningitis. He was given Fluconazole. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis
Inhibits epoxidation of squalene in fungi

questions.solution:
Fluconazole is the drug of choice for coccidioidal meningitis caused by Coccidioides immitis because of better CSF penetration. Triazoles act by inhibition of ergosterol synthesis.

Itraconazole is also effective in this condition but it is not the drug of choice. Amphotericin B is indicated in patients in whom triazoles have failed. 

The azole group inhibits the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme called 14-α-sterol demethylase and results in an impairment of conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. This results in the depletion of membrane ergosterol.

Azole antifungals are of two types:

  • Imidazoles - clotrimazole, ketoconazole, luliconazole
  • Triazoles - itraconazole, fluconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole and isavuconazole

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: Which of the following stages of Entamoeba histolytica is considered an infective form?
questions.solution:
The mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form of E. histolytica. It is passed in feces and can remain viable under moist conditions for about 10 days.

Humans acquire infection by ingestion of food and water contaminated with mature quadrinucleate cyst in the feces. So, a mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form. The ameboid trophozoite is the only form present in tissues. The cytoplasm may contain red blood cells which is a pathognomonic feature.

It can manifest as acute intestinal amebiasis with symptoms of dysentery, lower abdominal discomfort, and flatulence. Low-grade symptoms such as occasional diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue are present in chronic amebiasis.

The amebic ulcer which is flask-shaped is the typical lesion seen in intestinal amebiasis. The ulcers are multiple and are confined to the colon. Sometimes, in secondary intestinal lesions, the ulcers are numerous in the cecum, followed by the sigmoid-rectal region. A granulomatous lesion called an ameboma may form in the cecal or rectosigmoid areas of the colon which can resemble an adenocarcinoma of the colon.

The most common extraintestinal manifestation is amebic hepatitis or liver abscess. The contents are necrotic and bacteriologically sterile, with active amebae confined to the walls. A characteristic anchovy paste is produced in the abscess and seen on surgical drainage

Other options:

Option A: Trophozoite is the active, feeding, and motile stage of E. histolytica that lives in the intestine. However, trophozoites are not the infective form as they cannot survive outside the host’s body due to their sensitivity to environmental conditions.

Option C: Binucleate cyst is an immature cyst, which contains only two nuclei. It is not fully developed and therefore not infective.

Option D: Metacystic trophozoites are the trophozoites that emerge from the cyst after excystation in the host’s intestine. They are not infective outside the body, as they represent a post-infection stage.

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Protozoans

Parasite Infective form Diagnostic form

Giardia lamblia Quadrinucleate cyst Trophozoites, cyst
Trichomonas vaginalis Trophozoites Trophozoites

Acanthamoeba Trophozoites and cysts Trophozoite in CSF
Leishmania donovani Promastigote amastigotes in macrophage

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought in a semi-conscious state. He is sweating profusely, has muscle weakness, breathlessness with an audible wheeze, and constricted pupils. On further evaluation, he is diagnosed with carbaryl poisoning. Which of the following should not be used for treatment?
questions.solution:
Pralidoxime should not be used for treatment.

Pralidoxime may be hazardous in poisoning with carbaryl, which is a carbamate insecticide. It is not effective in carbamate anti-ChE poisoning as the anionic site required for attachment of oximes is occupied. 

Oximes are usually contraindicated in carbamate poisoning, as they do not reactivate the enzyme. They also have anti-ChE activity of their own that may worsen the condition.  

Option B: Atropine is the mainstay in the management of carbamate poisoning. 

Options C and D: Diazepam may be used for the management of seizures. Activated charcoal can be used to perform gastric lavage in oral carbamate poisoning.

Related Pearl: Certain specific clinical features diagnostic of poisons and poisoning

Pupillary constriction (Miosois) Barbiturates, caffeine, carbamates, carbolic acid (phenol), clonidine, methyl dopa, nicotine, opiates, organophosphates, parasympathomimetics.

Nystagmus Alcohol, barbiturates, carbamazepine, phencyclidine, phenytoin

Cyanosis Any CNS depressant or agent causing methemoglobinemia
Needle tracks, pinpoint pupils, and reduced respiratory rate IV Opioids
Dilated pupils or mid-point pupils, and reduced respiratory rate Benzodiazepines
Dilated pupils, tachycardia

  • Amphetamines, ecstasy, cocaine – may also be hallucinating or agitated
  • Anticholinergic drugs such as benzhexol, benztropine – may also have hyperreflexia and myoclonus
  • Antihistamines – may also be drowsy

Hypothermia

 

 Lithium, tricyclic antidepressants, anticholinergics, antihistamines

Hyperthermia
  • Amphetamines, ecstasy, cocaine (also hypertension, tachycardia, agitation, rhabdomyolysis)
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (also confusion, fluctuating consciousness, rigidity, tremor, autonomic instability, sweating, rhabdomyolysis)
  • Serotonin syndrome (also agitation, clonus, tremor, hyperreflexia, sweating, tachycardia)
  • Salicylates including aspirin (also tachycardia, metabolic acidosis, restlessness, hyperventilation)
Hypertension Amphetamine, ephedrine, cocaine, clonidine, MAO inhibitors, thyroid hormones
