questions.text: You have been allotted a patient with an upper limb fracture in the orthopedics ward. The patient fell on his elbow and has pain on elbow movement. On examining, the 3 bony point relationship is reversed. The examiner gives you the following x-rays and asks you to pick up the one belonging to the patient. Which one will you pick?
questions.solution:
The given patient with a fall on the elbow and reversed 3 bony point relationship is likely to have olecranon fracture (Image D). The x-ray (Image D) corresponds to the displaced transverse olecranon fracture.

The three bony points are the tip of the medial epicondyle, the tip of the lateral epicondyle, and the olecranon. When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line. 

Since supracondylar fracture (x-ray C) occurs above any of these bony landmarks, the 3 bony point relationship is preserved.

Other options:

A - Galeazzi fracture 

B - Monteggia fracture

C- Supracondylar fracture

 

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

questions.text: A patient in the emergency ward stays still while lying supine and hesitates to move. He also has very shallow breathing. This attitude of the patient is most likely due to which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of peritonitis. A patient with peritonitis lies supine without movement and has shallow breathing as any movement exacerbates the pain.

Option A: In renal colic, patients have a restless attitude, often rolling around because of pain.

Option C: In acute pancreatitis, the patient usually bends forward and assumes a knee-chest position because of abdominal pain.

Option D: Patients with meningitis present with neck stiffness.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy, who is a football player, comes to the casualty with complaints of epistaxis while playing football on the ground. There is no history of trauma or fall. He also gives a history of recurrent spontaneous nasal bleeding as well as unilateral nasal obstruction and denasal speech. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is shown below. What is the sign shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus is called the Holman-Miller sign or antral sign.

The given clinical picture along with a CT scan showing the Holman-Miller sign is suggestive of the diagnosis of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. It most commonly arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. 

From here. the tumor grows into the

  • Nasal cavity
  • Nasopharynx
  • Pterygopalatine fossa
  • Pterygomaxillary fossa
  • Infratemporal fossa

Other options:

Aquino sign is the blanching of the tumor mass in glomus tumor, when the ipsilateral carotid artery is compressed manually.

Hanging drop/tear-drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum.

Given below is CT showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus—antral sign or Holman-Miller sign

questions.text: As per the WHO Labour Care Guidelines, documentation on the LCG should begin at _____.
questions.solution:
As per the WHO Labour Care Guidelines, documentation on the LCG should begin at 5 cm of dilation.

WHO modified partograph WHO Labour Care Guide
Documentation of labor progression begins at 4 cm of cervical dilatation Documentation of labour progression begins at 5 cm of cervical dilatation
Fixed 1 cm/hour ‘alert’ and ‘action’ lines Time-based cut-offs for each centimeter of cervical dilatation to guide the obstetrician to take action. For example, at 5 cm of cervical dilatation, if there is no progress >6 hours, action needs to be taken
Monitoring of labour is restricted to the first stage only Monitoring of second stage of labour is included
No section on supportive care interventions Addition of a section on supportive care of the mother
Documentation of strength, duration, and frequency of uterine contractions Documentation of only the duration and frequency of uterine contractions

questions.text: The following image shows the resulting wound cavity from a  bullet.  Which of the following explains the shape of the wound cavity?
questions.solution:
The shape of the wound cavity can be explained by yawing of the bullet. 

Yawing is a common phenomenon seen with bullets (not with spheres). It is the rotation of the bullet around a lateral axis while passing through dense media such as tissues. 

The angle between the trajectory and the long axis of the bullet increases due to destabilising forces until it reaches 90 degrees , i.e., the bullet’s long axis is perpendicular to the trajectory. The yawing motion then continues until 180 degrees and the bullet will remain in this stable position where the base is the leading part.

The path of a projectile in a dense medium therefore shows three distinct sections, depending on the respective cross sectional area: narrow channel, increased cavities, and tail end.

 

Tracking produced by a yawing bullet.

Peculiar phenomena seen with bullets:

Tandem bullet (also called piggyback bullet): This is where two bullets come out with a single shot. Seen with unused or locally made weapons. It may cause confusion with the number of entry and exit wounds.

Tandem cartridge (also called duplex cartridge): It is a single cartridge containing two bullets. 

Ricochet : This is when the bullet hits an intervening object before hitting the desired target. Due to this, it tumbles towards the target and enters it obliquely, rather than head-on.

Souvenir bullet : When bullets are allowed to remain in the body, fibrous tissue is deposited around them. Then, these are called souvenir bullets. It may lead to chronic lead poisoning. They can be visualized on X-ray.

questions.text: What is the location of the Bartholin cyst?
questions.solution:
Bartholin cysts are located in the posterior 1/3 of the vulva.

The Bartholin glands are known as the greater vestibular glands in females. These glands are located in the posterior part of the vestibule and open through a duct into the vaginal orifice at approximately 5 and 7 o’clock positions. They secrete mucus during sexual arousal for lubrication. They are the homologs of the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands.

Bartholin cyst is caused by obstruction of the duct due to infection, trauma, mucus changes, and congenitally narrowed ducts. If the cyst gets infected, it leads to the formation of a Bartholin abscess. Escherichia coli is the most common causative agent, however, other gram-positive and gram-negative organisms can also cause the same.

Clinical features:

  • If the size is big, it might cause abdominal and vaginal discomfort with dyspareunia. 
  • A vulval cleft of 'S' shape is usually noted on inspection.
  • It is fluctuant swelling and transillumination can be positive as the fluid collected is generally clear.

Treatment:

  • Analgesics for pain
  • Antibiotic for combating infections.
  • Specific treatment:
    1. Drainage under anesthesia: Generally conservative method, chances of re-infection and formation of granulation tissue can happen.
    2. Marsupialization Complete excision of sac and cyst along with drainage of the substance. The edges are also clearly approximated. This is the ideal management.  The advantages of marsupialization over other methods include:
      • Simple procedure
      • Can be done even under local anesthesia.
      • Shorter hospital stay (24 hours).
      • The postoperative complication is almost nil.
      • Gland function (moisture) remains intact. 
    3. Incision and drainage with word catheter placement: A deflated word catheter is used to tuck the vagina here and prevent it from damage that can happen during movement of the perineum and thus avert re-infection and granulation tissue formation. Alternatively, a 14 F foley catheter can also be used.
    4. Bartholinectomy: This is a very invasive surgery and carries a greater morbidity profile. This is also associated with loss of lubricant function. 

Notes:

In any woman above the age of forty with recurrent Bartholin cyst, a suspicion of Bartholin gland cancer should arise and the cyst wall should be sent for biopsy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of Virchow’s triad?
questions.solution:
Thrombus formation is not included in Virchow’s triad.

Virchow’s triad refers to three primary influences that predispose to thrombus formation:

  • Endothelial injury
  • Stasis or low turbulence of blood flow
  • Blood hypercoagulability

questions.text: A 27-year-old male patient presents with a well-demarcated, coin-shaped erythematous plaque on his left shin, as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of nummular dermatitis or nummular eczema.

The diagnostic lesion of nummular dermatitis is a well-demarcated coin-shaped erythematous plaque, with vesicles surrounding it. Later, central clearing (resolution) and peripheral extension lead to annular or ring-shaped lesions. Initially, the lesions are red and pruritic, but later, they become more scaly and less exudative. 

Common locations involved are 

  • Trunk
  • Extensor surfaces of extremities: 
    • Men - Pretibial areas
    • Women - Dorsal aspect of the hand

questions.text: A histology slide of the adrenal gland is provided below. Which is the hormone(s) secreted from the zone marked as B?
questions.solution:
In the above image, structure marked B is zona fasciculata. Glucocorticoids are secreted from the zona fasciculata. 

Zona fasiculata secretes:

  • Glucocorticoids
  • Cortisol
  • Corticosterone

Other structures marked are as follows:

A – Zona glomerulosa (just underneath the eosinophilic connective tissue)

C – Zona reticularis (cells arranged in the form of irregular cords giving rise to the reticular pattern)

D – Adrenal Medulla 

Related Pearl: Secretion of Adrenal Hormones by the different Zones of the Adrenal Cortex and Adrenal Medulla

Adrenal Cortex

Adrenal Medulla

Zona glomerulosa(15%)

Mineralocorticoids

Aldosterone

Deoxycorticosterone

Norepinephrine

Epinephrine

Dopamine

Zona fasiculata (50%)

Glucocorticoids

Cortisol

Corticosterone

Zona reticularis(7%)

Androgens:

  • DHEA
  • Androstenedione

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for female with atrophic vaginitis with complains of itching?
questions.solution:
Atrophic vaginitis is treated with topical estrogen vaginal cream.

Use of 1 g of conjugated estrogen cream intravaginally each day for 1 to 2 weeks generally provides relief. Systemic estrogen therapy should be considered to prevent recurrence of this disorder.

questions.text: Single-combination medication used in emergency contraception:
questions.solution:
Single-combination medication used in emergency contraception is levonorgestrel 1.5 mg.

Levonorgestrel:

Each tablet contains 0.75 mg levonorgestrel: one tablet should be taken within 72 h of unprotected intercourse and another 12 h later. Alternatively, two tablets can be taken as a single dose. The failure rate is 1.1%. The tablets can be offered up to 120 h, but the efficacy of the drug decreases with increasing coital-drug interval. Levonorgestrel prevents ovulation and causes desynchronization of the endometrium through its receptors (luteal phase deficiency). The period may come earlier or may be delayed.

Advantages:

  • It has no estrogen and its associated side effects
  • It can be offered to women with hypertension, cardiovascular dysfunction, and/or diabetes.
  • It can be offered to a lactating woman
  • It can be given as late as 120 h after the unprotected intercourse
  • It can be given as a single dose

Contraindicated in liver disease, contains lactate, so allergy to galactose. The drug is also contraindicated in a woman with history of thrombophlebitis and migraine.

This is a high yield MCQ. Various contraception methods and the appropriate beneficiaries of these methods are being tested regularly by AIIMS and NEET exams. Do not forget to revise them before each exam!

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presents to the OPD with fever, shortness of breath, chest pain, and productive cough. On examination, there is bronchial breathing on the right side and a dull note on percussion. A chest x-ray is done. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray are suggestive of lobar pneumonia caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae. 

Klebsiella pneumonia is associated mostly with alcoholics and shows upper lobe involvement. The patients present with red-currant jelly sputum.

Chest X-ray shows:

  • Cavitation
  • Pneumatocele (also seen in S. aureus)
  • Bulging fissure sign: Classically seen in Klebsiella pneumonia. It represents expansive lobar consolidation causing fissural bulging; or displacement of copious amounts of inflammatory exudates within the affected parenchyma. It is seen in any space-occupying process in the lung such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and lung tumors.

questions.text: The most common salivary gland to develop stones is/are ______.
questions.solution:
80% of salivary gland stones occur in the submandibular gland and are mostly radiopaque.

Sialolithiasis:

  • It is less common in the parotid gland (20%) than in the submandibular gland (80%), leading to sialadenitis.
  • Parotid duct stones are usually radiolucent and rarely visible on plain radiography.
  • They are frequently located at the confluence of the collecting ducts or located in the distal aspect of the parotid duct adjacent to the parotid papilla.
  • Parotid gland sialography is usually required to identify the stone.
  • A stone located in the collecting duct or within the gland may be managed by either endoscopic retrieval, or lithotripsy; in rare cases, surgical removal via a parotidectomy approach may be required.
  • In the case of sialadenitis, treatment is either marsupialization or total excision of the gland.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of pulmonary arterial hypertension?

choices.text: Mean pulmonary arterial pressure >20 mm Hg
Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure ≤ 25 mm Hg

questions.solution:
Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) ≤ 15 mm Hg is a feature of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).

The table below shows the hemodynamic classification of pulmonary hypertension. PAH belongs to WHO group 1.

Parameters

Pre-capillary

WHO groups 1,3,4,5

Post-capillary

WHO group 2

Combined pre and post-capillary 

WHO groups 2,5
mPAP (mmHg) >20 (Option A) >20 >20
PCWP (mmHg) ≤15 (Option C) >15 >15
PVR (wood units) ≥3 (Option D) <3 ≥3

mPAP- Mean pulmonary artery pressure

PCWP-Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure

PVR- Pulmonary vascular resistance

Related Pearl: Classification of Pulmonary Hypertension & its Causes

Based on underlying mechanisms, the World Health Organization has classified pulmonary hypertension into five groups.

Classification

Causes

Group 1

Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH)

Idiopathic PAH

Hereditary PAH - BMPR2 gene (most common mutation)

Drug or toxin-induced PAH

PAH associated with

  • Connective tissue disorder (limited systemic sclerosis)
  • Portal hypertension
  • HIV
  • Schistosomiasis
  • Congenital heart diseases

Group 2

Left ventricular systolic or diastolic dysfunction

Group 3

Pulmonary hypertension associated with lung disease

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

Interstitial lung disease

Sleep-disordered breathing

Alveolar hypoventilation disorders

Group 4

Chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension

Chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension

Congenital pulmonary artery stenosis

Pulmonary arteritis

Group 5

Hematological disorders (chronic hemolytic anemias)

questions.text: A 55-year-old man on routine examination is found to have a hemoglobin of 8.4 g/dL, WBC count of 1,65,000/cu.mm, and platelet count of 6,10,000/cu.mm. The peripheral smear is suggestive of chronic myeloid leukemia. Which of the following forms of WBCs will be predominantly elevated in the peripheral smear of this patient?
questions.solution:
Segmented neutrophils will be predominantly elevated in the peripheral smear of the patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

The clinical hallmark of CML is the uncontrolled production of mature and maturing granulocytes. The myeloblasts, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and the band stage are the immature cells seen in order during the development of granulocytes. Therefore, all of these cells can be seen in the peripheral smear. They can be identified as

  • myeloblast- large cells with a round or oval nucleus. The cytoplasm is dark and does not have granules.
  • myelocyte- the nucleus is oval and is eccentrically placed.
  • metamyelocyte- the nucleus is like a kidney bean in shape.
  • band forms- the nucleus is in the shape of C or U.
  • segmented neutrophils (predominantly elevated)- the nucleus will have 2-5 lobes.

 On peripheral smear there is leukocytosis with leukocyte count, often exceeding 100,000 cells/mm3 (neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils), blasts are usually less than 10% of the circulating cells, the platelet count is usually increased.

The image below shows peripheral smear findings of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) with neutrophils, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band cells.

questions.text: The thoracic duct begins in the abdomen at the T12 vertebral level as the continuation of cisterna chyli. Which of the following structures is not drained by it?
questions.solution:
Right upper part of the body is not drained by the thoracic duct. The rest of the body drains into the thoracic duct.

The thoracic duct begins in the abdomen at the T-12 vertebral level as the continuation of cisterna chyli.

  • It is usually beaded due to its numerous valves.
  • It drains the body below the diaphragm (lower limbs, pelvis, abdomen) and the left half of the body above the diaphragm (thorax, upper limb, head, and neck).
  • The thoracic duct passes through the aortic hiatus in the diaphragm and ascends through the posterior mediastinum between the aorta and the azygous vein.
  • At the T-5 level, it deviates to the left side and ascends to pass the thoracic inlet.

Tributaries of the thoracic duct:

  • Bilateral (right and left) descending thoracic lymph trunks which convey lymph from lower intercostal spaces (6–11).
  • Left upper intercostal lymph trunks, which convey lymph from the upper intercostal spaces (1-5).
  • Mediastinal lymph trunks
  • Left subclavian lymph trunk
  • Left jugular lymph trunk
  • Left bronchomediastinal lymph trunk

Related Pearl: Diaphragmatic openings

Major openings through the diaphragm

Level of opening

T8

T10

T12

Located in

In the central tendon

In the muscular part

In crus of the diaphragm

Structures passing through

 

Inferior Vena cava

Right phrenic nerve 

Oesophagus

Vagus nerve- right and left

Aorta

Thoracic duct

Azygous vein

Hemiazygous vein

 

Minor openings through the diaphragm

  • Space of Larry (Costo-Xiphoid gap) - Superior epigastric artery
  • Medial arcuate ligament - Sympathetic chain
  • Lateral arcuate ligament - Subcostal nerves and vessels

 

Note:

Splanchnic nerves pass through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.

The azygous vein may sometimes pass through the right crus of the diaphragm.

The hemizygous vein may sometimes pass through the left crus of the diaphragm.

questions.text: As an intern, you are currently posted in the pediatric endocrinology OPD, where you see multiple cases of girls having precocious puberty. The condition is defined by the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of_________ in girls.
questions.solution:
Precocious puberty is defined as the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years in girls and 9 years in boys.

Depending on the primary source of hormonal production, precocious puberty can be classified in the following manner:

Central Precocious Puberty

(Gonadotropin-dependent puberty)

Peripheral Precocious Puberty

(Gonadotropin independent)

Due to the excess secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) from the pituitary

Due to excess secretion of testosterone or estrogen from the gonads/adrenals

Always isosexual (appearance of phenotypically appropriate secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years in girls and 9 years in boys)

Can be isosexual or heterosexual (appearance of secondary sex characters of the opposite sex)

Girls 

  • Idiopathic (most common)

Boys

  • CNS pathology (most common)

Girls 

  • Estrogenic ovarian cysts (isosexual)
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) (testosterone increases; heterosexual)

Boys

  • CAH (isosexual; most common)

Note:

Central precocious puberty (more common) >> Peripheral precocious puberty

questions.text: Which of the following disability indicators is the best to know the overall burden of disease?
questions.solution:
DALY is the best measure of overall burden of a disease in a defined population and effectiveness of interventions.

Disability Adjusted Life Years: Years of lost life prematurely (YLL) + Years lost of disability (YLD)

  • It can measure both mortality and disability together. 
  • Alzheimer's Disease has a lower DALY as it is a disease that mostly develops during old age due to which the YLL will be lower than other diseases that develop in a younger age group.
  • Generally, Road Traffic Accidents would be considered to have a high DALY as it is more prevalent in the younger age group and thus the YLL will be higher.

Related Pearl: QALY vs. DALY

QALY and DALY are disability indicators used as measures of health in a population.

QALY

Quality Adjusted Life Years

DALY

Disability Adjusted Life Years

 

Measures quality of life in health gain

 

Measures health loss in quality of life

 

Indicator of cost effectiveness of intervention

 

Indicator of overall burden of disease in a population

 

Expressed as 1 or 0 where,

1 = Perfect health

0 = Death

 

 

Expressed as 0 or 1 where,

0 = Perfect health

1 = Death

questions.text: The major prostanoid synthesized in kidney is ________
questions.solution:
PGE2 is the major prostanoid synthesized in the kidney.

It is secreted by:

  • RMICs (Renal Medullary Interstitial Cells)
  • Macula densa
  • Cells in the collecting ducts.

Prostacyclin (PGI2) and other prostaglandins are secreted by the arterioles and glomeruli.

questions.text: A child with Kawasaki disease is admitted to the ward for treatment. Which of the following features would you not expect to see in her?
questions.solution:
Purulent conjunctivitis is not a feature of Kawasaki disease. Bilateral nonexudative conjunctival injection with limbal sparing is characteristically seen in Kawasaki disease.

Kawasaki disease is also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome and is commonly seen in children between 3 months to 5 years of age.

Note: Perineal desquamation is common in the acute phase, while periungual desquamation begins 2-3 weeks after the onset of illness and may even progress to involve the entire hand and foot.

Related Pearl: Kawasaki disease criteria

Diagnostic criteria of Kawasaki disease: 

Fever of five days or more duration plus four out of the following five criteria:

  1. Oropharyngeal changes (90% of cases)
  2. Changes in peripheral extremities (90% of cases)
  3. Cervical lymphadenopathy (~75% of cases)
  4. Polymorphous rash (95% of cases)
  5. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival injection (90% of cases)

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis of a patient reveals a pH of 7.55, pCO2- 54 mmHg, and HCO3- 40 mEq/L. What is the underlying disorder?

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis
Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
Respiratory alkalosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis

questions.solution:
The underlying disorder in this patient is metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 7.55 indicates alkalosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 40 mEq/L, which in the presence of a high pH indicates metabolic alkalosis.

Step 3: pCO2 is 54 mmHg indicating respiratory acidosis. The increase in pCO2 along with the increase in pH suggests that this is a compensatory response.

Step 4: Assessing the compensatory response:

On average, the pCO2 rises 0.75 mmHg for every 1.0 mEq/L increment in the plasma HCO3-

In the above scenario, the plasma HCO3- concentration is increased to 40 mEq/L (The average normal value is considered as 24 mEq/L)

Thus, the HCO3- elevation is 40 – 24 = 16 mEq/L

Therefore, pCO2 elevation should be 0.75 × 16 =  12 mmHg

Now, considering that the average value of normal pCO2 is 40 mmHg, the estimated pCO2 measured should be 40 + 12= 52 mmHg.

As pCO2 is higher than the expected estimate, it is a case of metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

questions.text: Which of the following patients is not at an increased risk for developing deep vein thrombosis?

choices.text: Woman on high-dose estrogen therapy for menopausal symptoms
Teenager who has sustained major trauma in an accident

questions.solution:
Nephritic syndrome is not associated with an increased risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Nephrotic syndrome is associated with an increased risk of developing DVT.

DVT is the presence or formation of a thrombus is present in the deep venous system, usually in the deep veins of the lower limbs.

Related Pearl: Risk factors for venous thromboembolism

Patient factors:

  • Age
  • Obesity
  • Varicose veins
  • Immobility
  • Pregnancy
  • Puerperium
  • High-dose estrogen therapy
  • Previous deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.

Thrombophilia

  • Congenital
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III, protein C or protein S
    • Antiphospholipid antibody or lupus anticoagulant
    • Factor V leiden gene defect or activated protein C resistance
    • Dysfibrinogenaemias
  • Acquired
    • Antiphospholipid antibody or lupus anticoagulant

Disease or surgical procedure

  • Trauma or surgery, especially of pelvis, hip, and lower limb
  • Malignancy, especially pelvic, and abdominal metastatic
  • Heart failure
  • Recent myocardial infarction
  • Paralysis of lower limb(s) infection
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Polycythaemia
  • Paraproteinaemia
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
  • Behçet’s disease
  • Homocysteinemia

questions.text: A patient presents with a seizure. On evaluation, urine osmolality is 1000 mOsm/Kg and serum osmolality is 270 mOsm/Kg. Which electrolyte abnormality can be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has high urine osmolality of 1000 mOsm/kg (normal 500-800 mOsm/kg) and low plasma osmolality of 270 mOsm/kg (normal 285-295 mOsm/kg). This is seen in the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone synthesis (SIADH) and hyponatremia is the most common electrolyte abnormality seen.

Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone ADH release (SIADH) is a condition where there is an unsuppressed release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) from the pituitary gland or nonpituitary sources or its continued action on vasopressin receptors.

ADH promotes the reabsorption of water from the collecting duct. Excessive secretion of ADH in SIADH results in enhanced water reabsorption. Therefore, only water is reabsorbed and not the solutes resulting in concentrated urine. This is depicted as high urine osmolality. The excess of water reabsorbed from the tubules expand and dilute the extracellular fluid leading to dilutional hyponatremia. This is depicted as low plasma osmolality. 

Since there is an increase in body water with little or no change in body sodium in SIADH, this is known as euvolemic hyponatremia.

Patients may be asymptomatic or present with headache, confusion, nausea, vomiting, anorexia, seizures, and coma.

Related Pearl: Causes of SIADH

Neoplasms

Carcinomas

  • Lung
  • Duodenum
  • Pancreas
  • Ovary
  • Bladder, ureter

Other neoplasms

  • Thymoma
  • Mesothelioma
  • Bronchial adenoma
  • Carcinoid
  • Gangliocytoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma

Head trauma (closed and penetrating)

Infections

  • Pneumonia
  • Abscess
  • Cavitation (aspergillosis)
  • Tuberculosis
  • Meningitis, Encephalitis
  • AIDS

Vascular

  • Cerebrovascular occlusions, haemorrhage
  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Neurologic

  • Guillain-Barre syndrome
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Delirium tremens
  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Psychosis
  • Peripheral neuropathy

Congenital malformations

Metabolic

  • Acute intermittent porphyria

Respiratory

  • Asthma
  • Pneumothorax
  • Positive-pressure respiration

Drugs

  • Vasopressin or desmopressin
  • Serotonin reuptake inhibitors
  • Oxytocin (high dose)
  • Vincristine
  • Carbamazepine
  • Nicotine

Under the MCH program, the government of India advocates giving 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid to pregnant women.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman in the first trimester of pregnancy presents to your clinic with hair loss. She gives a history of typhoid fever 3 months ago. What is the pattern of hair loss seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The pattern of hair loss in this clinical scenario is telogen effluvium. It is an acute-onset scalp hair loss that occurs 2–3 months after a triggering event such as high fever, surgical trauma, sudden starvation, or hemorrhage.

It refers to an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to premature termination of the anagen (proliferative) phase of the hair cycle following a period of stress.

Chronic diffuse telogen hair loss refers to telogen hair shedding persisting for >6 months.

Causes of chronic diffuse telogen hair loss are

  • Thyroid disorders (Both hyper- and hypo­thyroidism)
  • Severe iron-deficiency anemia, acroder­matitis enteropathica, and malnutrition.

 

 

Other Options:

Option A: Anagen effluvium is a type of alopecia, which is the sudden loss of anagen (actively growing) hair, usually occuring post chemotherapy.


 Option B: Androgenetic alopecia is a permanent hair loss from the scalp, causing baldness, and has a common genetic cause. Hair loss typically occurs on the top and front of the head. It occurs progressively, unlike what is seen here. 

Option D: Telogen gravidarum refers to telogen hair loss seen 2–3 months after childbirth. The circulating placental estrogen during pregnancy prolongs the anagen phase. After delivery, the estrogen withdrawal pushes all the hair simultaneously into the catagen and then the telogen phase.

questions.text: A patient with a leg injury was treated with a skin graft as shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this type of skin graft?

choices.text: Degree of contraction is dependant on amount of dermis in graft
Healing with abnormal pigmentation is common.
The reliability of graft take is high.
Meshing grafts improve their ultimate cosmetic appearance

questions.solution:
The given image shows a meshed, split-thickness skin graft. Split grafts are meshed to expand the surface area that can be covered, but it does not improve the cosmetic appearance.

Less dermis in the split-thickness skin graft translates into less primary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks in surface area after harvesting and before grafting) and more secondary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks during healing).

Less dermis also translates into a better chance of graft survival. Thin-split grafts have a low primary contraction, high secondary contraction, and high reliability of graft take. However, they tend to heal with abnormal pigmentation and poor durability.

Type of graft Split-thickness graft Full-thickness graft
Composition Epidermis + part of the dermis Epidermis + full dermis
Cosmetic appearance Relatively poor Good (texture and pigmentation are better matched)
Graft take/survival High chance of survival Poor (long healing time and vascularization)
Contraction Lesser primary contraction and more secondary contraction More primary contraction and lesser secondary contraction
Use Can cover large areas of defects For areas where least contraction (finger) or best cosmesis (face) is desired

The image given below shows the procedure of obtaining a split-thickness skin graft using a handheld Humby knife.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs increases uric acid in urine?
questions.solution:
Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that promotes the excretion of uric acid.

Probenecid is used to decrease the body pool of urate in patients with chronic gout. The drug acts by inhibiting the organic anion transporter, particularly URAT-1 in the renal tubules that are involved in uric acid reabsorption. It is used as an adjuvant to allopurinol in chronic gout and hyperuricemia.

Probenecid increases urinary urate levels. Plenty of fluids are given to avoid urate calculi formation. Probenecid should not be used in gouty patients with nephrolithiasis or with overproduction of uric acid.

Probenecid inhibits penicillin's urinary excretion, prolonging penicillin action by enhancing and sustaining their blood levels. It inhibits the urinary excretion of other drugs such as cephalosporins, sulfonamides, methotrexate, and indomethacin. Aspirin blocks the uricosuric action of the drug.

Other options: 

Option A: Colchicine acts by preventing the polymerization of microtubules by tubulin, this reduces neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue and also decreases the secretion of chemotactic factors by activated neutrophils. Overall it reduces the inflammatory response.

Option B: Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that prevents the conversion of xanthine to uric acid approved for the treatment of hyperuricemia in patients with gout.

Option D: Allopurinol acts by inhibiting the xanthine oxidase enzyme that prevents the conversion of xanthine to uric acid.

questions.text: A nulliparous lady, with a BMI of 23, presents with hirsutism. Ultrasonography was done, and the obtained image is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound image shows an enlarged ovary with multiple follicles in the periphery. The patient's clinical history and given USG image are indicative of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. The Rotterdam criteria are used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS:

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Menstrual abnormalities (oligomenorrhea/amenorrhea), anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries on ultrasonography.

Sonographic criteria for polycystic ovaries include ≥ 12 small cysts or an increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both. 

Management:

  • Weight reduction alone is beneficial in mild hirsutism and lifestyle changes (like smoking cessation) are advised in the management of PCOS.
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 μg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. It also reduces acne and further hirsutism.
  • Anti-androgens are useful in treating hirsutism. OCP with cyproterone acetate is prescribed for PCOS patients with hirsutism. 
  • Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin. Acarbose can be used if metformin is contraindicated
  • Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical options include laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. This is done either by laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores the endocrine levels and improves fertility.

Surgery is indicated only in the case of

  • Failure of medical therapy
  • Hyperstimulation
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 - 70 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: Which of the following is a non-electrical cold-chain equipment?
questions.solution:
Cold boxes, vaccine carriers, and ice packs are some of the non-electrical components of the cold-chain system.

  • Cold boxes are insulated containers used for transportation and temporary storage of vaccines and ice packs.
  • Vaccine carriers are usually not used for storage of vaccines but for their transportation.
  • Ice packs generally have two holes in them for placing vaccines. They are filled with water.

Storage : 

  • Walk in cooler (WIC)
  • Walk in freezer (WIF)
  • Ice lined refrigerator (ILR)
  • Deep freezer 
  • Domestic refrigerator

Transportation : 

  • Refrigerator vaccine van
  • Insulated vaccine van
  • Cold box 
  • Vaccine carrier

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. On examination, he had multiple injuries over his body and was found to be in class II hemorrhagic shock. The percentage of blood loss would be between:
questions.solution:
The percentage of blood loss in class II hemorrhagic shock is 15–30%, which amounts to a loss of 750–1500 mL of blood.

The class II hemorrhagic shock is considered as a mild shock with heart rate more than 100. It is associated with orthostatic hypotension, and the patient is usually anxious at this stage.

questions.text: Out of 100 women who took oral contraceptive pills for contraception, 10 women got pregnant within 24 months. What is the Pearl index?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the pearl index is 5 per HWY.

Here, the total number of accidental pregnancies is 10. There are 100 couples who are exposed to the method.

So, the total months of exposure are 24 months x 100 = 2400.

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure

Hence, pearl index = 10 x 1200/2400 = 5 per HWY. 

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: What level of prevention is pap smear test for detection of carcinoma cervix?
questions.solution:
Pap smear is a screening test for carcinoma cervix and is a type of secondary prevention.

Early diagnosis (including screening) and treatment is the component of secondary prevention. Some of the examples of secondary prevention are as follows:

  • Papanicolaou (Pap) smear for early detection of cervical cancer
  • Mammography, for early detection of breast cancer
  • Colonoscopies, for early detection of colon cancer
  • Blood Pressure Screening

Secondary prevention measures focus on the sub-clinical stage and the early clinical stage, such as dysplasia in this case. These measures enable early detection and prompt effective intervention to correct departures from a state of health.

questions.text: A patient presented with reduced levels of high-density lipoprotein, and ABCA1 mutation. On examination, tonsils appeared as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this case with reduced levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL), ABCA1 mutation, and orange tonsils on examination is Tangier's disease. It is caused by a defect in ABCA1 receptors.

ABCA1 plays a role in the efflux of cholesterol from peripheral cells of HDL. LCAT (lecithin cholesterol acyltransferase) converts cholesterol to cholesterol esters, which accumulate in the core of HDL. Thus, defective ABCA1 will lead to low levels of HDL in the blood. 

Other options:

Option B: Abetalipoproteinemia is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a defect in the MTP gene. Here, loading apolipoprotein B with lipids is defective. Hence, few very low density-lipoproteins (VLDLs) or chylomicrons are formed, leading to the accumulation of triacylglycerols in the liver and intestine.

Option C: Hyperlipoproteinemia is a disorder that causes the body to metabolize lipids incorrectly. This results in hyperlipidemia and can lead to the development of multiple small xanthomas in the skin.

Option D: Acid lipase deficiency can lead to Wolman's disease which is a lysosomal storage disease. The pathognomic feature of this condition is adrenal calcification. So patients generally present with adrenal insufficiency and are neonates.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, TG and cholesterol Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: A patient was incidentally found to have essential fructosuria. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Essential fructosuria is due to the deficiency of the enzyme hepatic fructokinase, inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Fructokinase is the first enzyme to act on fructose metabolism.

  • This defective degradation does not cause any clinical symptoms.
  • Fructose is either excreted unchanged in the urine or metabolized to fructose-6-phosphate by alternate pathways in the body, most commonly by hexokinase in adipose tissue and muscle.
  • No treatment is indicated for essential fructosuria.

questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty ward with right lower abdominal pain, nausea, and fever. On examination, there is increased pain in the right lower quadrant when palpating the left lower quadrant. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
The given triad of clinical features, namely fever, nausea, and right lower abdominal pain, is the Murphy triad. It is suggestive of acute appendicitis. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa can cause pain in the right iliac fossa. This sign is called the Rovsing sign.

This pain is due to the backflow of gases from the colon into the inflamed right intestine when the left lower abdomen is palpated.

Other options:

Option B: Aaron sign-Pain or pressure in epigastrium or anterior chest with persistent firm pressure applied to McBurney’s point. It is seen in acute appendicitis.

Option C: Dunphy sign-pain on coughing.It is seen in acute appendicitis.

Option D: McBurney sign-it refers to deep tenderness at McBurney's point. It is seen in acute appendicitis.

questions.text: The following set of instruments are used for which procedure?
questions.solution:
The given set of instruments are commonly used for the collection of pap smears. The given image includes Cusco's bivalved self-retaining speculum, Koplin's jar, smear slides, Ayer's spatula, and endocervical brush. 

Pap/ Papanicolaou test is a screening test only. The presence of abnormal cells/ a positive test requires further evaluation by colposcopy, cervical biopsy, or fractional curettage.

Prerequisites:

  • Should be done prior to vaginal examination.
  • Lubricants should not be used.
  • The patient should not be menstruating during the pap test.
  • The ideal time is around ovulation.
  • The patient should not have had intercourse in the 24hrs prior to the test.

Screening guidelines:

  • Time for initiation: 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse.
  • Women aged 21-29 years: Every 3 years(earlier it was done annually)
  • Women who are aged 30-65 years: Pap test + HPV testing every 5 years.
  • Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If suspicious PAP, screening till 75 years.
  • HIV+ women: annual checkup until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life.
  • HPV DNA testing in combination with PAP improves the sensitivity of screening.

Ayres spatula and endocervical brush are the instruments used for the pap test.

 

 

Hysteroscopy is the process of inspection of the uterine cavity. 

Indications:

Diagnostic:

  • Endocervical study in suspected endocervical malignancy, preinvasive cancer, and biopsy
  • Uterus—malformations, endometrial TB, Asherman syndrome, misplaced IUCD, menorrhagia, intermenstrual, bleeding submucous fibroid, polyp
  • Falloscopy

Therapeutic:

  • Endometrial polypectomy
  • Submucous fibroid
  • Septate uterus
  • Asherman syndrome
  • Removal of IUCD
  • Tubal sterilization
  • Balloonoplasty
  • IVF Intrafallopian insemination

The image shows the procedure of hysteroscopy and the common instruments used for the same.

 

Biopsy:

To take biopsy we commonly use Gellhorn's punch biopsy forceps as shown in the image below. It is used to take biopsies from the cervix.

 

Dilatation and curettage:

Instruments used in D&C:

  • Sim’s speculum: It retracts the posterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix
  • Anterior vaginal wall retractor: Retracts the anterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix.
  • Vulsellum or Allis forceps: To hold the anterior lip of the cervix
  • Uterine sound: Simpson's uterine sound is a 30 cm long angulated instrument with a handle at one end and a rounded blunt tip at the other.
    It is used to measure the length of the uterus. It can be identified by the markings used for measurement
  • Cervical dilators: 
    • Hegar's dilator is a double-ended dilator used to dilate the cervix.
    • Hawkins’ single-ended dilator 
    • Fenton’s dilator
  • Curette:
    • Sim's curette is a single-ended curette
    • Blake's curette is a double-ended curette

 

The image above shows the trolley with various instruments:

  1. Sim's uterine curette
  2. Hegars dilator
  3. Sim's uterine sound
  4. Karman's cannula - It is used for menstrual regulation. It can be identified by the whistle-like tip.
  5. Leech Wilkinson's cannula
  6. Rubin's cannula 

Leech Wilkinson's cannula and Rubin's cannula are used in hysterosalpingography.

questions.text: Inferior thyroid artery supplies which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
All the given 3 structures are supplied by the inferior thyroid artery.

Inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk, which in turn, is a branch of the first part of the subclavian artery.

Branches:

  • Pharyngeal branches (these supply the lower part of the pharynx):
    • Tracheal branches 
    • Esophageal branches 
    • Inferior and ascending glandular branches supply the posterior and inferior regions of the thyroid gland, and anastomose with the contralateral inferior and ipsilateral superior thyroid arteries.
    • The ascending branch also supplies the parathyroid glands.
  • Ascending cervical artery
  • Inferior laryngeal
  • Muscular branches

Note: Thymic branches originating from the internal thoracic, inferior thyroid artery, and sometimes superior thyroid arteries supply the thymus and the surrounding mediastinal connective tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following post-mortem changes is a result of hydrolysis of lipids under warm and humid weather?
questions.solution:
Hydrolysis of lipids under warm and humid weather would result in adipocere formation, which is seen in image 4. 

Postmortem changes are classified on the basis of time:

  • Immediate signs of death (at the time of somatic or clinical death):
    1. Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
    2. Cessation of respiration
    3. Cessation of circulation
  • Early signs of death. It is seen in cellular death:
    1. Pallor and loss of elasticity of the skin
    2. Eye changes
    3. Primary flaccidity of muscles
    4. Algor mortis/Postmortem cooling
    5. Postmortem lividity/Suggillation
    6. Rigor mortis
  • Late signs of death:
    1. Putrefaction
    2. Adipocere
    3. Mummification

Adipocere formation (Image 4) is a late sign of death. The transformation is brought about by the gradual hydrolysis and hydrogenation of pre-existing fats, including olein, into higher fatty acids. These higher fatty acids then join with calcium and ammonium ions to produce insoluble soaps, which since they are acidic, prevent putrefactive bacteria. The usual time for adipocere formation is between 3 to 6 months. Still, in countries like India, it is accelerated by the warm and humid weather, resulting in the beginning of adipocere formation as early as 4 to 5 days after death. 

Image 1. Marbling: It is seen when blood in the vessels is hemolyzed to sulfate-hemoglobin, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance. The marbling of the skin begins at about 24 hours and becomes prominent  36–48 hours after death. It is a visible postmortem change that is characterized by linear branching patterns on skin that correspond to the course of superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

Image 2. Cadaveric lividity: Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to the collection of blood in most superficial layers of the dermis in the dependent parts of the body. Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6 – 12 hours after death and persists until putrefaction sets in.

Image 3. Mummification: It occurs in the absence of moisture in the air and continuous action of dry or warmed air. It is a process of dehydration or drying and shriveling of the cadaver that occurs from the evaporation of water. The natural appearances of the body and general facial features are preserved.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is non-compliant with medication presents to you with sudden-onset breathlessness. A chest x-ray was done, which is shown below. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette along with the given x-ray points to a diagnosis of acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema. It can be managed by the administration of intravenous nitroglycerin.

Acute severe hypertension, acute myocardial infarction, or exacerbation of chronic heart failure are some of the common causes of cardiogenic pulmonary edema. It can be precipitated by the discontinuation of medications (non-compliant patient), excessive salt intake, or tachyarrhythmias. 

It presents with severe dyspnea, pink frothy sputum production, diaphoresis, and cyanosis. Auscultation reveals rales and rhonchi in all lung fields. Chest x-ray shows increased interstitial markings, vascular redistribution, and alveolar edema in a butterfly pattern. Cardiomegaly might be seen in cases of chronic heart failure.

Management of pulmonary edema includes the use of diuretics, nitrates, and morphine to decrease the preload. Nitroglycerin and isosorbide dinitrate have a rapid onset of action and can be given sublingually. If there is a persistence of pulmonary edema and no hypotension, it can be administered intravenously.

Oxygen therapy to maintain a saturation of >92% is recommended. Positive-pressure ventilation through a face mask or endotracheal intubation is required if saturation is not maintained even with supplemental oxygen. A sitting position with legs hanging by the side of the bed can be used to reduce venous return in patients without hypotension.

Non-cardiac causes of pulmonary edema are high altitude, sepsis, and disseminated intravascular coagulation. 

Heart failure is a manifestation of most chronic cardiac conditions such as hypertension, valvular heart disease, and coronary artery disease. Symptoms such as shortness of breath, orthopnea, and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea point to left heart failure due to pulmonary congestion. In contrast, symptoms such as pedal edema, weight gain, early satiety, and hepatic congestion are characteristic of right heart failure.

Other options: 

Options A and C -  Salbutamol is a short-acting β2-agonist that is used to treat acute severe asthma. Salbutamol nebulization is used to treat hyperkalemia. Side effects include tachycardia, tremors, hypokalemia, and raised glucose levels. 

Option D - Oxygen supplementation is recommended for pulmonary edema but antibiotics have no role in cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in heart failure

Related Pearl: Summary of Pathogenesis of Major Findings in Congestive Heart Failure

Summary of Pathogenesis of Major Findings in Congestive Heart Failure

Abnormality

Cause

Weakness, exercise intolerance, fatigue

Left ventricle output inadequate to perfuse muscles; especially, failure of output to rise with exercise

Ankle, sacral edema

Increased peripheral venous pressure →increased fluid transudation.

Hepatomegaly

Increased peripheral venous pressure →increased resistance to portal flow.

Pulmonary congestion

Increased pulmonary venous pressure →pulmonary venous distention and transudation of fluid into air spaces

Dyspnea on exertion

Failure of left ventricular output to rise during exercise → increased pulmonary venous pressure

Paroxysmal dyspnea, pulmonary edema

Probably a sudden failure of left heart output to keep up with the right heart output →acute rise in pulmonary venous and capillary pressure →transudation of fluid into air spaces.

Orthopnea

Normal pooling of blood in lungs in supine position added to the already congested pulmonary vascular system; increased venous return not put out by the left ventricle. (Relieved by sitting up, raising the head of the bed, lying on extra pillows.)

Cardiac dilation

Greater ventricular end-diastolic volume.

questions.text: What is the cause of lactational amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
The cause of lactational amenorrhea is increased prolactin secretion as a result of the baby sucking at the mother's breast.

Lactational amenorrhea:

  • It is a type of secondary amenorrhea due to the effect of prolactin secretion.
  • During lactation, there are pulsatile bursts of prolactin secretion in response to suckling.
  • Prolactin suppresses GnRH, LH, and FSH, causing lactational amenorrhea.
  • Regular lactation with one feed at night delays ovulation and pregnancy for up to 6 months, provided the woman remains amenorrhic.
  • After 6 months, lactation has no bearing on ovulation and pregnancy can occur despite amenorrhea; therefore, other forms of contraception may be needed.

questions.text: All the following muscles of the tongue are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve, except _________.
questions.solution:
Palatoglossus is not supplied by the hypoglossal nerve.

All intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue are derived from occipital myotomes (hence innervated by the hypoglossal nerve), except palatoglossus, which is derived from the pharyngeal arch and is supplied by the vago-accessory nerve.

Note:

  • All the muscles of the tongue, except palatoglossus (cranial accessory nerve through pharyngeal plexus) are supplied by hypoglossal nerve.
  • All the muscles of pharynx, except stylopharyngeus (glossopharyngeal nerve) are supplied by pharyngeal plexus.
  • All muscles of soft palate, except tensor veli palatini (nerve to medial pterygoid from mandibular nerve) are supplied by pharyngeal plexus.
  • All muscles of the larynx, except the cricothyroid (external laryngeal nerve) are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: An unbooked primigravida, with no antenatal records, delivers a 2.5-kg male baby by normal delivery. While ascertaining the maturity of the child, which of the following would be against a diagnosis of prematurity?
questions.solution:
Thick cartilage with a stiff ear in a newborn is a sign of maturity (not prematurity).

In a premature neonate, the pinna is flat without any recoil on pressing and releasing. As the baby matures, it becomes more curved and starts to recoil due to the elasticity of cartilage. A fully mature pinna will have thick cartilage and a stiff ear.

No creases on the sole, insignificant breast nodule and an empty scrotum are all physical signs of prematurity in a newborn. As it matures the sole creases become well-developed, breast nodules become prominent and the testis fills up the scrotum with the development of rugosities.

Abundant lanugo hair is not discriminatory evidence of prematurity. This is because neonates born to diabetic mothers at term, or even post-term, have abundant lanugo hair, especially over the pinna and upper back.

questions.text: A patient died of a heart attack a few hours back. On autopsy, it was determined that he is at the stage of cellular death. Which of the following signs can be noted?
questions.solution:
Suggilation/postmortem hypostasis is an early sign of death. Putrefaction, adipocere formation, mummification are late signs of death. 

Immediate signs of death (somatic death):

  • Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
  • Cessation of respiration
  • Cessation of circulation

Early signs of death (cellular death):

  • Pallor and loss of elasticity of skin
  • Eye changes
  • Primary flaccidity of muscles
  • Cooling of the body
  • Postmortem lividity/suggilation
  • Rigor mortis

Late signs of death:

  • Putrefaction
  • Adipocere
  • Mummification

Cadaveric lividity: Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to the collection of blood in most superficial layers of the dermis in the dependent parts of the body. Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6 – 12 hours after death and persists until putrefaction sets in.

questions.text:
What is the cause of LH surge?

FSH: Follicle-stimulating Hormone

LH: Luteinizing hormone
questions.solution:
Estradiol causes LH surge. Estradiol concentrations of 200 pg/mL for 50 hours are necessary to initiate this LH surge.

Phases of the menstrual cycle :

Follicular phase (days 0–14)

 

  • A higher FSH level at the beginning of this phase is responsible for the recruitment of the follicle cohort that contains the follicle destined for ovulation. A primordial follicle develops to the Graafian stage, with atresia of neighboring follicles.
  • LH receptors are up-regulated in theca and granulosa cells. During the mid-follicular phase, follicles produce greater amounts of estrogen and inhibin.
  • Estradiol levels increase and cause proliferation of the uterus.
  • FSH are suppressed by the negative feedback effect of estradiol and inhibin on the anterior pituitary.

Ovulation (day 14)

  • A burst of estradiol synthesis at the end of the follicular phase has a positive feedback effect on the secretion of LH (LH surge). There is a small preovulatory rise in progesterone concentrations generates an FSH level surge, which occurs with the LH surge.
  • Ovulation occurs as a result of the estrogen-induced LH surge.

Luteal phase (days 14–28)

  • Ovulation is assumed to have occurred if the progesterone level exceeds 3 nglmL on cycle day 21. Progesterone levels are high in this phase.
  • The corpus luteum begins to develop, and it synthesizes estrogen and progesterone. Vascularity and secretory activity of the endometrium increase to prepare for the receipt of a fertilized egg.
  • If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses at the end of the luteal phase. As a result, estradiol and progesterone levels decrease abruptly.

Menses (days 0–4)

  • The endometrium is sloughed because of the abrupt withdrawal of estradiol and progesterone.

A schematic diagram of the menstrual cycle and the changes occurring are shown below:

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is diagnosed with mitral stenosis. Which of the following features is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Left ventricular hypertrophy is not seen in mitral stenosis. On the contrary, right ventricle hypertrophy is seen.

Mechanism of mitral stenosis (MS):

In a normal mitral valve, there is no obstruction to the flow of blood from the left atrium(LA) to the left ventricle. Therefore a small LA pressure is sufficient to empty the blood into the ventricle.

When the MVA is <~2 sq cm, blood flows from the left atrium to the left ventricle, propelled by a mildly elevated atrial pressure. Hence, patients are usually asymptomatic and may develop dyspnea only when the heart rate increases, as seen in exertion, excitement, fever, etc. All these conditions:

  •  Increase the rate of blood flow across the mitral orifice, resulting in further elevation of the LA pressure
  •  Decrease the diastolic filling time, resulting in a reduction in cardiac output

The image below explains the mechanism of mitral stenosis.

questions.text: All of the following are included in the first stage of labor, except ______.
questions.solution:
The encirclement of the largest head diameter by the vulval ring is called crowning. This occurs in the second stage of labor.

Cervical effacement and dilatation occur in the first stage of labor.

First stage of labor is divided into 2 phases:

Latent phase Active phase
The onset of true labor pain up to 5cm cervical dilatation  From ≥ 6cm cervical dilatation with regular uterine contractions
Duration: 10-12 hours (nullipara) 6-8 hours (multipara) Rate of cervical dilatation:
1.2 cm/hour (nullipara)
1.5 cm/hour (multipara)
Concerned with cervical effacement Concerned with cervical dilatation

 

Note: Clinically, the active phase of labor is considered from ≥6 cm of cervical dilatation. However, we begin plotting the partograph from 4 cm of cervical dilatation (in accordance with modified WHO Partograph).

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Factories Act?

choices.text: Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories.
A child of 16 years can be employed in certain industries from 6 AM to 9 PM.
The maximum working hours for an adult is 72 hours per week.
A child of 16 years can work till 6-8 hours per day.

questions.solution:
Factories act prohibits children of < 14 years from being employed.

For children between 14–18 years

  • They can be employed only in certain industries and work between 6 AM–7 PM
  • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.


Hours of work for Adults: Maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day; if overtime is paid, then it should be not more than 60 hrs per week.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

  • The act defines factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 
  • Age of employment –  prohibition children of < 14 years from working.
  • Adolescents between 15 – 18 years
    • Can be employed  only in certain industries and  work between 6 AM – 7 PM
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours
    • They are allowed to take leave once in every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days
  • Hours of work for adults: maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day, if working overtime then it should be no more than 60 hrs per week
  • Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person
  • Safety and Welfare measures:
    • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
    • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
    • > 250 Workers – Canteen
    • > 50 Workers- Crèche*

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law which has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers- 12 weeks to 26 weeks
  • Working mothers, already with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

 

*for fifty women worker after the 1976 amendment.

questions.text: Identify the following species of mosquito that has spotted wings.
questions.solution:
• Anopheline mosquitoes have spotted wings.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution.
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes and Mansonia.
  • Flight range varies up to 11 kms, except Aedes for which it is 100 metres.
  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen.

Lies parallel to undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Has siphon tube.

Has siphon tube.

They get the"tiger" name from white stripes  on its legs.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about antrochoanal polyp except that _______.

choices.text: It arises from the maxillary antrum
It is most commonly seen in children

questions.solution:
All of the above statements about the antrochoanal polyp are true except that it is bilateral.

Antrochoanal polyp is a type of non-neoplastic nasal polypoidal masses of edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. It arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium, comes out of it, and grows in the choana and nasal cavity. It is usually single and unilateral and is more commonly seen in children and young adults. 

The clinical features include unilateral nasal obstruction, mucoid nasal discharge, and a hyponasal voice. Anterior rhinoscopy may miss the antrochoanal polyp when it starts to grow posteriorly. A large polyp may protrude from the nasal cavity and may appear pink and congested.  

Diagnosis: Radiograph of the paranasal sinuses reveals opacity of the involved antrum. Non-contrast CT scan reveals the extent of the polyp. Endoscopic examination reveals the antrochoanal polyp hidden posteriorly in the nasal cavity

Treatment: Endoscopic sinus surgery is the treatment of choice. Recurrence is uncommon after the complete removal of the polyp.

questions.text: Roth spots are seen in ________.
questions.solution:
Roth spots are seen in acute leukemia.

Roth spots are retinal hemorrhages, named after Moritz Roth. It is a red spot (caused by hemorrhage), with a characteristic pale white center. This white center usually represents fibrin-platelet plugs.

They are composed of coagulated fibrin, including platelets, focal ischemia, inflammatory infiltrate, infectious organisms, or neoplastic cells.

Roth spots may be seen in

  • Leukemia
  • Diabetes
  • Subacute bacterial endocarditis
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • HIV retinopathy
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus

Image: Roth spots

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 40 children in rural and 30 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate test of significance, in this case, is the chi-square test. It is used to compare qualitative data between 2 groups with independent measures.

In this question,

  • Nutritional status (nourished or malnourished) is a qualitative measure.
  • Residence (Urban or rural) is again a qualitative measure.
  • Further, only these TWO variables are being compared. Therefore, the chi-square test is the most appropriate test of significance.

The Chi-square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed, but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

Other options:

Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This does not apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option C: Standard error of the mean is calculated for quantitative data, with measure of central tendency as mean.

Option D: The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

questions.text: The following feature is not seen in:
questions.solution:
Simian crease (single transverse palmar crease) is not seen in cystic fibrosis. 

Simian crease is seen in:

  • Down's syndrome
  • Fetal alcohol syndrome
  • Trisomy 13
  • Cri du chat syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is true about measles?

choices.text: Otitis media is a common complication

questions.solution:
The most common complications of measles include

  • Otitis media–in about 10–15 % of patients
  • Measles-associated diarrhea
  • Pneumonia

Subacute sclerosing pan encephalitis is a rare complication of measles which is fatal and occurs several years after primary infection.

Mortality rate in encephalitis is around 10–20 %.

Other options:

  • The incubation period of measles is 10 to 14 days
  • Measles is caused by RNA virus of the Paramyxoviruses.
  • The only source of infection is a case of measles. Carriers are not known to occur.

questions.text: Insulin inhibits which of the following lipase enzymes?
questions.solution:
Insulin has an inhibitory effect on lipolytic hormones like hormone sensitive lipase (HSL). In adipose tissues, the stored triglycerides are broken down (lipolysis) by hormone sensitive lipase (HSL) into free fatty acids (FFAs). Insulin inhibits HSL and thus reduces the release of FFAs and also glycerol.

In diabetic patients, low insulin level corresponds to an increase in HSL activity, promoting the breakdown of lipids and release of FFAs from adipose tissue. Hormone-sensitive lipase activity is accelerated by hormones like epinephrine, norepinephrine, glucagon, ACTH, TSH, GH, ADH, and Melanocyte stimulating hormones (MSH).

Insulin induces the activity of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) which is present on the walls of capillaries. LPL promotes hydrolysis of TGs and degradation of VLDL and chylomicrons. In diabetes, low insulin leads to decreased LPL activity resulting in increased VLDL and TGs levels.

Well-fed state (Insulin) During fasting (Glucagon)
Lipogenesis increased Lipogenesis inhibited
Lipolysis inhibited Lipolysis increased
Insulin inhibits HS-lipase Glucagon activates HS-lipase
Lipoprotein lipase active Lipoprotein lipase inactive

Effects of insulin on various tissues:

Tissue Increases Decreases
Adipose tissue Increased glucose entry
Increased fatty acid synthesis
Increased glycerol phosphate synthesis
Increased triglycerides deposition
Activation of lipoprotein lipase
Increased K+ uptake		 Inhibition of hormone-sensitive lipase
Muscle Increased glucose entry
Increased glycogen synthesis
Increased amino acid uptake
Increased protein synthesis in ribosome
Increase ketone uptake
Increase K+ uptake

Decrease protein catabolism

Decrease  release of glucogenic amino acids
Liver Increased protein synthesis
Increased lipid synthesis
Increased glycogen synthesis & glycolysis

Decrease ketogenesis

Decreased glucose output due to decreased gluconeogenesis
General Increased cell growth

questions.text: Which of the following findings is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows linea nigra.

Linea nigra is a brownish-black pigmented area that stretches from the xiphisternum to the symphysis pubis in the midline. The pigmentary changes may be due to melanocyte-stimulating hormone from the anterior pituitary. The pigmentation disappears after delivery. Similar changes are observed in women taking oral contraceptives may be due to estrogen and progesterone may be related to it as. 

Other options:

Option A: Striae gravidarum is slightly depressed linear marks with varying length and breadth found in pregnancy. They are predominantly found in the abdominal wall below the umbilicus. They appear pinkish in color. They can sometimes be found over the thighs and breasts. These stretch marks represent the scar tissues in the deeper layer of the cutis. 

Option B: Chloasma gravidarum also called pregnancy mask is an extreme form of pigmentation around the cheek, forehead, and around eyes. It may be patchy or diffuse. It disappears spontaneously after delivery.

Option C: Initially, striae gravidarum are pinkish but after the delivery, the scar tissues contract and obliterate the capillaries and appear glistening white. They are called the linea alba.

questions.text: Which of the following is the first marker to appear in blood after HBV infection?
questions.solution:
HBsAg is the first marker to appear in blood after infection. It can be detected even before the elevation of serum transaminases and onset of clinical illness. Usually, it disappears within 2 months of onset of clinical disease but may last for even 6 months and beyond. If it persists beyond 6 months, it indicates chronic hepatitis. Anti-HBs is the protective antibody, which appears soon after HBsAg disappears and remains in serum for a long time.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection
