questions.text: The muscle marked as 1 in the image below, is attached to which of the following?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked as 1 in the image above is the gluteus maximus muscle. It is attached to the iliotibial tract of the fascia lata.

Origin:

  • Posterior aspect of dorsal ilium, posterior to posterior gluteal line
  • Posterior superior iliac spine
  • Posterior aspect of sacrum and coccyx
  • Sacrotuberous ligament

Insertion - It is inserted mainly in fascia lata at the iliotibial band and also into the gluteal tuberosity on the posterior femoral surface.

Action:

  • Major extensor of hip joint
  • Lateral rotation of hip joint
  • Active in powerful abduction of thigh

Arterial Supply - Inferior and superior gluteal arteries and the first perforating branch of the profunda femoris artery.

Nerve Supply- Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1 and S2).

Note:

The fascia lata is a deep fascial investment of the whole thigh musculature.

The iliotibial tract is a longitudinal thickening of the fascia lata, which is strengthened posteriorly by fibers from the gluteus maximus.

Other options:

2 - The gluteus medius originates from the outer surface of the ileum between the anterior and posterior gluteal lines. Insertion of the muscle is at the lateral surface of the greater trochanter. It is supplied by the superior gluteal nerve.

3 - Piriformis - involved in lateral rotation and assists abduction at the hip joint. It is inserted into the medial side of greater trochanter of the femur. Entrapment of the sciatic nerve in the piriformis can lead to piriformis syndrome.

4 - Sciatic nerve - The nerve passes over the obturator internus, gemellus superior, gemellus inferior and quadratus femoris. It supplies knee flexors and muscles below the knee. Paralysis of this nerve results in flail foot and severe difficulty in walking.

questions.text: The image given below depicts which abnormality of the placenta?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts placenta succenturiata in which one or more small lobes of placenta may be placed at a distance from main placental margin.

Its complications are

  • Postpartum hemorrhage
  • Subinvolution
  • Uterine sepsis
  • Polyp formation

Other options:

  • Battledore placenta – The cord is attached to the margin of the placenta.
  • Circumvallate placenta - The fetal surface of placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery made up of a double fold of amnion and chorion.
  • Velamentous cord insertion - The umbilical cord is attached to the fetal membranes. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta.

questions.text: A woman is diagnosed to be positive for HIV in her first trimester. What is the appropriate management?

choices.text: Start ART immediately and continue till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue life-long
Start ART immediately and continue life-long
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue till 6 weeks after delivery

questions.solution:
ART should be initiated immediately and continued lifelong in all pregnant and breastfeeding women with HIV. This is regardless of their WHO clinical stage and CD4 cell count.

*Note: Pearl attached below has been updated according to the NACO ART guidelines 2021. Efavirenz has been replaced by Dolutegravir as per the new guidelines.

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who are age >10 years and body weight >30 kg with HIV-1, HIV-2, HIV 1&2 co-infection who have not received any ART 
  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
  • All PLHIV with abnormal serum creatinine values 
  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who were on the previous recommended regime (Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Efavirenz) to be counselled to switch to new regime. Continue older regime if response is good
  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

*PLHIV: People living with HIV

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male patient presents with recent onset of photosensitivity and development of vesicles and bullae on the sun-exposed areas of his skin as shown below. A urine analysis showed the presence of elevated levels of uroporphyrin I and normal red cell uroporphyrin. Identify the false statement regarding the patient's illness.

UROD- Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase

choices.text: Low dose hydroxychloroquine is used in management
Associated with increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is porphyria cutanea tarda. The false statement regarding the patient's illness is that the hepatic iron stores are normal. The hepatic iron stores are increased.

Porphyrias are a group of metabolic disorders caused by the deficiency/ abnormal functioning of enzymes involved in heme biosynthesis which leads to subsequent accumulation and excretion of porphyrins/ their precursors.

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is a type of hepatic, cutaneous porphyria caused due to a deficiency in the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase, which converts uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III. Mutations of the uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (UROD) gene are present.

The accumulated porphyrins transported to the skin act as photosensitizers. Hence, the patients usually present with skin fragility and bullae on sun-exposed skin, in areas of repeated trauma such as the dorsal aspect of the hands, the forearms, face, and ears. The erosions produced by the rupture of skin lesions heal with purplish discoloration. Hypertrichosis, mottled pigmentary change, and scleroderma-like induration are associated features.

Diagnosis is made by the classical clinical feature of photosensitivity with elevated urine, stool, and plasma uroporphyrin with normal red cell uroporphyrin. 

PCT is the most readily treated form of porphyria. Management includes:

  • Phlebotomies to deplete iron, guided by serum ferritin level estimation.
  • Hydroxychloroquine to remove excess porphyrins from the liver. A low-dose hydroxychloroquine regimen is preferred to avoid hepatotoxicity.

 

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic porphyria

Hepatic porphyria is caused due to enzyme deficiency early in the pathway of heme synthesis. There is an accumulation of ALA and PBG. The patient principally presents with neurovisceral symptoms.

Erythropoietic porphyria is caused due to enzyme deficiency late in the pathway of heme synthesis. There is an accumulation of porphyrins which leads to cutaneous photosensitivity.

Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except

questions.text: Identify the investigation and the lesion depicted in the image given below.

choices.text: Retrograde cystourethrogram with membranous urethra stricture
Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture
Micturating cystourethrography with prostratic urethra stricture

questions.solution:
The given image shows retrograde cystourethrogram with findings consistent with penile urethral stricture.

The male urethra can be visualized by retrograde urethrography (RGU) or voiding cystourethrogram (VCU), also known as micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).

In RGU, the urethra is visualized with the instillation of contrast into the anterior urethra (penile urethra and bulbar urethra). It is helpful for diagnosing anterior urethral abnormalities.

The following image shows an RGU with bulbar urethral stricture:


In VCU, after injecting contrast into the bladder using a Foleys catheter, the posterior urethra (membranous urethra and prostatic urethra) is visualized during micturition. It is helpful for diagnosing posterior urethral abnormalities and bladder abnormalities. It is the investigation of choice for vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) and posterior urethral valve.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient with diabetic neuropathy was found to have a loss of sensation to tap and vibration at low frequency (20 Hz), but an intact vibration sense at a higher frequency (200 Hz). Which of the following somatosensory receptors is most likely to have been affected?
questions.solution:
Sensations of tap and low-frequency vibration (flutter, 5-40 Hz) are sensed by Meissner's corpuscles. Hence, a loss of sensation of tap and flutter is most likely due to the disease affecting Meissner's corpuscles.

Cutaneous mechanoreceptors: There are four mechanoreceptors for sensing touch and pressure. They include:

  • Meissner corpuscles
  • Merkel cells
  • Ruffini corpuscles
  • Pacinian corpuscles

 Meissner corpuscles are dendrites encapsulated in the connective tissue beneath the epidermis of glabrous (non-hairy) skin. They respond to tap and flutter (low-frequency vibration - 5-40Hz).

Merkel cells are expanded dendritic endings in the epidermis of glabrous (non-hairy) skin. They respond to sustained pressure and touch.

Ruffini's corpuscles are enlarged dendritic endings with elongated capsules in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin. They respond to stretch and fluttering vibrations.

Pacinian corpuscles:

  • They are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptor, measuring about 2mm long and 1mm in diameter.
  • They are present in the dermis of glabrous (non-hairy) and hairy skin.
  • A Pacinian corpuscle consists of a nerve ending encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue, giving it an onion-like appearance.
  • They respond to fast vibration (60-500Hz) and deep pressure.

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

questions.text: Which of the following structures is involved in tonsillar herniation?
questions.solution:
Cerebellum is involved in tonsillar herniation.

Tonsillar herniation refers to the displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. This pattern of herniation is life-­threatening because it causes brainstem compression and compromises vital respiratory and cardiac centers in the medulla.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should not be continued on the day of surgery?
questions.solution:
Oral hypoglycemic agents are generally withheld on the day of surgery except for minor, short procedures.

Related Pearl: Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery

Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery:

Drug Duration before discontinuation

Discontinue on the day of surgery

Oral hypoglycemic agents 

Discontinue on the day of surgery

Discontinue 24 hours before the day of surgery

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol consumption for 3 days and presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient who has not consumed alcohol for the past 3 days presenting with disorientation, paranoid delusions, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is a medical emergency that occurs during alcohol withdrawal. It is an acute condition and usually develops within 72 hours after the last drink. It has symptoms of both delirium and alcohol withdrawal.

The clinical features of delirium tremens are as follows:

  • Altered sensorium with disorientation
  • Perceptual distortions, most frequently tactile or visual hallucinations
  • Autonomic hyperactivity with tachycardia, fever, anxiety, insomnia, hypertension, and sweating
  • Fluctuating levels of psychomotor activity, ranging from agitation to lethargy
  • Altered sleep-wake cycle

Other options:

Option B: Wernicke’s encephalopathy (alcoholic encephalopathy) is associated with thiamine deficiency. Alcohol abuse may lead to thiamine deficiency because of poor nutritional habits or malabsorption.

It is an acute neurological disorder characterized by

  • Global confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities like horizontal nystagmus, gaze palsy, anisocoria, and sluggish pupillary reflex
  • Ataxia - mainly affecting the gait
  • Vestibular dysfunction

It may resolve with thiamine therapy or progress to Korsakoff's syndrome.

Option C: Korsakoff’s psychosis can follow Wernicke’s encephalopathy due to thiamine deficiency. It is a chronic amnestic syndrome that is characterized by the following clinical symptoms in an intact and responsive patient:

  • Impaired mental syndrome, especially recent memory
  • Anterograde amnesia
  • Confabulation

Option D: Alcohol-induced psychosis is characterized by the development of auditory hallucinations or paranoid delusions in the context of heavy drinking or alcohol withdrawal. These patients have a clear sensorium, unlike the patients having delirium tremens.

questions.text: A  female patient presents with severe abdominal pain and vomiting, which was provisionally diagnosed as intestinal obstruction. An emergency laparotomy was done, and the following specimen was removed. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the image of a trichobezoar, suggests a diagnosis of trichophagia.

Trichophagia is the compulsive eating of hair associated with trichotillomania. Trichotillomania is a form of obsessive-compulsive disorder that is associated with hair pulling. In trichophagia, people also ingest the hair that they pull. 

Complications of trichotillomania include

  • trichobezoars
  • malnutrition
  • intestinal obstruction

Trichobezoar is a foreign body found in the gastrointestinal tract as a result of accumulated ingested hair.

The modalities currently used in the management of trichotillomania are cognitive behavioral therapy and habit reversal training.

questions.text: A female patient comes to the clinic with complaints of pain in the lateral aspect of the right breast for the past 5 days. On examination, the following finding is noted under her breast. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mondor disease. The image shows the presence of a subcutaneous cord and a narrow shallow groove along the side of the cord.

Mondor disease is the thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall. The most commonly involved vein is the lateral thoracic vein. Patients usually present with pain along the lateral chest wall and a tender, firm cord below the breast. It is a benign condition and gets resolved on its own within 4-6 weeks. Warm compresses and anti-inflammatory medicines can be used to reduce pain. If the symptoms persist despite medications, the affected segment of the vein can be excised.

Option A: Tietze syndrome is a benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages.

Option B: Zuska disease is the subcutaneous abscess of the breast tissue beneath the areola of the nipple. It is also called a subareolar abscess.

Option D: Stewart–Treves Syndrome is characterized by lymphangiosarcoma in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common type of atrial septal defect?
questions.solution:
Ostium secundum is the most common type of atrial septal defect (ASD), located at mid-inter-atrial septum, in the region of the fossa ovalis.

Other options:

  • Ostium primum: lower atrial septum
  • Endocardial cushion defect/AV septal defect/AV canal defect consists of contiguous atrial and VSDs with markedly abnormal AV valves. The lesion is common in children with Down syndrome
  • Sinus venosus: high atrial septum, at the junction of superior vena cava and right atrium

Related Pearl: Locations of Congenital Heart Disease

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not reduce mortality in a patient with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction?
questions.solution:
Digoxin does not reduce mortality in patients with HFrEF.

  • ACE inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)
  • Angiotensin receptor neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI)

questions.text: The predominant type of collagen in the sclera is __________.
questions.solution:
Collagen type I is the predominant type of collagen found in the sclera. In fact, collagen forms 50 to 75% of the dry weight of the sclera.

Type II is absent in the sclera. It is rather found in the vitreous body of the eye.

questions.text: The amplifier for Japanese encephalitis is _________.
questions.solution:
• Pigs are considered the amplifiers of the virus.
  • Pigs have been incriminated the major hosts for JE virus. Infected pigs do not manifest any overt symptoms of illness but circulate the virus so that mosquitoes can get infected and transmit the virus to man. Hence, pigs are considered the "amplifiers" of the virus.
  • Cattle and buffaloes may also be infected with JE virus and they act as "mosquito attractants".

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presented with malaise, fatigue, and rigors for 1 week. Multiple puncture sites were present on the forearm along with sclerosed veins. His temperature on admission was 38.5 °C. Examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur which was loudest at the left sternal edge. Three sets of blood cultures were taken. Which organism is most likely to be found in his blood cultures?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario the patient is having malaise and fever and on examination pan-systolic murmur is heard which is suggestive of infective endocarditis. Staphylococcus aureus is most likely to be positive in cultures as it is the most common cause of infective endocarditis in IV drug abusers. Endocarditis in injection drug users is mostly right-sided and involves the tricuspid valve.

Infective endocarditis is a microbial infection of the heart valves or the mural endocardium that leads to the formation of vegetations composed of thrombotic debris and organisms, often associated with the destruction of the underlying cardiac tissue.

It is classified as :

Acute - infection of a previously normal heart valve by a highly virulent organism that progresses rapidly.

Subacute - infection in previously deformed valves by organisms of lower virulence like  S.viridans, S. epidermidis, HACEK(Haemophilus, Actinobacillus, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, and Kingella) group that progresses gradually over weeks to months. Microscopically, the vegetations of subacute IE typically exhibit granulation tissue at their bases indicative of healing

Clinical features include subungual splinter haemorrhages, Osler nodes, Janeway lesions, and Roth spots. 

The image below shows Osler nodes which are painful raised violaceous lesions commonly affecting the fingers, toes, and feet. It is immunologically mediated.

Related Pearl: Microbiology of Infective Endocarditis

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: The following test is positive for the identification of ________.
questions.solution:
The image shows the germ tube test used for identifying Candida albicans.

Germ tube test: Unlike other species of Candida, yeast cells of C. albicans will begin to form true hyphae or germ tubes after incubation in serum for about 90 minutes at 37°C. This is known as Reynolds-Braude phenomenon.

questions.text: A patient comes to the sleep clinic and the following pattern is seen on polysomnography. What type of breathing pattern is it?
questions.solution:
The breathing pattern shown in the image is suggestive of Cheyne-Stokes respiration. It is characterized by progressively deeper and sometimes faster breathing, followed by a gradual decrease that results in a temporary stop in breathing called apnea.

It is caused by an increased sensitivity of the respiratory center to arterial PCO2. There is an apneic phase, during which arterial PO2 falls and arterial PCO2 rises. These changes in the arterial blood gas content stimulate the respiratory center, resulting in hyperventilation and hypocapnia, followed by recurrence of apnea. It is present in 40% of patients with advanced HF and usually is associated with low cardiac output.

questions.text: The image below shows an instrument used in mastoid surgery. Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker, which is used in mastoid surgery to explore the air cells with one end and to curette the intervening septa and granulations with the other.

Note:

MacEwen’s (suprameatal) triangle:

It is bounded by

  • temporal line
  • posterosuperior segment of bony external auditory canal 
  • the line drawn as a tangent to the external canal

It is an important landmark to locate the mastoid antrum in mastoid surgery.

questions.text: The visual field defect usually found in craniopharyngioma is _____.
questions.solution:
The visual field defect usually found in craniopharyngioma is bitemporal hemianopia.

Craniopharyngiomas are benign masses usually presenting in the suprasellar region arising near the pituitary stalk and can produce functional impairment of the hypophysis due to mass effect. The clinical features of craniopharyngiomas include headaches, visual field defects, growth failure and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypofunction. CT scan may show calcifications in the supra-sellar region. Treatment includes trans-sphenoidal resection of the tumor followed by adjuvant chemotherapy.

Lesions of the optic chiasma can cause bitemporal hemianopia, i.e, loss of vision in the temporal halves of both visual fields. Nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma at this level, and hence, these fibers are compromised.

Other causes of chiasmal lesions are

  • Pituitary adenoma (most common)
  • Aneurysm of the anterior communicating artery
  • Meningioma
  • Glioma

Other options:

Option B) Binasal hemianopia is a rare visual field defect also caused due to lesions at the optic chiasma.  

Option C) Superior quadrantanopia is also known as pie-in-the-sky defect and is caused when lesions affect the inferior fibers of the optic radiations in the temporal lobe.  

Option D) Inferior quadrantanopia is also known as pie-on-the-floor defect and is caused due to lesions affecting the superior fibers of the optic radiations in the parietal lobe.

questions.text: Dengue fever is transmitted by _______.
questions.solution:
• Dengue is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito, which is also called as tiger mosquitoe.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution.
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes and Mansonia.
  • Flight range varies up to 11 kms, except Aedes for which it is 100 metres.
  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen.

Charateristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia
EggsUsually 100-250. This stage lasts 1 – 2 days. Laid singly; boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star shaped clusters.
Larval stageThis stage lasts for 5 -7 days.

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Stripped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artifical collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis,Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 
  • Called "Nuisance mosquitoes"
  • These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called as tiger mosquitoes and they are day biters

They get the"tiger" name from white stripes  on its legs.

 Mansonia mosquitoes are big, black or brown mosquitoes with sparkling on their wings and legs. 

 

 

  • Culex mosquito, they keep their bodies horizontal while feeding:

 

  • Anopheles mosquito as seen in the image below, they tend to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high:

 

  • Aedes mosquito (aegypti), as seen in the image below, their bodies are striped:

questions.text: Identify the following instrument that was devised to measure the cooling power of air
questions.solution: • The image shown above is of the kata thermometer, which was used to measure the cooling power of air.

questions.text: A young sheep farmer presents to the OPD with pain in the right upper part of the abdomen. On examination, there is tenderness and enlargement of the liver. The abdominal ultrasound image is shown below. How would you classify this patient as per the WHO classification of cystic echinococcosis (CE)?
questions.solution:
The ultrasound image is of active hydatid cyst with multiple septations and rosette or honeycomb appearance. As per the WHO classification of cystic echinococcosis (CE), this finding indicates type 2 CE (CE2).

Classification of CE based on ultrasound imaging

Type Ultrasound features
Active cyst
CE1 Univesicular fluid collection
CE2 Honeycomb appearance: Multivesicular fluid collection with daughter cysts separated by septae
Transitional cyst
CE3A Water lily sign: Fluid collection with detached membrane
CE3B Daughter cysts present in a solid matrix
Inactive/dead cyst
CE4 Cysts in a heterogeneous matrix with no daughter cysts
CE5 Solid cystic wall
Class Management
CE1 

<5 cm albendazole 400 mg PO BID

 >5 cm albendazole 400 mg PO BID+ PAIR
CE3a

<5 cm albendazole 400 mg PO BID

>5 cm albendazole  PO BID+ PAIR
CE2, CE3b

PAIR contraindicated

Large bore percutaneous treatment

Surgery+albendazole 400 mg PO BID.
CE4 & 5

PAIR contraindicated

Observation (ultrasonography preferred every 6 months)

 

 CE: Cystic echinococcosis

PO: Per oral

BID: Twice daily

PAIR: Puncture, aspiration, injection, and respiration

questions.text: Soiling index is a measure of which of the following?

choices.text: Organic pollution of air and water

questions.solution:
Soiling index is a measure of air pollution.

In this method, a known volume of air is filtered through a white filter paper under specified conditions and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter.

Other indicators of air pollution:

  • Sulfur dioxide 
  • Grit and dust measurement 
  • The co-efficient of haze 
  • Air pollution index / AQI
  • Suspended particle matter (SPM)

Related Pearl: Air Pollution

  • The vertical diffusion of pollutants depends upon the temperature gradient. When there is rapid cooling of the lower atmospheric layers – which is called temperature inversion - due to little vertical diffusion, pollutants and water vapor get trapped in the lower levels of the atmosphere.
  • Air pollutants:
Pollutant Comments
Carbon monoxide From incomplete combustion of carbon-containing materials like fuel combustion, vehicles, industries, etc.
Sulphur dioxide Colorless gas with a sharp odor. Results from combustion of sulphur-containing fossil fuels, smelting of ores, etc. It is one of the main components of acid rain.
Lead Usually occupational and environmental sources.
Carbon dioxide Increase in global concentration above natural levels can increase temperature and affect climate adversely.
Hydrocarbons Cause photochemical smog.
Cadmium Results from volcanic action, waste incineration, zinc production, smoking, etc.
Hydrogen sulphide Produced in waste-water treatment plants, wood pulp production, coke production, etc.
Ozone Ground level ozone is one of the main constituents of photochemical smog.
Oxides of nitrogen  Most common form is nitric oxide. Produced from coal burning, road traffic and electricity generation. Affects lungs adversely.
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) Produced by incomplete burning of wood or coal, vehicle exhausts, smoking, etc. PAHs are carcinogenic and mutagenic.
Particulate matter Mixture of solid and liquid, organic and inorganic matter. Major components are sulfates, nitrates, sodium chloride, mineral dust, black carbon and water.
  • Common indoor air pollutants include carbon monoxide, PAHs, nitrogen and sulphur oxides, pesticides, asbestos, lead, radon and other biological pollutants. Most these are from coal or fuel combustion. Pollutants like radon, lead, asbestos, etc. are from construction materials, paints and demolition.
  • Effects of indoor air pollution:
    • Lung infections including pneumonia, tuberculosis, ALRI
    • Stroke
    • Ischemic heart disease
    • COPD
    • Lung, laryngeal, nasopharyngeal cancers
    • Pregnancy problems like low birth weight
  • Indicators of air pollution:
    • Sulphur dioxide is one of the best indicators of air pollution
    • Smoke or soiling index: A known volume of air is filtered through a white filter paper under specified conditions and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter
    • Grit and dust measurement are another indicator of air pollution
    • Co-efficient of haze is a factor used in assessment of the amount of smoke or other aerosol in air
    • Air pollution index is an arbitrary index which takes into account one or more pollutants as a measure of pollution severity
    • Suspended particle matter (SPM) is another indicator widely used
  • In India, National Air Quality Programme sponsored by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) is the main mode of monitoring air pollution.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common benign liver tumor?
questions.solution:
Cavernous hemangioma is the most common benign liver tumor.

Cavernous hemangiomas appear as red-blue, soft nodules, usually less than 2 cm in diameter. Their clinical significance is that they might be mistaken radiographically or intraoperatively for metastatic tumors.

questions.text: Patients with urine output below what level are said to have anuria?
questions.solution:
Anuria is defined as urine output less than 100 mL/day. Oliguria is defined as urine output less than 400 mL/day. 

Acute kidney injury (AKI) can have varied clinical features depending on the etiology. The history and physical examination in AKI aims mainly at:

  • Finding the etiology 
  • Identifying the occurrence of any complications

The following clinical features may be seen:

  • Oliguria or anuria 
  • Gross hematuria 
  • Renal colic pain (in renal stones)
  • Loss of skin turgor, dry mouth, hypotension, tachycardia (in hypovolemia) 
  • Prostatomegaly and/or a pelvic mass (in post-renal obstruction) 
  • Dysuria, fever with chills and rigors, increased frequency of micturition, renal angle tenderness (in pyelonephritis)
  • Edema, hypertension (volume overload)
  • Encephalopathy, seizures, platelet dysfunction (uremia)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding screening mammography?

choices.text: Two views are obtained, the craniocaudal (CC) and mediolateral oblique (MLO) views.
Mammography is usually performed in the 2nd half of menstrual cycle.
Mammography is less sensitive in young patients.
The MLO view images the greatest volume of breast tissue.

questions.solution:
Mammography is best performed in the 1st half of the menstrual cycle, as breast tissue is less dense in the follicular phase.

In the 2nd half of the menstrual cycle, since ovulation occurs and there is a chance for pregnancy, radiation can potentially affect the embryo. 

The sensitivity of mammography increases with age, as the breast tissue becomes less dense. 

It involves 2 standard views: 

  1. Mediolateral oblique (MLO) view - covers a greater volume of breast tissue, including the upper outer quadrant and the axillary tail of Spence
  2. Craniocaudal (CC) view - provides better visualization of the medial aspect of the breast

Mammography uses low-voltage, high-amperage X-rays. The radiation dose from mammography is around 0.1 cGy per study.

questions.text:
A patient presented with tendon xanthomas. His lipid profile showed serum cholesterol levels to be 283 mg/dL and serum LDL to be 202 mg/dL. He was started on lovastatin. What is the likely diagnosis?

LDL - Low-density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with tendon xanthomas and elevated serum LDL (low-density lipoprotein) and elevated serum cholesterol points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia (FH).

Familial hypercholesterolemia (type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia) is an inherited disorder due to defects in LDL receptors. This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and cholesterol are elevated. Such patients are at increased risk to develop atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.

Features of FH: 

  • Painful polyarthritis and tendinitis are common.
  • Physical findings seen are corneal arcus and tendon xanthomas over Achilles tendon and the dorsum of hands. Xanthomas are tumorous masses produced by foamy cell clusters (lipid-laden macrophages) found in the connective tissue of the skin and in tendons.

Diagnosis is done clinically based on hypercholesterolemia with 

  • LDL >190 mg/dL, 
  • Family history of hypercholesterolemia and/or
  • Premature coronary artery disease.

Treatment includes lifestyle changes, restriction of a fatty diet, and pharmacotherapy with statins in heterozygous FH patients.

Recent drugs for specific treatment of homozygous FH are:

  • Lomitapide, a microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) inhibitor, and
  • Mipomersen, an antisense oligonucleotide against apoB.

The image below shows Achilles tendon xanthoma and a plain lateral radiograph of both ankles showing bilateral symmetrical swellings (arrows) superior to the calcaneum respectively. 

 

Other options

Option B: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Enlarged orange tonsils are pathognomonic. Low HDL levels are seen. There is an increased risk for atherosclerosis.

The image below shows enlarged yellow-orange colored tonsils in Tangier's disease.

 

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency causes type I hyperlipoproteinemia due to defects in LPL or apo C-II. Eruptive xanthomas are seen. Chylomicrons and VLDL are elevated. LDL and HDL are low. There is no risk for coronary disease.

Option D: Familial hyperchylomicronemia syndrome is caused due to either LPL deficiency, ApoC-II deficiency, ApoA-V deficiency, or GPIHBP1 mutation. Clinically, patients present with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain due to acute pancreatitis. The retinal blood vessels may be opalescent and are called lipemia retinalis. Increased levels of triglycerides (mostly >1000 mg/dL) is seen. The risk of premature coronary heart disease is low.

questions.text:
ORS solution facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors?

ORS-Oral Rehydration Solution
questions.solution:
Oral rehydration solution (ORS) facilitates glucose absorption through sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter 1(SGLT 1). In a child with diarrhoea, when ORS is given, there is coupled absorption of sodium and glucose through SGLT-1.

Glucose transport may be active or passive:

  • Active transport of glucose takes place through SGLT-1 and SLGT-2.
  • SGLT 1 helps in glucose absorption in the small intestine and renal tubules.
  • SGLT 2 (Option B) primarily facilitates glucose absorption in the renal tubules.
  • Passive absorption of glucose occurs through facilitated diffusion. This is carried out by glucose transporters GLUT 1 to 7. 

Other options :

Option C: GLUT4 is the carrier for insulin-mediated uptake of glucose into muscle and adipose tissue.

Option D: The sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX), also known as the sodium-calcium transporter, is a crucial membrane protein that helps maintain cellular calcium homeostasis by facilitating the exchange of sodium (Na⁺) and calcium (Ca²⁺) ions across the plasma membrane.

Related Pearl: Glucose Transporters

 

Function

Major sites of expression

Secondary active transport

(Na + -glucose cotransport)

    

SGLT 1

Absorption of glucose

Small intestine, renal tubules

SGLT 2

Absorption of glucose

Renal tubules

Facilitated diffusion

    

GLUT 1

Basal glucose uptake

Placenta, blood-brain barrier, brain, red cells, kidneys, colon, many other organs

GLUT 2

β-cell glucose sensor; transport out of intestinal and renal epithelial cells

β cells of islets, liver, epithelial cells of small intestine, kidneys

GLUT 3

Basal glucose uptake

Brain, placenta, kidneys, many other organs

GLUT 4

Insulin-stimulated glucose uptake

Skeletal and cardiac muscle, adipose tissue, other tissues

GLUT 5

Fructose transport

Jejunum, sperm

GLUT 6

 Function not known Brain, spleen, leucocytes
GLUT 7 Glucose-6-phosphate transporter in the endoplasmic reticulum Liver

  • Arytenoid
