questions.text: As a first-year resident assisting in a superficial parotidectomy, you have been asked to identify the facial nerve trunk. All of the following structures can be used for its localization, except ____.
questions.solution:
The inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle is not used as an anatomical landmark for the identification of the facial nerve trunk.

There are two methods for localization of the facial nerve trunk: 

1. Anterograde method: In this method, the facial nerve trunk is identified based on the anatomical landmarks after it exits from the stylomastoid foramen. The anatomical landmarks include:

  • Conley's pointer is the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. The facial nerve trunk lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip.
  • Posterior belly of digastric - The facial nerve lies superior to the upper border of the muscle.
  • Mastoid process - Upon drilling it, the nerve is identified proximally.
  • Squamotympanic fissure is a fissure in the temporal bone, which runs from TMJ to the tympanic cavity. The facial nerve runs through this fissure.
  • Styloid process - The facial nerve lies superficial to it.

2. Retrograde method: In this method, the main branches of the facial nerve trunk are identified and are then traced proximally until the main tunk is identified. Some of the main branches that are commonly used for tracing the facial nerve trunk include:

  • Buccal branch lies in relation to the parotid gland
  • Marginal mandibular branch lies in relation to the facial vessels
  • Temporal branch

The given image shows the anatomical relations useful for the localization of the facial nerve trunk.

questions.text: The middle meningeal artery enters into the middle cranial fossa through which of the following foramina?
questions.solution:
The middle meningeal artery enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen spinosum, labeled as 3 in the image.

Foramina marked in the image are

1 - Foramen rotundum

2 - Foramen ovale

3 - Foramen spinosum

4 - Jugular foramen

The middle meningeal artery is a branch of the first part of maxillary artery, given off in the infratemporal fossa. In here, it first runs upwards and medially between the sphenomandibular ligament and lateral pterygoid muscle and then passes through a loop formed by the two roots of the auriculotemporal nerve.
Following this, it enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen spinosum; following which it has an extradural course. It runs forward and laterally, grooving the squamous temporal bone and gives rise to its frontal and parietal branches.

The middle meningeal artery is predominantly a periosteal artery which supplies the bone and red bone marrow in the diploe.

questions.text: A man was rushed to the casualty after getting stabbed in the back with a knife. On MRI, a complete transection of one side of the spinal cord is suspected. Which of the following is likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
Fine touch lost on the opposite side
Pain and temperature lost on the same side
Only pain lost on the same side

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has Brown-Sequard syndrome. It is characterized by loss of pain and temperature on the opposite side.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome.

The lesion to fasciculus gracilus or fasciculus cuneatus leads to ipsilateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion.

The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to contra­lateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion.

Damage to the cor­ticospinal tract produces weakness and spasticity in certain muscle groups on the same side of the body.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: Reduviid bugs are the biological vectors for the transmission of ______.
questions.solution:
Reduviid bugs are the biological vectors for the transmission of Chagas disease.

Biological vectors: Vectors that not only help in the transfer of parasites but the parasites undergo development or multiplication in their body as well. They are also called as true vectors.

Examples:

Mosquito - Malaria, filariasis

Sandfly - Kala-azar

Tsetse fly - Sleeping sickness

Reduviid bugs - Chagas disease

Ticks - Babesiosis

questions.text: You are planning to conduct a randomized control trial to study the effect of an emollient for eczema, you consider two groups of which one group will receive a placebo. You are considering a blinding trial for this to prevent bias. Which among the following is the most frequent blinding that is used to conduct such trials?
questions.solution:
The most frequently used method when blinded-trials are conducted is double-blinding, although ideally triple blinding should be used.

Double blinding trials are where neither the group members nor the observers are aware of the group allocation.

Related Pearl: Blinding in Epidemiology

  • Blinding is done in epidemiology to reduce the possibility of bias.
  • Types
    • In single blind trials, only the participants or group members are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In double blind trials, both the group members and the observers are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In triple blind trials, the group members, the observers and the analyzers are unaware of the group allocation.
  • The most commonly used type of blinding is double blinding.

questions.text: The area marked "x" in the image given below consists of all, except ______.
questions.solution:
The area marked "x" in the image does not contain myosin.

Myosin forms the thick filament, while actin, troponin, and tropomyosin form the thin filament.

Thin Filaments in Sarcomere:

  • The thin filaments are polymers made up of two chains of actin that form a long double helix.
  • Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin. Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.
  • Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:
    • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
    • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
    • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca2+ that helps to initiate contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: Which of the following peaks marked in the image below is responsible for ovulation?
questions.solution:
The label marked 2 represents the LH surge ,which is responsible for ovulation.

Phases of the menstrual cycle:

Follicular phase (days 0–14)

  • A primordial follicle develops to the Graafian stage, with atresia of neighboring follicles.
  • LH and FSH receptors are upregulated in theca and granulosa cells.
  • Estradiol levels increase and cause the proliferation of the uterus.
  • FSH and LH levels are suppressed by the negative feedback effect of estradiol on the anterior pituitary.
  • Progesterone levels are low.

Ovulation (day 14)

  • It occurs 14 days before menses, regardless of cycle length. Thus, in a 28-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 14; in a 35-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 22.
  • A burst of estradiol synthesis at the end of the follicular phase has a positive feedback effect on the secretion of FSH and LH (LH surge).
  • Ovulation occurs as a result of the estrogen-induced LH surge.
  • Estrogen levels decrease just after ovulation (but rise again during the luteal phase).
  • Cervical mucus increases in quantity; it becomes less viscous and more penetrable by sperm.

Luteal phase (days 14–28)

  • Progesterone levels are high.
  • The corpus luteum begins to develop, and it synthesizes estrogen and progesterone. Vascularity and secretory activity of the endometrium increase to prepare for the receipt of a fertilized egg.
  • Basal body temperature increases because of the effect of progesterone on the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center.
  • If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses at the end of the luteal phase. As a result, estradiol and progesterone levels decrease abruptly.

Menses (days 0–4)

  • The endometrium is sloughed because of the abrupt withdrawal of estradiol and progesterone.

A schematic diagram of the menstrual cycle and the changes occurring is shown below:

Related Pearl: Hormonal Regulation of Menstrual Cycle

questions.text: In tennis elbow, the primary tendinosis occurs at ______.
questions.solution:
In the tennis elbow, primary tendinosis occurs at 1-2 cm distal to the attachment of extensor carpi radialis brevis muscle to the lateral epicondyle. 

Tennis elbow is also known as lateral epicondylitis. This is the most common tendinopathy. It is caused by repetitive contraction of extensor muscles at lateral epicondyle in activities that require repetitive forceful wrist extension and supination. 

It is common in individuals who play tennis, squash, and badminton. The pain improves on rest.

Conservative management with physiotherapy will speed up the recovery. Steroid injections can be used for short-term pain relief. Arthroscopic surgery technique can be used, but it has a higher risk of nerve injury.

Related Pearl: Medial and lateral epicondylitis

Tennis elbow or Lateral epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over or below the lateral epicondyle of the humerus.
  • Pain is aggravated by lifting movements. 
  • It is common among tennis players and in those who perform repetitive wrist extension.
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon is commonly involved.

Tests:

  • Cozen's test: The patient is asked to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle. 
  • Mills sign: Pain at the lateral condyle when the elbow is extended in pronation with a flexed wrist. 
  • Wringing test: The patient is asked to wring a towel. Pain is felt at the lateral epicondyle in tennis elbow.
  • Maudsley's test: Resisted extension of the middle finger produces pain at the lateral epicondyle.

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and usage of a tennis elbow clasp are sufficient in most cases. Corticosteroid and local anaesthetic injections into the tender area may reduce the pain, but is not curative.
  • Operative treatment: Detachment of the common extensor muscle from the lateral epicondyle.

 

Golfer's elbow or Medial epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over the medial epicondyle of the humerus where pronators have their origin
  • Associated with ulnar nerve neuropathy
  • Less common than tennis elbow

Tests:

  • Reverse Cozen: The elbow is kept in slight flexion with the hand and wrist in supination. The examiner attempts to extend the elbow, while the patient is asked to resist this movement with active flexion. If pain is elicited at the medial epicondyle, it suggests golfer’s elbow.

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and pain killers is sufficient in most cases.
  • Operative treatment:  Excision of the abnormal tendons at the flexor-pronator origin

questions.text: In the pediatric wards, you notice a baby completely preoccupied with play and a mother trying hard to spoonfeed him. He is busy stacking toy cubes on top of each other and starts gleefully clapping once he makes a tower of 6 cubes. What is the likely age that this milestone corresponds to?
questions.solution:
A child can usually make a tower of 6 blocks by 24 months.

A child makes a tower of

  • 2 blocks by 15 months
  • 3 blocks by 18 months
  • 6 blocks by 2 years
  • 9 blocks by 3 years.

Related Pearl: Fine motor milestones

 
Age Milestone
4 months Reaches out for objects with both hands (Bidextrous reach)
6 months
Reaches out for objects with one hand (Unidextrous reach) and transfers objects
9 months Immature pincer grasp
12 months Mature pincer grasp
15 months Imitates scribbling and builds a tower of 2 blocks
18 months Scribbles and builds a tower of 3 blocks
2 years Builds a tower of 6 blocks
3 years Builds a tower of 9 blocks and copies a circle
4 years Builds a bridge with blocks and copies a cross
5 years Copies a triangle and builds a gate with blocks

questions.text: Ubiquitin is a key molecule in protein degradation. Ubiquitinated proteins are degraded by ______
questions.solution:
Ubiquitination is an enzymatic, post-translational modification involving the covalent binding of a small 76–amino acid protein, ubiquitin, to the proteins. This process most commonly binds the last amino acid of ubiquitin (glycine 76) to a lysine residue on the substrate.

  • Ubiquitination usually marks denatured or misfolded proteins for degradation by the proteasome.
  • Polymeric proteasome complex is a cylinder-like structure containing multiple, different protease activities, into which the poly-ubiquitinated molecules are unfolded and funnelled, each with its active site pointed at the hollow core.
  • Proteasomes digest proteins into small (6 to 12 amino acids) fragments that can subsequently be degraded to their constituent amino acids and recycled.
  • Ubiquitination of proteins may also alter their cellular location, affect their activity, and promote or prevent protein interactions.

Clinical importance: Proteasome inhibitor - bortezomib is used in multiple myeloma and hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following complications would you not expect to see in a patient diagnosed with diphtheria?
questions.solution:
Hard palate paralysis is not seen in diphtheria.

The exotoxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae is toxic to the heart and nerves. It causes:

  • Myocarditis
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Acute circulatory failure

Neurological complications include paralysis of the soft-palate, diaphragm, and ocular muscles. In the larynx, the diphtheric membrane may cause airway obstruction.

questions.text: DNA expansion with repeats of CTG triplet sequence leads to which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disease caused due to triplet repeat expansion of DNA in the DMPK gene. The polynucleotide sequence involved in the expansion is the CTG sequence. This leads to an abnormal expression of myotonin protein kinase.

In the childhood form of DM, intellectual disability and behavioral problems are often the predominant features. Other key findings of classic DM include:

  • Myotonia or delay in muscle relaxation.
  • Weakness and atrophy of facial and distal limb musculature.
  • Cardiac abnormalities including cardiomyopathy and conduction disturbances.
  • Frontal hair loss, cataracts, insulin resistance.

 Other options:

Option B- Fragile X syndrome is caused due to trinucleotide repeats- CGG- in the FMR1 gene of the X chromosome.

Option C- Huntington’s disease is an autosomal dominant disease caused due to triplet expansion of DNA by the CAG sequence. Clinical features include dementia, loss of motor control and affective disorder.

Option D- Spinocerebellar ataxia is caused by triplet expansion of DNA by the CAG sequence. Clinical features include progressive ataxia and dysarthria.

questions.text: In cricothyrotomy, the incision is made on_____.
questions.solution:
In cricothyrotomy, the incision is made on the cricothyroid membrane.

Most laryngeal foreign bodies are arrested above the vocal cords, i.e. above the middle of the thyroid cartilage, and an effective airway can be established by piercing the cricothyroid membrane—a procedure called cricothyrotomy.

questions.text: In a civil negligence case against a doctor who bears the onus of proof?

choices.text: Police not under rank of  sub inspector

questions.solution:
In case of a civil negligence against a doctor, the burden of proof is on the patient.

The question of civil negligence arises when a suit is filed in a civil court:

  • By a patient or his/her relatives against the doctor for getting compensation from the doctor if he/she has suffered an injury due to the doctor's negligence.
  • By a doctor against the patient or his/her relatives to collect the fees, the payment of which has been refused due to alleged professional negligence by the doctor.

In either case, the patient has to prove that the doctor has committed professional negligence. To prove negligence, all the following four elements must be present:

  • Duty: A duty of care by the doctor must exist.
  • Dereliction: The physician must maintain the standard of a 'prudent physician' under similar circumstances. If the physician fails to maintain the standard of care, it is called dereliction.
  • Direct causation: The negligent act or omission must directly cause the injury without any intervening cause.
  • Damage: The negligent act must cause damage of a type that would have been foreseen by a reasonable physician.

questions.text: A neonate is brought with complaints of photophobia and watering. Clinical examination shows normal tear passages and a clear, but large, cornea as well as Haab’s striae. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of buphthalmos. Haab’s striae are horizontal/circumferential breaks in Descemet’s membrane seen in buphthalmos.

Buphthalmos (bull-like eyes) is an enlargement of the eyeball seen in true congenital and infantile glaucoma, usually when the disease onset is before 3 years.

The image given below shows Haab's striae and a child having buphthalmos in congenital glaucoma.

Note: 

Vogt's striae are vertical, fine, whitish lines (folds/tears) in Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.

The image given below shows Vogt's striae.

questions.text: Which of the following jugular venous pressure (JVP) waves corresponds to the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
The c wave of jugular venous pressure wave corresponds to the isovolumetric contraction phase in the cardiac cycle.

During isovolumetric contraction, the ventricles start contracting with valves closed. This leads to bulging of the tricuspid valve. This bulging increases pressure in the right atrium which is transmitted to the right internal jugular vein. This appears as a c wave in jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing.

JVP measured in the internal jugular vein (IJV) is a reflection of the right atrial pressure. IJV is preferred because it is not valved and is in direct line with superior vena cava and right atrium.

The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
  • c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
  • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening.

 The Wiggers diagram given below correlates JVP with other aspects of cardiac cycle. 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: Thirty minutes after a blood transfusion is started, the patient develops chills and severe flank pain. Temperature is 102.4 F and she begins bleeding around her IV catheter site. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR).

This patient presents with high-grade fever (102.4 F and chills), flank pain and features suggestive of DIC (bleeding around her IV catheter site), 30 minutes after transfusion was started. The time course and presentation is consistent with acute hemolytic reaction. The first step is to stop transfusion immediately and then collect blood samples for testing.

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR)

  • occurs within 24 hours of transfusion
  • fever, flank pain, hemoglobinuria, renal failure, and DIC
  • caused by ABO incompatibility, Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction
  • positive Direct Coomb's test, pink plasma
  • transfusion to be stopped immediately

The various blood transfusion reactions according to their time of occurrence are as follows:

  • Anaphylactic reaction - Within a few seconds to minutes of the transfusion
  • Allergic/Urticarial reactions - Within 2-3 hours of transfusion
  • Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) - Within 24 hours of transfusion
  • Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR) - Within 6 hours of transfusion
  • Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction (DHTR) - After 24 hours of transfusion

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

Immunological Transfusion Reactions             

Reaction
(Onset)

 Mechanism Presentation Management

Anaphylactic transfusion reaction

(Seconds-minutes)

Common in IgA deficient recipients 

Shock, respiratory distress, angioedema

Stop transfusion immediately, give epinephrine

Prevention – using IgA deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components

Allergic/ Urticarial transfusion reaction

(Within 2-3 hours)

Recipient IgE against donor components causing mast cell activation

Urticaria, flushing, pruritus

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction

(within 6h)

 

(Most common complication of blood transfusion)

Antibodies against donor WBC and HLA antigens (sensitization)

Cytokine accumulation during blood storage

More common in multipally transfused patients and multiparous women

Fever and chills sometimes with mild dyspnoea

Antihistamines and antipyretics

Transfusion can be stopped if symptoms are severe

Prevention: Leukoreduced products

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)

(1-6 hours)

Anti-HLA type 2 antibodies in donor plasma bind recipient WBCs, increase capillary permeability

Hypoxia, non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema

CXR: Bilateral interstitial infiltrates

Stop transfusion immediately

Supportive care

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction

(during transfusion to within 24h)

ABO incompatibility

(Type 2 hypersensitivity)

Pre-existing high affinity IgM antibodies rapidly induce complement mediated lysis, intra-vascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria

Fever, chills, flank/back pain

Sense of impending doom

Hemoglobinuria

DIC, Renal failure

Coomb’s test positive, pink plasma

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction

occurs after 24 hours ( usually 2 weeks )

Recipients have prior exposure to RBC antigens. After the transfusion, anamnestic response results in antibody production

Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis.

Mild fever, hemolytic anemia

Coomb’s test positive

Screening for new antibodies positive

Supportive care

Additional transfusions if needed

Non-immune mediated transfusion reactions are as follows:

  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Hypothermia
  • Electrolyte abnormality- hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia
  • Iron overload
  • Transient hypotension
  • Immunomodulation
  • Blood-borne infections

questions.text: Condyloma acuminatum is most commonly caused by _____.
questions.solution:
Condyloma acuminatum is most commonly caused by HPV 6 and 11. Condyloma acuminatum is a genital wart which is a moist, soft, pedunculated wart found on the external genitalia.

Related Pearl: Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) and Associated Lesions

HPV serotype Lesions
HPV 6 and 11
  • Condyloma acuminatum (genital warts)
  • Sinonasal papilloma
  • Squamous papilloma of the larynx
HPV 16
  • LSIL, HSIL, carcinoma cervix
  • Vulval carcinoma
  • Bowen disease (Carcinoma in situ of male external genitalia)
  • Oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma
HPV 18
  • LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma of the cervix
  • Carcinoma of the anogenital region
HPV 5 and 8
  • Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin in epidermodysplasia verruciformis patients
   

 

LSIL: Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

HSIL: High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of peripheral neuropathy and macrocytic anemia. She was given folate 5 mg and the blood picture improved. However, the neurologic manifestations were aggravated. What is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Treatment with folate unmasking pyridoxine deficiency
Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS
Folate therapy using the B12 stores

questions.solution:
The most likely cause is folate therapy which used up the B12 stores aggravating symptoms.

The patient presented with megaloblastic anemia. The most common causes include vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency. This patient has been empirically treated with folate supplements.

Administration of folic acid can partially reverse some of the hematologic abnormalities associated with vitamin B12 deficiency. However, the neurologic manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are not treated by folic acid.

Administration of folic acid to an individual with vitamin B12 deficiency can potentially mask untreated vitamin B12 deficiency or even worsen the neurologic complications. Hence, testing for and/or treatment of vitamin B12 deficiency is required in all patients being treated with folic acid.

questions.text:
Which of the following are oncofetal antigens?
  1. α-fetoprotein
  2. Carcinoembryonic antigen
  3. Human chorionic gonadotropin
  4. Placental alkaline phosphatase
  5. Immunoglobulins
questions.solution:
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) are oncofetal antigens.

Alpha-fetoprotein is a valuable clinical aid in diagnosis, prognosis, and monitoring of the following tumors:

  • Primary hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Non-seminomatous testicular germ cell tumors
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratomas
  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Yolk sac carcinoma
  • Germ cell tumors of the ovary and extragonadal germ cell tumors

Regenerated hepatic tissue following liver damage due to viral hepatitis, chemically induced necrosis, and liver surgery are associated with moderately raised serum AFP levels.

Carcinoembryonic antigen is normally detected in glycocalyx of fetal epithelial cells. It is useful in detection, assessing recurrence, and prognosis of the following tumors:

  • Adenocarcinoma of lung
  • Colorectal carcinoma

CEA levels >5 ng/dL are noted in ascites fluid associated with malignancy. Canalicular pattern for polyclonal CEA more sensitive for hepatocellular carcinoma, metastases in pancreatic adenocarcinoma and not sensitive for metastasis in bile duct adenoma.

Elevated levels are also present in the following non-neoplastic conditions:

  • Cirrhosis
  • Biliary obstruction
  • Hepatitis
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Smokers
  • Post-surgical bowel sequestration
  • Mucocele
  • Benign cysts may be positive for carcinoembryonic antigen

Related Pearl: Tumor Markers in Testicular Germ Cell

 

AFP

b-hCG

LDH

Seminoma

 -

+

++

Yolk sac tumor

+++

+

+

Choriocarcinoma

 -

+++

+

Embryonal carcinoma

+

+

++

Teratoma

 - 

 -

 -

 Note:

 Alpha-fetoprotein AFP:

  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Mixed germ cell tumor
  •  AFP is never raised in pure seminomas or pure choriocarcinoma

human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Seminoma
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the casualty following a fall on an outstretched hand. An x-ray of the patient is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of falling on an outstretched hand and the X-ray above showing a fracture in the distal part of the humerus with posterior dislocation of fracture fragment are suggestive of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. 

Supracondylar fractures are the commonest fractures in children younger than the age of 7 years. It typically occurs due to a fall on an outstretched arm. They can be of various types as listed below:

  • Posterior displacement of distal fracture fragment occurs commonly and is an extension type of fracture.
  • Anterior displacement of distal fracture fragment is less common and occurs due to a direct blow on a flexed elbow and is often unstable
  • Lateral condylar fractures are due to a varus force on an extended elbow and may extend through the unossified portion of the capitellum into the joint space.

Other options:

Option A: Cubitus varus deformity or gunstock deformity is a complication of supracondylar humerus fracture that occurs due to malunion. When the distal fragment unites with an excessive backward tilt, there is hyperextension at the elbow.

Option C: Dislocated radial head would present with a discontinuity in the line drawn along the shaft of the proximal radius (the line should normally pass through the capitellum). 

The image below shows an anterior dislocated radial head with calcification of the annular ligament:

Option D: Proximal humerus fractures are uncommon in children and will be pathological fractures (due to reasons such as the presence of a bone cyst).

The image below shows a radiograph showing a proximal humerus fracture with the involvement of the greater trochanter:

questions.text: A hypertensive pregnant woman presents with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum, and loss of fetal movements. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum, and loss of fetal movements in a hypertensive pregnant woman points to the diagnosis of placental abruption.  

Premature separation of a normally implanted placenta is placental abruption. Hypertension is a very important etiological factor in abruption. 

The hemorrhage into decidua basalis causes separation and compression of the placenta. This leads to a compromise of circulation to fetus, leading to fetal distress. The bleeding may escape through the cervix to cause external hemorrhage.

Clinical classification of placental abruption:

Grade 1 Grade 2 Grade 3
Vaginal bleeding is slight Vaginal bleeding mild to moderate Bleeding is moderate to severe or concealed.

Uterus irritable, minimal tenderness

 Uterine tenderness is always present Uterine tenderness is marked.
Maternal BP and fibrinogen unaffected Maternal pulse increased, BP maintained Shock is pronounced
FHS good Fetal distress present Fetal death is the rule
Maternal shock absent Maternal shock absent Associated coagulation defect or anuria may complicate

Other options:

Option B: Placenta previa presents with painless vaginal bleeding. Hypertension is not a predisposing factor. High-risk factors include multiparty, previous cesarean, or myomectomy scar in the uterus.

Option C: In preterm labor, fetal movements are not compromised.

Option D: Hydramnios does not present with bleeding PV.

questions.text: A patient with a suspected pulmonary embolism underwent a chest X-ray. It showed an enlarged right descending pulmonary artery.  What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
Enlarged right descending pulmonary artery on a chest X-ray in pulmonary embolism is called Palla’s sign.

The black pleura sign is seen in alveolar pulmonary microlithiasis. It refers to the shadow of the pleura between the extensive alveolar calcification and the adjacent rib cage.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most dangerous type of dehydration?
questions.solution:
Hypernatremic dehydration is the most dangerous type of dehydration.

Hypernatremia causes movement of water from brain cells into hypertonic extracellular fluid, causing brain cell shrinkage and shearing of blood vessels within the brain. This leads to central nervous system hemorrhages and thrombosis.

The fluid deficit in hypernatremic dehydration should be corrected slowly as rapid correction would cause rapid movement of water from the extracellular space into brain cells, leading to cerebral edema, seizures, brain herniation, and even death.

questions.text: Flask-shaped ulcers are characteristic of infection with _____.
questions.solution:
Flask shaped ulcers are characteristic of amoebiasis.

Amoebiasis is caused by Entamoeba histolytica and most often affects the cecum and ascending colon. Parasites may penetrate splanchnic vessels and embolize to the liver to produce amebic liver abscesses. 

Image: Flask-shaped ulcer of amebiasis.

Note: In typhoid, ulcers are oriented along the axis of the intestine (longitudinal ulcers). In TB, ulcers are perpendicular to the axis of the intestine (transverse ulcers). Both ulcers affect the ileocecal junction commonly.

questions.text: Identify the surgical step shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Capsulorrhexis is the step shown in the given image.

Capsulorrhexis is a method of anterior capsulotomy, where an opening is made in the anterior capsule of the lens. It is one of the steps involved in conventional extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE).

Continuous curvilinear capsulorrhexis (CCC) is considered to be superior to all the pre-existing methods because when done correctly, it does not leave any edges or tears. Trypan blue dye can be used to stain the lens capsule for better visibility.

In ECCE, a portion of the anterior capsule of the lens is removed, allowing extraction of the lens nucleus and cortex. This leaves the remainder of the anterior capsule, the posterior capsule, and the zonular support intact. The intact lens nucleus is then removed from the eye through a limbal incision. 

An anterior capsulotomy is followed by hydrodissection using a balanced salt solution. This helps to separate the corticonuclear mass from the capsule. Removal of lens nucleus and aspiration of the cortex is done using a two-way irrigation and aspiration cannula. An intraocular lens (IOL) is then implanted and the incision is then closed.

Some of the IOLs used are shown in the image below.

questions.text: What is the tell-tale sign of free radical injury?
questions.solution:
Lipochrome is a tell-tale sign of free radical injury and lipid peroxidation. It is also known as wear-and-tear pigment or lipofuscin.

It is an insoluble, brownish yellow, granular intracellular material. It accumulates in various tissues like the heart, liver, and brain with aging. The brown pigment in large amounts can give a characteristic appearance to the tissue called brown atrophy.

Given below is a histopathological image of cardiac muscle showing lipofuscin pigmentation.

questions.text: A child presented with a history of loose stools with an increase in frequency for 4 days. On examination, he is drowsy and unable to feed, with skin going back very slowly on pinching. As per Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI), this child will be classified as having _______.
questions.solution:
A clinical scenario of a dehydrated child who is drowsy and not able to feed with skin going back very slowly on pinching is suggestive of severe dehydration (as per IMNCI).

Diarrhea is defined as a change in consistency and frequency of stools that occurs more than 3 times a day. Diarrhea, if associated with blood in stools, is called dysentery. If the episodes subside within 7 days, it is called acute diarrhea. If it persists for more than 2 weeks, it is called persistent diarrhea.

Intestinal infections are the most common cause of acute diarrhea. Rotavirus and enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli are the major infectious causes of acute diarrhea. Other causes are certain drugs, food allergies, and systemic infections (e.g. urinary tract infection and otitis media).

The most important assessment in the evaluation of diarrhea is to look for the degree of dehydration. It is assessed as follows:

Parameters No dehydration Some dehydration Severe dehydration
Condition Well alert Restless, irritable Lethargic or unconscious, floppy
Eyes Normal Sunken Very sunken and dry
Tears Present Absent Absent
Mouth and tongue Moist Dry Very dry
Thirst Drinks normally
not thirsty		 Thirsty, drinks eagerly Drinks poorly or is not able to drink
Skin pinch Goes back quickly Goes back slowly Goes back very slowly
Treatment Plan A Weigh the patient, if possible,
and use treatment Plan B		 Weigh the patient and use treatment
Plan C urgently

Based on the degree of dehydration after history and examination, the
estimated fluid loss is calculated as follows:

Degree of dehydration Assessment of fluid loss
No dehydration less than 50 mL/kg
Some dehydration 50-100 mL/kg
Severe dehydration more than 100 mL/kg

The treatment plans A, B, and C are explained in the pearl below.

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

 

Plan B: For moderate dehydration, the amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

 

Plan C: For severe dehydration, treatment includes IV fluid administration.

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

questions.text: In the metabolism of vitamin D, where does the conversion of calcidiol to calcitriol occur?
questions.solution:
In the metabolism of vitamin D, the conversion of calcidiol (25-hydroxycholecalciferol) to calcitriol (1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol) occurs in the kidney.

Vitamin D metabolism occurs in 3 steps:

Step 1- Skin: 7-dehydrocholesterol (an intermediate in cholesterol synthesis that accumulates in the skin) undergoes a nonenzymatic reaction on exposure to ultraviolet light, yielding cholecalciferol, which is absorbed into the bloodstream. Note that 7-dehydrocholesterol and cholecalciferol already contain one hydroxy group.

Step 2- Liver:  Cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol. This is released into the circulation bound to a vitamin D–binding globulin, which is the main storage form of the vitamin.

Step 3- Kidney: 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol, the biologically active form by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase.

questions.text: The most common clinical form of actinomycosis is ________.
questions.solution:
The most common clinical form of actinomycosis is cervicofacial.

  • Actinomycosis is a chronic granulomatous infection characterized by indurated swellings, mainly in the connective tissue, suppuration, and discharge of “sulphur granules.” The most common causative agent is Actinomycetes israelii.
  • Various clinical forms of actinomycosis involves cervicofacial, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic actinomycosis.

questions.text: A  primigravida in her 10th week of gestation presents with spotting. On examination, the uterine size corresponds to 12 weeks. Transvaginal ultrasound was done and is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture along with the image is suggestive of a hydatidiform mole. The ultrasonography (USG) image shows the characteristic snowstorm appearance seen in a complete mole. It refers to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces.

Hydatidiform mole is an abnormal condition of the placenta, characterized by partly degenerative and partly proliferative changes in the villi. It is a gestational trophoblastic disease. Hydatidiform moles may be either partial or complete:

Classical clinical features of a complete mole:

  • Abnormal vaginal bleeding
  • Lower abdominal pain
  • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Features of early-onset preeclampsia
  • Uterus appears large for date
  • Absent fetal parts and FHS
  • Expulsion of vesicular tissues (grape-like vesicles)
  • Theca lutein cyst of ovaries of more than 6 cm
  • Hyperthyroidism (rare)
  • Serum hCG > 100,000 mIU/ml
  • USG - snowstorm appearance

The definitive management after diagnosis is suction and evacuation, after making the cervix favorable.

Other options:

Option A: Blighted ovum (silent miscarriage) occurs when a fertilized egg implants in the uterus but does not develop into an embryo. It is a sonographic diagnosis where there is an absence of a fetal pole in a gestational sac with a diameter of 3 cm or more.

Option B: Missed abortion is when the fetus is dead and retained inside the uterus for a variable period. USG shows an empty sac early in the pregnancy or the absence of fetal cardiac activity and fetal movements.

Option C: Ectopic pregnancy is one in which the fertilized ovum is implanted and develops outside the normal endometrial cavity. The majority of ectopic pregnancies occur in the fallopian tube, the ampulla being the most common site.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XXX or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: Identify the catheter:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a rubber catheter with a flower-shaped ending. This is a Malecot catheter. A Malecot catheter is never introduced per urethrally.

It is a self-retaining catheter with an umbrella or flower tip. It contains sulfur and, hence, is radio-opaque. It can be sterilized by boiling.

Uses:

  • Suprapubic cystostomy
  • Perinephric abscess
  • Pyonephrosis
  • Cabot’s nephrostomy
  • Subphrenic abscess
  • Cholecystotomy
  • Infected pseudocyst of pancreas
  • Amebic liver abscess
  • Gastrostomy

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the OPD with a skin lesion as shown in the image below. The lesions were initially small but have now spread to the entire limb and the abdomen. She has a history of long-standing diabetes and recurrent episodes of deep vein thrombosis despite anticoagulation therapy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image depicts necrolytic migratory erythema. This skin lesion along with a history of long-standing diabetes and recurrent deep vein thrombosis is suggestive of glucagonoma. Necrolytic migratory erythema is commonly associated with glucagon secreting pancreatic islet cell adenoma.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of glucaganoma: 4Ds

  • Diabetes – usually mild and not associated with ketoacidosis
  • Dermatitis – Necrolytic erythema migrans
  • Deep vein thrombosis
  • Depression

  • Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.
  • In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: All of the following are sources of infection of rabies except ________

choices.text: Direct contact of the infected saliva with the mucosa
Ingestion of raw meat of infected animal

questions.solution:
Ingestion of the raw meat of infected animal is not a source of infection of rabies.

Modes of transmission of rabies :

  • Scratch/deep bite by infected dog and bats is the main mode of transmission.
  • Transmission by direct contact of infected saliva with mucosa or fresh skin wounds of an uninfected individual.
  • Human–to–human transmission by bite has never been confirmed.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man, who is a known case of lung cancer, presents with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair. The following characteristic sign was found on examination. The most probable diagnosis is ________.
questions.solution:
The given image shows characteristic upper eyelid lilac erythema/heliotrope rash, which is pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.

The other features that further point to a diagnosis of dermatomyositis are as follows:

  • Age group 50-60 years
  • Proximal myopathy, which is manifested as difficulty in climbing stairs, getting up from chairs, lifting hands, etc.
  • Association with internal malignancy

The classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:

  • Facial rash
  • Eyelid erythema and edema
  • Nail fold changes
  • Gottron’s papules
  • Shawl sign which is macular erythema of the upper chest and back
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Flagellate erythema
  • Mechanic’s hands
  • Poikiloderma
  • Cutaneous calcinosis

The following images show Grotton's papules on hand and V-shaped rash, respectively:

questions.text: A patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy, and abdominal pain. He had an x-ray taken a few days ago, which is given below. Which of the following investigations would not be useful in arriving at a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the x-ray showing nephrocalcinosis is suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Angiography of renal arteries is not a useful investigation for hyperparathyroidism.  

Nephrocalcinosis occurs in this condition due to hypercalcemia. It decreases renal concentrating ability, which may cause polyuria and polydipsia.

Clinical features of hyperparathyroidism:

  • Bones:
    • Pathological fractures
    • Subperiosteal bone resorption - 2nd and 3rd digits, most common in the radial aspect
    • Salt and pepper skull
    • Osteitis fibrosa cystica or von Recklinghausen disease of bone
  • Stones
    • Multiple and recurrent renal stones - most common
    • Nephrocalcinosis
  • Abdominal groans
    • Colicky due to pancreatitis
  • Psychiatric overtones -
    • Raised PTH causing CNS depression and psychiatric symptoms
  • Band keratopathy
  • Features of hypercalcemia 
    • Vomiting
    • Confusion
    • ECG changes: increased PR interval, shortened QT interval

 The image given below shows salt-and-pepper skull seen in hyperparathyroidism.

Investigations done in primary hyperparathyroidism:

  • Ultrasonography of the neck is a safe and widely used technique for the localization of abnormal parathyroid glands.  
  • Nuclear medicine scanning with radiolabeled sestamibi is also a widely used technique. Sestamibi accumulates in parathyroid adenomas. This radionuclide is concentrated in the thyroid and parathyroid tissue but usually washes out of normal thyroid tissue in under an hour. It persists in abnormal parathyroid tissue.  
  • Dual-energy radiographic absorptiometry is a useful tool to demonstrate skeletal involvement in primary hyperparathyroidism.

The image given below shows a radiolabeled sestamibi scan.

questions.text: Which of the following is a special stain for melanin?
questions.solution:
Fontana-Masson is a special stain for melanin.

The Masson-Fontana stain is a histochemical method used to identify melanin pigment in tissues. This stain relies on the ability of melanin to reduce silver ions to metallic silver. The stain imparts a black color to melanin granules, allowing for their easy visualization under a microscope.

The Masson-Fontana stain is particularly useful for distinguishing melanin from other pigments such as hemosiderin, which requires a different staining approach (e.g., Prussian blue). It is commonly employed in diagnosing pigmented lesions, such as melanomas. Other methods of detection for melanin are Schmorl's method, DOPA oxidase method, bleaching techniques and formalin-induced fluorescence.

Image :  Masson Fontana stain of a metastatic deposit of malignant melanoma. The brown pigment stains black after staining

Other options:

Option B: Giemsa- A Romanowsky type 2 stain used for G banding, peripheral smears, H.pylori, mast cells. 
Option C: Gomori methanamine silver / GMS is used to stain fungi and for Pneumocystis jiroveci (carinii).  
Option D: Von Kossa is a special stain for calcium.

questions.text: Disinfecting action of chlorine on water is mainly due to ________
questions.solution: The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. It is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 –80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.

questions.text: Which of the following will be the most important prognostic indicator in patients with stage 1 melanoma?
questions.solution:
The best prognostic factor in primary stage 1 melanoma (T1N0) is the tumor thickness or depth of the melanoma. 

The presence of lymph node metastases is the single most important prognostic index for melanoma in general. But since there is no lymph node involvement in Stage 1 melanoma, the depth of the melanoma is the best prognostic factor.

 Other major prognostic factors, in order of impact on survival:

  • Presence of lymph node metastases
  • Ulceration
  • Age
  • Anatomic location of the primary tumor 
  • Gender

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has the following lesion over the face. He complains of bleeding while itching. The most likely diagnosis is ______.
questions.solution:
The image above shows a central ulcer with raised borders and rolled-out edges (rodent ulcer), suggesting a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma (BCC).

BCC is a slow-growing malignant tumor with locally invasive characteristics. It affects the pilosebaceous skin.

Ultraviolet radiation exposure is the strongest predisposing factor. Other risk factors include exposure to arsenic, coal tar, aromatic hydrocarbons, and ionizing radiation. 

BCC mainly affects elderly or middle-aged men with excessive skin exposure, commonly in the age group of 40–80 years and in white-skinned people.

Macroscopically, it is categorized as localized and generalized. Nodular, nodulocystic (nodular and nodulocystic together account for 90% of basal cell carcinoma), pigmented, and nevoid are the localized cancers, while superficial multifocal and superficial spreading, infiltrative, and cicatrizing are the generalized types. The nodular type is described as pearly waxy nodules at the margins. A central depression (umbilication) or ulceration and rolled-out edges are characteristic of BCC.

Sites near the eye, nose, and ear and of size >2 cm are considered to be high risk. Direct invasion at these sites can reach the cranium.

Management is by Mohs microscopic surgery. Non-surgical measures, such as the administration of topical 5-fluorouracil and imiquimod, are useful. Metastasis is extremely rare.

Histopathologic features show ovoid cells in nests with a single palisading layer. The outer layer of cells is in the active division, and thus, incomplete excision can lead to increased aggressiveness.

The below image shows the histopathology of BCC.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with fever, swelling of his hands after playing football, and frequent complaints of fatigue. He has a history of dactylitis. His peripheral blood smear is given below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the peripheral smear showing sickle-shaped cells is suggestive of sickle cell disease.

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to the point mutation in the β-globin gene, which results in the replacement of glutamate residue with valine. This causes the production of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS).

Factors that predispose to sickling are infection, dehydration, and acidosis.

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated.

Clinical features:

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice
  • Painful bone crisis - hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of the bones of hands and feet.
  • Acute chest syndrome - Typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Hyposthenuria- inability to concentrate urine.
  • The aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Spleen
    • In children- splenic sequestration crises occur which results in splenomegaly due to red pulp congestion.
    • Adolescence or early adulthood- autosplenectomy occurs due to splenic infarction, fibrosis, and progressive shrinkage.
    • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Haemophilus influenzae septicemia, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.
  • Other clinical features- priapism, leg ulcers, stroke, retinopathy, pigment gallstones, and growth retardation.

The diagnosis is suggested by the clinical findings, the presence of irreversibly sickled red cells on the peripheral smear, and hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2 and HbF and S spike. The changes in the skull resemble a crewcut in radiographic studies as a result of compensatory erythroid hyperplasia.

The image given below shows the sickling of RBCs in sickle cell disease.

The image given below shows Howell-Jolly bodies seen in asplenia.

Note: The sickle cell trait protects against falciparum malaria in certain African populations.

questions.text: Which of the following pathway is the most important source of reducing equivalents for fatty acid synthesis in the liver?
questions.solution:
The most important source of reducing equivalents (NADPH) for fatty acid synthesis in the liver is the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway (HMP).

Since HMP shunt pathway and fatty acid synthesis both occur in the cytosol of the cell, there are no membranes or permeability barriers against the transfer of NADPH. This NADPH is involved as a donor of reducing equivalents in both the reduction of the 3-ketoacyl and of the 2,3-unsaturated acyl derivatives. 

Other sources are:

  • Extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase (minor source)
  • Malic enzyme

questions.text: Most afferent fibers from the lateral geniculate body terminate in  ______ of the primary visual cortex.
questions.solution:
Most afferent fibers from the lateral geniculate body (LGB) terminate in the primary visual cortex in layer 4.

  • Both the magnocellular and parvocellular pathways from the LGB terminate in layer 4 of the visual cortex.
  • Only the interlaminar pathway terminates in layers 2 and 3.

questions.text: In the auditory pathway, which is the first structure that can determine the direction of the perceived sound?
questions.solution:
The superior olivary nuclei receive information from both ears and begin the process of detecting the direction from which a sound comes.

The lateral part of superior olivary nucleus does so by comparing the difference in intensities of sound reaching the two ears, whereas the medial part of the superior olivary nucleus detects the time lag between the signals entering the two ears.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presented with a vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus. Which functional area is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Broca's motor speech area is likely to be affected in the vascular injury of the inferior frontal gyrus.

A lesion in this region leads to motor/ Broca's aphasia. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted by many word-finding pauses. The speech is impoverished in function words that contribute to the syntax but is enriched in meaningful nouns and verbs. However, comprehension of speech is intact, and the patient knows what he wants to say.

For example, a patient with Broca's aphasia may say "walk dog" instead of "I want to take the dog for a walk".

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the casualty ward with a history of road traffic accident and head trauma. She opens her eyes to pain, moans, can localize her limb towards the pain stimulus on the left hand and away from the pain stimulus on the right hand and both the legs are in extended posture. Calculate her GCS.
questions.solution:
The GCS (Glasgow Coma Scale) of this patient is E2V2M5, which comes to a total score of 9.

  • E2 - Eye opens to pain
  • V2 - Moans
  • M5 - Localizes to pain on the left hand (the score represents the best performance elicited, which would be localized towards the pain stimulus)

The best possible score is 15; The worst possible score is 3.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal/flexion 4
Abnormal flexion/Decorticate posturing  3
Extension/Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

Half-hourly for 2 hours,
Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
Then 2-hourly thereafter.
Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who presented with features of tremors, palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities is diagnosed with Graves disease. Which of the following statements is true with respect to the report of the thyroid function test in Graves disease?

choices.text: Radioactive Iodine Uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal

questions.solution:
In Graves disease, the level of serum TSH is low, unbound T4 is high and serum T3 is high. 

Graves disease is caused by autoantibodies that bind to the thyrotropin receptor (TSHR-Ab), stimulating the growth of the thyroid and overproduction of thyroid hormone (T4 and T3). These hormones then cause negative feedback to the anterior pituitary and thus, decrease TSH levels.

In patients with thyrotoxicosis, including Graves disease, the radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours is characteristically elevated.

The evaluation of thyrotoxicosis is given in the flowchart below:

Related Pearl: Radioiodine uptake of thyroid gland

Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scans are interpreted as follows:

  • High (or normal) radioiodine uptake indicates de-novo synthesis of the hormone. Therefore, there is increased hormone synthesis
  • Low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates:
    • Inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue with release of the preformed hormone into the circulation
    • Extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone

Conditions with high and low RAIU are given below:

High RAIU Low RAIU
  • Graves’ disease
  • Toxic multinodular goiter
  • Toxic adenoma
  • Thyroid cancer
  • Hydatidiform mole
  • TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma

 

 

 
  • Acute phase of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis
  • Drug-induced— iodine, amiodarone-induced thyroiditis
  • Subacute/ Dequervain thyroiditis
  • Radiation thyroiditis
  • Metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma
  • Factitious (iatrogenic) thyrotoxicosis
  • Struma ovarii (extrathyroid source)
  • Hamburger thyrotoxicosis (exogenous source)

questions.text: A female patient at 33 weeks of gestation was diagnosed with severe preeclampsia. The patient was given MgSO4 at a loading dose of 14 g,  followed by 5 g intramuscularly every 4 hours in the alternate buttocks. Which regimen is being followed here?
questions.solution:
The regimen being followed here is Pritchard regimen.

Preeclampsia is a multisystem disorder of pregnancy characterized by hypertension and proteinuria.

Patients present with elevated blood pressure, proteinuria, thrombocytopenia, cerebral and visual symptoms, intrauterine growth restriction of the fetus, and pulmonary edema. Patients with severe preeclampsia eventually eclamptic convulsions.

Magnesium sulfate is an anticonvulsant used to manage severe preeclampsia and eclampsia. The following regimens are employed to administer magnesium sulfate.

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4 g (20% solution) intravenously over 3-5 minutes,
followed by 10 g intramuscularly
(5 g in each buttock)		 5 g (50%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttocks
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4 g IV slow over 15-20 minutes 1-2 g/h IV infusion

questions.text: Which of the following has the longest period of use?
questions.solution:
IUD Years of use
Progestasert 1
Cu-T-200 4
Nova T 5
LNG IUD 7-10
Cu-T-380 A 10

questions.text: A patient with carcinoma in situ of the urinary bladder is posted for intravesical BCG therapy. What is the strain of mycobacteria that will be used in this therapy?
questions.solution:
An attenuated strain of Mycobacterium bovis is used in intravesical BCG therapy.

Intravesical BCG is used for the treatment of non-invasive (no invasion into the muscle layer) urinary bladder tumors. It induces a strong local inflammatory response against the attenuated bacteria, which helps in the destruction of the tumor cells.

Option D: Mycobacterium indicus pranii is used to prepare the Mw vaccine, which is administered to multibacillary leprosy patients and their contacts. It is also used as an adjunct to chemotherapy for category II tuberculosis.

questions.text: The most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas is _____.
questions.solution:
• Pancreas divisum: Most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas
  • Annular pancreas: Annular pancreas is a band-like ring of normal pancreatic tissue that completely encircles the second portion of the duodenum. The annular pancreas can produce duodenal obstruction.
  • Ectopic pancreas: Pancreatic tissue that is aberrantly situated, or ectopic, is found in about 2% of careful routine postmortem examinations. The favored sites for ectopia are the stomach and duodenum, followed by the jejunum.

questions.text: A patient underwent parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism. One year post surgery, the following ECG changes were seen. What is the immediate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and ECG showing a prolonged QT interval (QT interval more than 0.43 seconds) is suggestive of hungry bone syndrome, i.e. hypocalcemia post parathyroidectomy. Acute symptomatic presentation of hypocalcemia is treated with IV calcium gluconate.

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia:

  • Mild circumoral or digital numbness
  • Paresthesia
  • Laryngeal spasms 
  • Cardiac arrhythmias 
  • Chvostek sign: This is elicited by gently tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear. There is hyperexcitability of the facial muscles, manifesting as a contraction of the muscles.
  • Trousseau's sign: This is elicited by making the forearm ischemic by applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure (SBP) for 5 minutes. The hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur’s hand position (shown in the image below).

Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia is an emergency and must be treated with

  • 10 mL of 10% calcium gluconate is given slowly through the intravenous route.
  • Calcium and vitamin D replacement is given orally.
  • Magnesium supplementation may also be required due to the synergistic actions of calcium and magnesium.

The continuous need for calcium or vitamin D, 1-year postoperatively is called permanent hypoparathyroidism.

questions.text: The most commonly affected joint in calcium pyrophosphate disease (CPPD) is ______.
questions.solution:
The knee is the joint most commonly affected in calcium pyrophosphate disease arthropathy (CPPD). Other sites include the wrist, shoulder, ankle, elbow, and hands.

Acute CPPD arthropathy is also known as pseudogout. It is commonly seen in the elderly and may be associated with conditions such as primary hyperparathyroidism, hemochromatosis etcetera. 

X-ray of the affected joint may reveal chondrocalcinosis, which represents calcium deposition in articular cartilage.

Diagnosis is established by detecting the presence of polarized light microscopy of the joint aspirate and demonstrating positively birefringent rhomboid crystals.

Related Pearl: Difference between Gout and Pseudo-gout

Gout

Pseudogout

Uric acid

Calcium pyrophosphate

Needle like

Negative

Weak positive

1st MTP

Knee

X-ray findings

Periarticular erosions with overhanging margins

Chondrocalcinosis

questions.text: What acid-base disturbance is seen in patients with renal tubular acidosis?

choices.text: Normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.
High anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
Normal anion gap  hypochloremic metabolic acidosis
High anion gap hypochloremic metabolic acidosis.

questions.solution:
In renal tubular acidosis (RTA), there is normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.

RTA refers to a group of disorders in which there is impaired tubular transport of H+ and/or HCO3- despite relatively well-preserved renal function. There are 4 types:

  • Type I - impaired H+ secretion (distal), leading to decreased HCO3- production
  • Type II - impaired HCO3- reabsorption (proximal)
  • Type III - carbonic anhydrase deficiency causing defects in the transport of both H+ and HCO3- (mixed)
  • Type IV - hypoaldosteronism (hyperkalemic)

The overall deficiency of HCO3- in all the types is compensated by Cl- secretion. Hence, the serum anion gap remains normal.
