questions.text: The lacrimal sac and nasolacrimal duct are derived from _______.
questions.solution:
The lacrimal sac and the nasolacrimal duct are derived from the ectoderm of the nasolacrimal groove (also known as naso-optic furrow). 

The deep furrow between the maxillary and lateral nasal prominence is known as the nasolacrimal groove.

  • The ectoderm in the floor of this groove becomes a solid epithelial cord and detaches from the overlying ectoderm.
  • This solid cord then canalizes to form the nasolacrimal duct. 
  • The lower end of the duct acquires a connection to the nasal cavity. 
  • The upper end of the duct widens to form the lacrimal sac.

questions.text: Jackknife position causes death due to ________.
questions.solution: Jackknife position is a position where the victim's thighs and knees are driven against the chest, causing indirect compression of the chest and restriction of breathing movements; remaining in this position for a long time leads to positional asphyxia.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented with symptoms of food impaction, dysphagia, and a burning sensation in his chest. Based on the barium swallow image given below, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium swallow image showing the feline esophagus sign are suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis.

Eosinophilic esophagitis is an idiopathic condition commonly affecting the proximal 1/3rd of the esophagus. Eosinophils migrate to the esophagus and contribute to extensive tissue damage and inflammation.  

Clinical features include difficulty in swallowing, food impaction, vomiting, heartburn, and symptoms similar to those of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Non-responsiveness to proton-pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy is often seen. 

Barium swallow shows the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus. These rings appear similar to stripes on a cat, and the appearance is referred to as the feline esophagus sign. It is thought to be due to contraction of the muscularis mucosae, with the resultant shortening of the esophagus and bunching up of the mucosa in the lumen.

On endoscopy, the esophagus appears narrow and friable with transient or fixed mucosal rings, strictures, and linear furrows. 

The diagnosis requires a biopsy with a histologic finding of >15–20 eosinophils per high-power field. An exclusion diet and steroids help in the management of this condition.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect. 

Related Pearl: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

 

Conditions Endoscopic findings
Infectious esophagitis Diffuse and involve the proximal esophagus  
HSV esophagitis Vesicles and small punched-out lesions (volcano ulcers)
CMV esophagitis Serpiginous ulcers
Peptic esophagitis Solitary and distal  
Eosinophilic esophagitis Multiple esophageal rings, linear furrows, or white punctate exudates (feline esophagus)
Pill esophagitis Singular and deep at points of luminal narrowing with sparing of the distal esophagus
Candida esophagitis White friable plaques, in advance form - adherent, grey-white pseudomembranes.

 

The image below shows the lesions of CMV esophagitis.

The image below shows the lesions of candida esophagitis.

The image below shows feline esophagus in eosinophilic esophagitis.

The image below shows the erosive lesion of pill esophagitis.

The image below shows the lesions of HSV esophagitis.

questions.text: The following diagram shows the depth of respiration of a 55-year old man who was diagnosed with sepsis. Identify the pattern of breathing.
questions.solution:
The pattern of breathing seen in the image is Kussmaul’s Breathing. It is a type of deep, rapid breathing usually implies metabolic acidosis, but can also occur with Ponto-mesencephalic lesions.

Other options:

Options A and B: Biot's breathing - The pattern of breathing is irregular and rapid with rhythmical pauses lasting for 10–30 seconds. It is also known as ataxic breathing is associated with increased intracranial pressure and meningitis.

Options D: Cheyne-Stokes Breathing - Characterized by progressively deeper and sometimes faster breathing (crescendo-decrescendo cycles), with periods of apnea. It is seen in patients with heart failure and uremia.

questions.text: When asked to give the Sims curette, you would pick:
questions.solution:
The instrument marked as 1 in the image is Sims curette. 

It is a single-ended uterine curette used for dilatation and curettage.

It is designed to remove tough tissue from the lining of the uterus for biopsy or excision. The curette features a sharp loop tip to aid in the removal of uterine tissue.

 The image above shows the trolley with various instruments:

  1. Sims uterine curette
  2. Hegar dilator
  3. Sims uterine sound
  4. Karman's cannula - It is used for menstrual regulation. It can be identified by the whistle-like tip.
  5. Leech Wilkinson's cannula
  6. Rubin's cannula 

Leech Wilkinson's cannula and Rubin's cannula are used in hysterosalpingography.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about cobalt-60?

choices.text: It is used for gamma knife surgery
It is used in high dose-rate brachytherapy

questions.solution:
Cobalt-60 emits beta particles and gamma radiation. It does not emit alpha particles.

Cobalt-60 is a radioactive metal commonly used in medical radiation therapy. Its mode of decay is via beta particles and gamma radiation. The half-life of cobalt-60 is 5.27 years.

Cobalt-60 isotope has traditionally been popular for teletherapy, although this use is decreasing. It has also been used in gamma knife surgeries. A newer use of the cobalt-60 isotope has been in the field of high-dose-rate brachytherapy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with a ​history of perianal pain is brought to the OPD. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine picrate. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The test done in the scenario is Barberio test. It is used to detect seminal fluid.

When saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Other options: 

Option B: Florence test: 

  • The suspected seminal stain is extracted with 10% hydrochloric acid and a drop of it is placed over a slide.
  • A coverslip is placed over it and a drop of Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water) is made to run under the coverslip.
  • If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately.

Option C: Takayama test (Hemochromogen crystal test): 

  • The test is used to detect suspected bloodstains. Small piece of suspected material is added on a glass slide.
  • Then, 2-3 drops of Takayama reagent is added and covered with a coverslip.
  • If it is a bloodstain, pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen or reduced alkaline hematin appear in a few minutes.

Option D: Teichmann test (Hemin Crystal Test): 

  • The test is used to detect suspected bloodstains.
  • Small piece of suspected material is placed on a glass slide. Then, 2-3 drops of glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride are added to the glass slide and covered with a coverslip. The slide is then heated.
  • If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of hemin or hematin chloride appear.
  • When hydrogen peroxide is added, the hematin crystals give bubbles of gas.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about triage?
questions.solution:
In triage, green signifies low priority or ambulatory patients and those with minor illnesses.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: The x-ray of a 7-year-old child diagnosed with scurvy showed the white line of Frankel. This would be best described as?

choices.text: Opaque radiologic shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification

questions.solution:
Calcified cartilage at metaphysis is known as the white line of Frankel, and it is seen in scurvy.

Scurvy results from ascorbic acid or vitamin C deficiency. Vitamin C is required for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline in procollagen. When it is deficient there is the defective formation of connective tissue and collagen in the skin, bone, cartilage, dentine, and blood vessels which leads to their fragility.

The clinical features are

  • Fatigue, irritability, loss of appetite
  • Loose and spongy gums along with loose teeth
  • Swollen joints
  • Perifollicular hemorrhages
  • Bleeding into the skin - ecchymosis, purpura, petechiae
  • Pseudoparalysis
  • Microcytic anemia (due to decreased absorption of iron from the intestine)
  • Scorbutic rosary - sharp, tender beading at the costochondral junctions.

Radiological findings in scurvy:

  • Frenkel's line - Zone of provisional calcification at the growing metaphysis is seen as a dense, white line called Frankel's line.
  • Pelkan spurs - These are metaphyseal spurs formed due to fractures manifesting at the cortical margins. 
  • Wimberger’s ring sign - The sclerotic rim around the epiphysis forms this appearance.
  • Trummerfeld zone. - Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line.

Related Pearl: Radiological features of scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent kidney stones. The microscopic examination of urine is shown below. What is the type of stone seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows a hexagonal crystal, suggesting cystine stones. These stones are a recurrent feature in patients with cystinuria.

Crystals in urine are usually associated with kidney stones. Crystals form in the urine depends upon a variety of factors including:

  • The degree of concentration of constituent molecules
  • The urine pH
  • The presence of inhibitors of crystallization

Calcium oxalate and uric acid crystals can sometimes be found in normal urine that has been left to stand, due to crystal formation ex vivo.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: A child on examination has Bitot’s spots. It belongs to the WHO class ______
questions.solution:
Bitot's spots belongs to WHO class X1 B.

WHO classification of Xerophthalmia

Primary signs

  • X1 A-Conjunctival xerosis
  • X1 B-Bitot’s spots
  • X2- Corneal xerosis
  • X3 A-Corneal ulceration (less than 1/3 of cornea)
  • X3 B-Corneal ulceration (more than 1/3 of cornea)

Secondary signs

  • XN-Night blindness
  • XF-fundal changes
  • XS-corneal scarring

questions.text: A Chinese woman brought her son to the clinic with the given finding. She gives no other significant history. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This Chinese patient has a unilateral blue-greyish hyperpigmented macule on his shoulder, which is suggestive of nevus of Ito.

It affects the acromioclavicular region and upper chest. It primarily occurs in Chinese and Japanese people.

It is rarer than nevus of Ota, which affects facial skin and sclera. It is distinguished from the nevus of Ota by its location in the area innervated by the posterior supraclavicular and lateral cutaneous brachial nerves.

Complications of nevus of Ota include meningeal melanocytoma of the brain, and malignant melanoma involving the meninges, choroid, iris, or orbit. In some rare cases, cutaneous melanoma can develop.

Pigment targeting Q‐switched laser systems is the treatment of choice.

 

Option A: Nevus of Ota is a blue-black macule usually present at birth. The conjunctiva, sclera, and skin supplied by the trigeminal nerve are the most common sites involved. They are present throughout life.

 

Option C : Nevus spilus is a congenital nevus presenting as a lentiginous macule that develops into multiple macules in a speckled distribution (image below).

Option D: Becker nevus is a hyperpigmented hairy patch. The shoulder, back, and proximal portion of the upper limb are the most common sites involved. Mostly seen in males before puberty. The image below shows a Becker nevus.

questions.text: Identify the surgical procedure shown below.
questions.solution:
The procedure illustrated in the image is Billroth II gastrectomy. Following resection, the distal end of the stomach is narrowed by the closure of the lesser curve aspect of the remnant. The greater curve aspect is then anastomosed, usually in a retro-colic fashion, to the jejunum.

Option A: In Billroth I gastrectomy, the lower half of the stomach is removed, and the cut end of the stomach is anastomosed to the first part of the duodenum.

Option C: Braun modification of classical Billroth II gastrectomy is Billroth II reconstruction with jejunojejunostomy.

Option D: Roux-en-Y gastrojejunostomy is a gastric bypass surgery where a loop of jejunum is anastomosed to a proximal gastric pouch.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman was brought to the casualty ward with a high fever and abdominal pain for the past 2 days. She has a history of inflammatory bowel disease. Her abdominal x-ray is shown below. Identify the true statement regarding this condition.

choices.text: It is defined as the dilatation of the transverse colon, with a diameter of  >6 cm
Emergency colectomy is the only treatment
It occurs as a complication of Crohn's disease
In 90% of patients, it resolves with conservative management

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the radiograph are suggestive of toxic megacolon. The true statement is that toxic megacolon is defined as the dilatation of the transverse colon to a diameter of more than 6 cm. It is usually associated with severe ulcerative colitis. It can be triggered by electrolyte imbalance and narcotics as they interfere with gut motility. 

Toxic megacolon may present with fever, abdominal pain, and abdominal distension. Bacterial infection with features of sepsis may also be seen. It can result in perforation. 

Abdominal radiography shows transverse or right colonic dilation of >6 cm and loss of haustrations.

It usually resolves with supportive treatment (correcting electrolyte imbalance, fluids, bowel rest) and medical therapy, which includes glucocorticoids, anti-inflammatory drugs, and antibiotics. However, an urgent colectomy is indicated in patients who do not show signs of improvement.

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) characterized by superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner.

The clinical features include abdominal pain, diarrhea, rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and passage of mucus. Other symptoms include anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fever, and weight loss.

Investigations show elevated levels of C-reactive protein, platelet count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, fecal calprotectin, and fecal lactoferrin. A colonoscopy reveals loss of typical vascular pattern, erythema, friability, and ulcerations. 

Extraintestinal manifestations associated with IBD include ocular features (episcleritis, uveitis), dermatological manifestations (erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum), rheumatological manifestations (arthropathies, sacroiliitis, ankylosing spondylitis), and primary sclerosing cholangitis.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria; the obtained x-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a homogenous and ground-glass-like calcification of the kidney, appearing like putty. In a patient with abdominal pain with sterile pyuria, the given image finding points towards a diagnosis of putty kidney.

The putty kidney is a characteristic finding of genitourinary tuberculosis (TB), specifically renal TB. It is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is, thus, always a secondary TB. There is either reinfection or reactivation of old TB.

Genitourinary TB is a cause of sterile pyuria. Diagnosis is confirmed by a tuberculin test or examination of at least 3 consecutive early-morning specimens of urine for acid-fast bacilli. The isolated bacilli are stained with a Ziehl-Neelsen stain and subsequently cultured.

CT is the most sensitive modality and the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications. CT urography is done to assess the various stages of renal TB and its manifestations, which are as follows:

  • Early: Papillary necrosis
  • Progressive:
    • Multifocal strictures.
    • Generalized or focal hydronephrosis.
    • Mural thickening and enhancement.
    • Poorly enhancing renal parenchyma.
  • End-stage:
    • Progressive hydronephrosis.
    • Amorphous dystrophic calcification that involves the entire kidney - putty kidney

Treatment involves short-course therapy with antitubercular drugs like pyrazinamide, isoniazid, and rifampicin. Partial nephrectomy, nephrectomy, or reconstructive surgery is often done.

Other options:

Option B: Nephrocalcinosis is the deposition of calcium in the kidney parenchyma or tubules, which is seen in hypercalcemia conditions like hyperparathyroidism. 

Option C: Staghorn calculus usually occurs in association with urinary infection with Proteus, Pseudomonas, and Staphylococcus and is not a cause for sterile pyuria. 

Option D: Psoas calcification is a muscle calcification and might be seen developing after acute renal failure and rhabdomyolysis.

questions.text: Which of the following is an antimetabolite?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate is an antimetabolite. It is a folic acid analog that inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). Methotrexate and its polyglutamate also inhibit the enzymes involved in denovo purine and thymidylate synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following organs is most radiosensitive to pelvic external beam irradiation?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, ovary is the most radiosensitive. 

The decreasing order of radiosensitivity is as follows: ovary >rectum > bladder >vagina.

Radiosensitivity is higher in cases where the proliferation is high. Since it is a reproductive organ, the ovary has a high number of clonal cells. Therefore, among the given options, the ovary is the most radiosensitive organ.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old G1P0 woman at 25 weeks of gestation presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 days. Her BP is 104/72 mmHg and PR is 72 bpm. There is generalized edema. Peripheral smear shows hemolysis. Laboratory test results are as follows:
Leukocyte count: 10,500/mm3
Platelet count: 62000/mm3
Hematocrit: 26%
AST: 90 IU/L
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is HELLP syndrome.

The typical presentation of right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, lab findings of thrombocytopenia, low hematocrit, and peripheral smear finding of hemolysis, point towards a diagnosis of  HELLP ( Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets) syndrome.

Although related to preeclampsia, hypertension and proteinuria may be absent or minimal in HELLP syndrome.

Tennessee criteria used in the diagnosis of HELLP syndrome :

  • Platelet count <1 lakh,
  • AST >70 IU/L,
  • LDH >600 IU/L

Risk factors for HELLP syndrome include

  • Preeclampsia
  • Abnormal placentation
  • Family history of HELLP syndrome
  • Elevated levels of fetal mRNA for FLT l (vascular endothelial growth factor rfi­ receptor 1) and
  • Multiparity
  • Maternal age >34 years
  • European descent
  • History of previous poor pregnancy outcomes

Laboratory evaluation in HELLP:

  • Complete blood cell (CBC) count: Thrombocytopenia, anemia with possible reticulocytosis
  • Coagulation studies: Normal prothrombin time, 50% may have prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time
  • Peripheral smear: Schistocytes, helmet cells, and burr cells secondary to microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Serum aspartate aminotransferase/alanine aminotransferase (AST/ALT) levels: Elevated secondary to liver dysfunction
  • Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level: Elevated secondary to liver dysfunction or hemolysis
  • Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN)/creatinine with acute renal failure
  • Bilirubin level: Increased secondary to hemolysis
  • Haptoglobin level: Decreased secondary to hemolysis
  • Fibrinogen levels: Low secondary to increased coagulation
  • D-dimer: Increased due to fibrinolysis/DIC

HELLP syndrome may lead to the development of DIC which manifests as increased fibrin split products and decreased fibrinogen levels.

Other options:

Disorder

 AST (SGOT) U/L Bilirubin (mg/dL)
Cholestasis of pregnancy Up to 200 1–5
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy 200–800 4–10
Hepatitis 2000+ 5–20

questions.text: What is the function of the proteasome?
questions.solution:
The proteasome is a cylindrical structure in the cytosol that degrades polyubiquitinated proteins. It has a central core with proteolytic enzymes. Proteins that are tagged by ubiquitin to be degraded enter the core through regulatory rings on either side of the cylinder.

Clinical relevance: It plays an important role in antigen presentation to T lymphocytes as it degrades viruses and other molecules to small peptides.

questions.text: The posterolateral bone grafting technique has been described for nonunion of fracture of _________.
questions.solution:
The posterolateral bone grafting technique has been described for nonunion of fracture of tibia.

  • This technique is recommended for tibial fractures with infection or extensive bone loss.
  • Reported rates of union after this procedure range from 80% to 97%, with an average time to union of 5 to 7 months.
  • Main advantage: It is a single, non-destructive procedure with a high degree of success.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the structural organization of proteins?

choices.text: Primary, secondary and tertiary structures are destroyed by denaturation
Secondary structure is stabilized by disulphide bonds
Secondary and tertiary structure depends upon amino acid sequence

questions.solution:
The tertiary structure is three dimensional is the right answer among the given options. Secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures are three-dimensional.
 
Structural organization of proteins:

Primary: a linear sequence of amino acids in the polypeptide chain

Secondary: Folded and geometrically ordered units of short segments of polypeptides; example alpha helix, beta-pleated sheets, loops, and bends

Tertiary: Secondary structures arranged into larger functional units

Quaternary: Different types of polypeptides arranged in a spatial manner

Other options

Option B: Protein denaturation results in the unfolding and disorganization of the secondary and tertiary structures without the hydrolysis of peptide bonds, which form the primary structure.

Option C: Hydrogen bond and Van der Waals interactions are involved in the stabilization of secondary structure (helix). Disulfide bonds stabilize the tertiary structure of proteins.

Option D: Primary structure depends upon the amino acid sequence.

questions.text: An intern is performing spirometry on a patient. He is asking the patient to do forceful expiration. Which of the following neurons predominantly fire during this activity?
questions.solution:
Ventral group of neurons fire, when forceful expiration is needed.

The dorsal group of neurons controls the normal inspiration and expiration.

Pneumotaxic center limits the duration of inspiration.

Respiratory center component

Pacemaker cells of spontaneous or automatic breathing

Overdrive mechanism

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented with high-grade fever, and purpuric rash as shown in the image below. CSF sample showed gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a purpuric rash seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram-negative diplococci. 

Pathogenesis and clinical features:

  • The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx by attaching to the epithelial cells with the help of pili. From nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteremia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection.
  • Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial hemorrhages. 
  • Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with obstructed labor and gross dehydration. Investigations reveal fetal demise. What will be the management?
questions.solution:
The best management in the above case is a cesarean section in a case of obstructed labor.

Management of obstructed labor:

  • IV fluids for dehydration
  • Antibiotics to prevent infection
  • Cesarean section to relieve obstruction; in case of a live fetus, immediate cesarean section is done.
  • Never wait and watch or use oxytocin in obstructed labor.

questions.text: What is the most common pulmonary manifestation of SLE?
questions.solution:
The most common pulmonary manifestation of SLE is pleuritis, with or without pleural effusion.

The most common manifestations of different systems involved in SLE are:

  • Musculoskeletal- arthritis and arthralgia
  • Skin- photosensitivity
  • Kidneys- proteinuria
  • Neurologic- cognitive impairment
  • Cardiac- pericarditis
  • Pulmonary- pleuritis
  • Hematologic- anemia

questions.text: Which of the blood vessels marked in the below image is the main arterial supply of palatine tonsils?
questions.solution:
The main arterial supply of tonsil is by the tonsillar branch of the facial artery, which is marked as "3" in the given image.

Other blood vessels marked in the image are 

1 - Descending palatine branch of the maxillary artery

2 - Tonsillar branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery

4 - Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery

Five arteries supply the tonsil:

  1. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (the main artery)
  2. Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery
  3. Ascending pharyngeal branch of the external carotid artery
  4. Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery
  5. Descending palatine branches of the maxillary artery

questions.text: A person has been bitten by the following snake. Which of the following options describes the symptoms classically seen in this snake bite?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows common krait, which is neurotoxic and shows classical symptoms such as muscle paralysis.

Clinical features of bites of Elapidae (cobras, kraits, mambas, coral snakes) present in a similar pattern. The local bite reaction is generally mild with oozing of bloodstained fluid. There is no burning sensation and swelling in the case of Krait bite but present in the case of Cobra bite.

However, their neurotoxic effects are prominent. Systemic symptoms appear after about 30 minutes. The patient feels sleepy, slightly intoxicated, weakness of legs, and is reluctant to stand or move. Nausea and vomiting are also seen. Cyanosis is very marked. Paralysis initially presents as ptosis and external ophthalmoplegia, which may appear within a few minutes after the bite or after some hours. Later, paralysis of the muscles of the face, palate, jaws, tongue, and neck can occur. Respiratory failure can occur due to airway obstruction at this stage or later due to paralysis of the intercostal muscles and diaphragm. 

Other options:

Option A: Anaphylaxis is seen in poisoning due to stiletto snakes. Other symptoms include pain, swelling, blisters and local lymph node enlargements.

Option B: Systemic bleeding such as intravascular hemolysis, ecchymosis and incoagulable blood is seen in bites due to back fanged snakes.

Option C: Myoglobinuria is seen in poisoning due to sea snakes.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of snake venom

  • severe
  • edema and necrosis

Anticoagulant effect - widespread bleeding

  • Krait

Local reaction

  • mild

Neurotoxicity leads to muscle paralysis

Hydrophidae (Sea snakes) are now considered subfamily of elapidae

questions.text: M’Fadyean reaction is shown by ________.
questions.solution:
M'Fadyean reaction is shown by Bacillus anthracis.

Bacillus anthracis is a gram-positive rod with square ends giving it a characteristic box car appearance/ bamboo stick appearance.

When blood films containing anthrax bacilli are stained with polychrome methylene blue for a few seconds and examined under the microscope, amorphous purplish material is noticed around the bacilli. This represents the capsular material and is called M'Fadyean reaction.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom of severe dehydration?
questions.solution:
A thirsty child signifies some dehydration, not severe dehydration. 

In severe dehydration the child is:

  • Drowsy, lethargic or unconscious
  • Drinks poorly or not able to drink
  • Sunken eyes
  • Skin pinch goes back very slowly

questions.text: What is the first investigation you would advise for a patient with a large thyroid swelling?
questions.solution:
Assessing the biochemical function of the thyroid i.e. thyroid function test (TFT) is the first investigation done in any thyroid condition.

Assessment of TSH, T3, and T4 levels is done. However, TSH is most helpful in determining the management plan, especially in patients with thyroid nodules who clinically appear to be euthyroid.

Modalities for evaluation of thyroid swelling include

  • Laboratory evaluation
    • TSH
    • T3
    • T4 
  • Thyroid imaging
    • Ultrasound
    • Radioisotope scanning
    • CT/MRI
  • Biopsy techniques
    • Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB)
    • Tru-cut/core-needle biopsy

questions.text: A man accidentally poured overheated water over himself while bathing. A few hours later, he developed the given lesion on his shoulders and chest. Following spontaneous rupture 3 days later, the base of the lesion is erythematous and blanches on touch. What is the time taken by these wounds to heal?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image are suggestive of second-degree superficial burns. They usually heal with minimal scarring in 10–14 days unless they become infected.

Second-degree burns are divided into two types: 

  • Superficial dermal burns are erythematous and painful, blanch to touch, and often blister. They heal in 10–14 days.
  • Deep dermal burns involve the reticular dermis, appear more pale with erythmatous regions, do not blanch to touch, but remain painful to pinprick. They heal in 4–8 weeks.

Related Pearl: Degrees of Burns

  First-degree Second-degree superficial (partial-thickness) Second-degree deep (partial-thickness)

Third-degree (full thickness)

 Fourth-degree (full thickness)
Depth Epidermis Epidermis + superficial dermis Epidermis + most of the dermis (most skin appendages destroyed) Entire dermis + subcutaneous tissue Involves connective tissue, muscle, possibly bone
Colour/texture Red Red, edematous, and blistered Pale, mottled Hard, leathery Pale, dry, charred
Blanchable (capillary refill)  Yes Yes No No No
Pain Painful Painful Painful (only on pinprick) No No
Healing 5-10 days; no scar 10-14 days; no or minimal scar  4-8 weeks, often with scarring and contractures Prolonged, with scarring and contractures, requires skin grafting Requires skin grafting or even amputation.

questions.text: The dissection of the inguinal canal reveals the structure marked A. Which of the following is the content of the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
The structure marked A represents the spermatic cord. The genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve is the content of the spermatic cord.

The spermatic cord is a structure that passes through the inguinal canal in males. The inguinal canal is a natural passageway between the muscle layers of the anterior abdominal wall in the region of the groin. It transmits the spermatic cord in males, the round ligament of the uterus in females, and the ilioinguinal nerve in both sexes.

The contents of the spermatic cord include:

  • Cremaster muscle fibers
  • Testicular artery and accompanying veins
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Vas deferens
  • Cremasteric vessels
  • Lymphatics
  • Processus vaginalis

Coverings of the spermatic cord from inside to outside are:

  • Internal spermatic fascia from fascia transversalis
  • Cremasteric fascia
  • External spermatic fascia from external oblique aponeurosis 

An injury to the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve results in loss of sensation in the skin of the scrotum of males, and loss of sensation of the mons pubis and labia majora in females.

Other options:

Option A: Iliohypogastric nerve is not the content of the spermatic cord/ inguinal canal. It carries the sensory supply from the suprapubic area.

Option B: Ilioinguinal nerve is not the content of the spermatic cord but it is the content of the inguinal canal. It supplies somatic sensation to the skin of the upper and medial thigh. In males, it also innervates the root of the penis and upper scrotum. In females, it innervates the mons pubis and labia majora.

Option C: Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve is a content of the femoral canal. It carries sensory supply to the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament.

The image given below shows nerves related to the inguinal region.

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal and spermatic cord contents

Inguinal canal contents:

Male Female
  • Spermatic cord  (with genital branch of genitofemoral nerve)
  • Ilioinguinal nerve
  • Round ligament of the uterus 
  • Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve
  • Ilioinguinal nerve

Spermatic cord contents:

  • Three arteries:
    • Testicular artery
    • Deferential artery
    • Cremasteric artery
  • Two nerves:
    • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
    • Sympathetic nerve fibers
  • Three other structures:
    • Ductus deferens
    • Pampiniform plexus of veins
    • Lymphatic vessels

questions.text: Photostress test is used to differentiate between _______.
questions.solution:
Photostress test is used to differentiate between diseases involving the macula and those involving the optic nerve.

In this test, one eye is covered and the patient is asked to read the smallest line on the near chart. A bright light is then shone into the eye for 15 seconds, and the patient is asked to read the line again; the time taken to recover is noted. The test is repeated with the other eye.

In normal persons and in patients with optic nerve disease, the recovery time is not affected. However, in patients with macular disease, the recovery time is prolonged and is usually more than one-third of the normal recovery time. This is because, in macular disease, the photoreceptors are damaged, and there is a delay in the visual pigment regeneration process.

questions.text: A child in your unit is admitted with acute bronchiolitis. Which of the following is the most common etiological agent responsible for this condition during infancy?
questions.solution:
Acute bronchiolitis is predominantly a viral disease in children younger than 2 years. Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is the most likely etiological agent and is responsible for more than 50% of cases.

Acute bronchiolitis refers to airway inflammation and obstruction of the lower respiratory tract.

Clinical features of bronchiolitis include fever, cough, fine inspiratory crackles, expiratory wheezes, and breathing difficulty. Cyanosis may be seen in severe cases.

Radiographs may be normal in some patients. In the majority of them, there will be interstitial infiltrates, hyper-expansion of the chest, and peribronchial thickening. 

Management is mainly conservative. Hypoxemic children should receive cool, humidified oxygen. Rarely, a child might develop respiratory failure and require hospitalization and invasive ventilation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and neck swelling, as shown in the image below. The swelling increases in size on coughing and on performing the Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the swelling, a gurgling sound is heard. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is laryngocele.

The given clinical scenario of hoarseness of voice, cough, neck swelling that increases in size on coughing/Valsalva maneuver and a gurgling sound heard on pressing the swelling are suggestive of laryngocele.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling in the neck due to dilatation of the saccule. It is more commonly seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to a raised transglottic air pressure in these people. It can be divided into internal, external, or combined types of laryngocele.

  • Internal laryngocele is limited within the larynx and appears as a distension of the false cord and aryepiglottic fold.
  • External laryngocele has a distended saccule that herniates through the thyrohyoid membrane and appears as a swelling in the neck.
  • Combined or mixed laryngocele has both internal and external laryngoceles as its components.

Given below is a diagrammatic representation of laryngocele.

Laryngocele presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and airway obstruction (if large). External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck that increases in size on coughing or performing Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the neck swelling, a gurgling sound is heard indicative of a positive Bryce's sign. Adult laryngoceles can be associated with carcinoma.

Diagnosis is based on an indirect laryngoscopy and CT scan. CT scan reveals the extent of the lesion.

Treatment: Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization and surgical excision is done through an external neck incision for external laryngocele.

Other options:

Option A- Thyroglossal cyst is a midline cystic swelling usually affecting younger children. This swelling moves along with tongue protrusion as the thyroglossal duct is attached to the foramen cecum at the base of the tongue. 

The below image shows a patient with a thyroglossal cyst.

Option C: Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum in which the pharyngeal mucosa is herniated through the Killian's dehiscence (a weak area between the 2 parts of the inferior constrictor). Dysphagia is the predominant feature with a gurgling sound produced on swallowing. 

The below image shows the Zenker's diverticulum on the barium swallow. 

Option D- Cystic hygroma occurs due to obstruction of the jugular lymph sac. It is most commonly seen in the posterior triangle of the neck. More than 90% of the cases occur before the age of 2 years. It can result in stridor, respiratory difficulty, or feeding problems. The below image shows cystic hygroma in a child.

questions.text: Beta hCG is structurally similar to which biochemical moiety?
questions.solution:
The Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) has a biological activity similar to that of Luteinizing Hormone (LH).

hCG is a glycoprotein produced by syncytiotrophoblast. It is made up of α and β subunits. Though the α subunit of hCG is similar to the α subunits of LH, FSH, and TSH, the β subunit has structural similarity to LH only. Hence, LH is a better answer than FSH. 

hCG is primarily luteinizing and luteotrophic. It appears to act on the same receptor as that of LH. The function of hCG is to prevent regression of the corpus luteum. It can be detected in blood as early as 6 days after conception and forms the basis of various tests used to identify pregnancy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man who had witnessed a terrorist attack has been experiencing frequent intrusive flashbacks and nightmares about the incident. He avoids the places that remind him of it. He is significantly distressed, has difficulty falling asleep, and frequently feels anxious. He has had these symptoms for the last 6 months. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with re-experiences (flashbacks and nightmares), avoidance of the stimuli associated with the attacks, and hyperarousal (impaired sleep and anxiety) for more than one month is suggestive of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

PTSD is a psychiatric disorder characterized by increased stress and anxiety occurring after a stressful or traumatic event (e.g., witnessing or being involved in violent accidents, crime, war, assault, kidnapping, natural disaster, life-threatening illness, physical or sexual abuse). 

The predisposing factors for this condition include

  • Presence of childhood trauma
  • Borderline, paranoid, dependent, or antisocial personality disorder traits
  • Inadequate family or peer support system
  • Female gender
  • Genetic susceptibility to psychiatric illness
  • Recent stressful life changes
  • Recent excessive intake of alcohol

Symptoms of PTSD can be divided into four types:

  • Intrusion symptoms
    • Flashbacks - The individual may act and feel as if the traumatic event is reoccurring. 
    • Nightmares of the event
  • Hyperarousal 
    • Increased startle response
    • Insomnia
    • Hypervigilance
    • Difficulty concentrating
    • Reckless and self-destructive behavior
    • Irritability and anxiety
  • Avoidance symptoms:  
    • Avoiding memories, thoughts, and feelings of the event
    • Avoiding external reminders of the traumatic event
  • Negative cognitions and mood associated with the traumatic event
    • Inability to remember an important aspect of the traumatic event
    • Feelings of depersonalization and derealization
    • Anhedonia
    • Negative emotional state - fear, horror, anger, guilt, or shame

The duration of these symptoms should be for >1 month to label it as PTSD.

Psychotherapies found to be effective for PTSD include exposure therapy, trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization, and abreaction. SSRIs may be prescribed as first-line treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Adjustment disorder is an emotional response to stressful situations like financial issues, medical illnesses, or relation­ship problems that develop within 3 months of the stressor. The stressor in adjustment disorder can be of any severity. In adjustment disorder, the individual does not experience intrusive symptoms like flashbacks and nightmares, hyperarousal symptoms, and avoidance symptoms.

Option B: Acute stress disorder presents with the same symptoms as PTSD, but the symptoms usually occur immediately after the trauma and persist for a period of 3 days to up to 1 month after the trauma.

Option C: Persistent complex bereavement disorder occurs after the death of a loved one. Since the death, for 12 months or more, the individual may experience persistent yearning/longing for the deceased, intense sorrow and emotional pain, as well as a preoccupation with the deceased and the circumstances of the death.

questions.text: Which of the following does not increase the secretion of gastric acid?
questions.solution:
All of the given options  increase gastric acid secretion except serotonin.

Serotonin is localized in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa and within neurons of the GI tract. Serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion. It stimulates the production and release of gastric and colonic mucus. Serotonin acts as an enteric neurotransmitter and increases intestinal motility.

The main factors that stimulate gastric secretion are acetylcholine, gastrin, and histamine. Parasympathetic stimulation releases Ach which stimulates the secretion of

  • pepsinogen by peptic cells
  • hydrochloric acid by parietal cells
  • mucus by mucous cells.

Both gastrin and histamine strongly stimulate acid secretion by parietal cells but have little effect on other cells.

The stomach mucosa has two important types of tubular glands:

  • The oxyntic (gastric) glands secrete hydrochloric acid, pepsinogen, intrinsic factor, and mucus.
  • The pyloric glands secrete mainly mucus for protection of the pyloric mucosa from the stomach acid. They also secrete the hormone gastrin.

Note- Serotonin released from the small intestine triggers vomiting by stimulation of 5HT3 receptors. Therefore, 5HT3 antagonists like ondansetron are used as antiemetics.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not reduce mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF)?
questions.solution:
Digoxin does not reduce mortality in patients with HFrEF.

The drugs which reduce mortality in patients with HFrEF are :

  • ACE inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)
  • Angiotensin receptor neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI)
  • Beta blockers
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists
    • Spironolactone
    • Eplerenone
  • Hydralazine + isosorbide dinitrate

Beta-blockers Used as first-line therapy  

Spironolactone

Eplerenone

 Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists - first-line drugs for symptomatic heart failure.
SGLT-2 inhibitors Used as 1st line therapy- reduces mortality and morbidity
Sacubitril/Valsartan Neprilysin inhibitor/ARB(ARNI)
Ivabradine Inhibitor of If current in the sinoatrial node

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents with a 2-day history of fever and joint pain. She had a sore throat 3 weeks back for which she did not seek medical help. Which of the following is not a component of the criteria used for the diagnosis of this child's condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute rheumatic fever (ARF). Erythema nodosum is not a component of Jones criteria, which is used for the diagnosis of ARF. Erythema marginatum is a major manifestation of the Jones criteria. It is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.

The image below shows erythema marginatum.

Related Pearl: Revised Jones criteria for diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF)

Revised Jones criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever are as follows:

Major criteria
Low-risk populations* Moderate- and high-risk populations*
   
Carditis- Clinical or subclinical Carditis- Clinical or subclinical
Arthritis- Polyarthritis only Arthritis- Polyarthritis/polyarthralgia/monoarthritis
Chorea Chorea
Erythema marginatum Erythema marginatum
Subcutaneous nodules Subcutaneous nodules
   
Minor criteria 
Polyarthralgia Monoarthralgia
Fever (≥38.5°C) Fever (≥38°C)
ESR ≥60 mm in the first hour and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL ESR ≥30 mm/hr and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL
Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) 
   
For all patient populations with evidence of preceding Group A Streptococcal infection:(Increased ASLO/ anti-DNAse B titer or positive throat culture for group A streptococcus or positive rapid streptococcal carbohydrate antigen test) 
Diagnosis of initial ARF 2 Major criteria or 1 major plus 2 minor criteria
Diagnosis of recurrent ARF 2 Major or 1 major and 2 minor or 3 minor criteria

*Low-risk populations are those with ARF incidence ≤2 per 100 000 school-aged children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of ≤1 per 1000 population per year. If the incidence exceeds the given limit, then it is moderate-high risk populations.

Related Pearl: Skin rashes (Erythemas)

Erythema marginatum is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Erythema nodosum is an acute, nodular, erythematous, painful eruption, occurring probably due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a variety of antigens. Lesions are usually seen over the extensor aspects of the legs. Its causes include infections (tuberculosis), autoimmune (IBD and sarcoidosis), idiopathic.

 

Erythema migrans has a bull's-eye appearance (central erythema and necrosis) and is seen in Lyme disease.

 

Erythema multiforme lesions usually have a target appearance; it is mediated by the deposition of immune complexes in the superficial microvasculature of the skin and oral mucosal membrane. It is usually triggered by certain infections (herpes simplex virus) and drugs.

questions.text: A patient with severe asthma was given a new drug called mepolizumab. This drug is a monoclonal antibody against:
questions.solution:
Mepolizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IL-5.

IL-5 plays a pivotal role in eosinophilic inflammation and is also involved in eosinophil survival and priming.

Mepolizumab is approved in highly selected (eosinophilic phenotype) patients with severe asthma.

Monoclonal antibodies against IL-5 approved for asthma are:

  • Mepolizumab
  • Reslizumab
  • Benralizumab

questions.text: A researcher wants to study the HLA complex. What chromosome is it located on?
questions.solution: HLA complex of genes is located on the short arm of chromosome 6 (chromosome 6p21).

questions.text: What percentage of drug given will be left in the body after 3 half-lives, If the drug is eliminated by first order kinetics?
questions.solution:
The percentage of drug given will be left in the body if the drug eliminates by first-order kinetics after 3 half-lives is 12.5%.

In first-order kinetics, the rate of elimination of the drug is directly proportional to the drug concentration.

The rate of clearance remains constant.

Half-life Elimination (%) Drug left in the body(%)
First 50  50
Second 75  25
Third 87.5  12.5
Fourth 93.75  6.25

Related Pearl: First order Vs Zero order kinetics of drugs

First order

Zero order

Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

Clearance remains constant

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

Half-life remains constant

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

questions.text: A young child was brought in after she was sexually assaulted and raped.  What would the condition of the hymen be in this patient?

choices.text: Ruptured since it is superficially situated
Ruptured since it is very thin
Unruptured since it is deeply situated
Unruptured since it is highly elastic

questions.solution:
In the case of a young child, the hymen is deeply situated and usually intact after intercourse.  

In children, the hymen is deeply situated, and as the vagina is very small, it is impossible for the penetration of the adult organ to take place.

In children, there are a few or no signs of general violence, as the child is unaware of the assault and incapable of resisting. A few indicators for routine enquiry are pain on urination and/or defecation, abdominal pain, inability to sleep, sudden withdrawal from peers/adults, feelings of anxiety, nervousness, helplessness, weight loss, and feelings of ending one’s life.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient with history of hepatitis and behavioral changes is known to have an inborn error of metabolism. Ocular examination of this patient shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows Kayser-Fleischer ring, which is seen in Wilson’s disease.  

Kayser-Fleischer ring (KF) ring:

  • KF ring is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea
  • Characteristically observed in Wilson's disease but is not pathognomonic
  • Does not interfere with vision
  • Present in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms
  • Present only in 30–50% of patients diagnosed in the hepatic or presymptomatic state, therefore the absence of KF rings does not exclude the diagnosis of Wilson's disease

Wilson's disease:

This autosomal-recessive disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase.

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Behavioral disturbances
  • Wing beating tremor
  • Ophthalmic characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • KF ring 

Diagnosis:

    • Presence of KF rings
    • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
    • Elevated hepatic copper levels detected in liver biopsy
    • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

The gold standard for diagnosis: Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays

Treatment: A drug regimen of trientine and zinc is the first choice for treating mild hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease.

Recommended drugs in Wilson's disease:

Disease Status First Choice Second Choice
Initial    

Hepatitis or cirrhosis without decompensation

 Zinc Trientine
Hepatic decompensation    
Mild Trientine and zinc Penicillamine and zinc
Moderate Trientine and zinc Hepatic transplantation
Severe Hepatic transplantation Trientine and zinc
Initial neurological/Psychiatric Tetrathiomolybdate and zinc Zinc
Maintenance Zinc Trientine
Presymptomatic Zinc Trientine

questions.text: The most common complication of pathological myopia is_____.
questions.solution:
Macular degeneration is the most common complication of myopia, followed by rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.

Complications of pathological myopia include the following:

  • Macular degeneration
  • Retinal detachment
  • Complicated cataract
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Choroidal hemorrhage
  • Strabismus fixus convergence
  • Primary open-angle glaucoma, which is not a complication, but reported to occur in association with pathological myopia

questions.text: An elderly patient admitted to the ICU with multiple comorbidities developed exposure keratitis and ulceration. An ophthalmology opinion was sought. On fundoscopy, the resident found the following picture. What is this most likely due to?
questions.solution:
The given image suggests a diagnosis of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

The hallmark of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is neovascularization. Abnormal new vessel formation, which occurs on the inner (vitreous) surface of the retina and may extend into the vitreous cavity, can cause vitreous hemorrhage. Neovascularization is often accompanied by pre-retinal fibrous tissue, which, along with the vitreous, can contract, resulting in traction retinal detachment. In addition, tiny microaneurysms can also be seen.The treatment available for proliferative diabetic retinopathy is photocoagulation of the ischaemic areas to reduce the metabolic demand and decrease or prevent the release of vasoproliferative factors.

Stages and fundus picture in diabetic retinopathy:

Background Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • Microaneurysms 
  • Dot and Blot hemorrhages 
  • Exudates

Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (indicates progressive retinal ischemia):

  • Intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities
  • Venous changes (such as beading)
  • Cotton wool spots
  • Deep retinal hemorrhages

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • NeoVascularization of the optic Disc (NVD)
  • NeoVascularization Elsewhere in the periphery of the fundus (NVE)

Advanced Diabetic Eye Disease:

  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: The establishment bearing the following logo would provide services aimed at ______.
questions.solution:
The Suraksha Clinics are for management of sexually transmitted diseases and patients are given color-coded kits.

The kits are

  • Kit 1– grey, for urethra discharge, painful scrotal swelling, and cervicitis.
  • Kit 2– green, for vaginitis
  • Kit 3– white, for genital ulcers
  • Kit 4– blue, for genital ulcers.
  • Kit 5– red, for genital ulcers.
  • Kit 6– yellow, for lower abdominal pain
  • Kit 7– black, for inguinal bubo.
  • Kit 8– brown, for anorectal discharge

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

questions.text: The most consistent and persistent feature of bladder carcinoma is ____.
questions.solution:
The most consistent and persistent feature of carcinoma bladder is painless hematuria.

Bladder tumors classically produce painless hematuria and, sometimes, as the only clinical manifestation. Frequency, urgency, and dysuria occasionally accompany the hematuria.

Patients with diffuse tu­mors or tumors at the bladder neck may present with irri­tative urinary symptoms. When the ureteral orifice is involved, pyelonephritis or hydronephrosis may follow.

Late presenta­tion with a large tumor mass may cause urinary obstructive symptoms, a palpa­ble suprapubic mass, or lower extrem­ity edema, whereas metastatic disease may present with weight loss and/or lo­calized bone pain.

questions.text: Administration of ______ vaccine can result in paralysis.
questions.solution:
• A rare event following vaccination with OPV is vaccine-associated paralytic poliomyelitis.
  • Acute-onset flaccid paralysis occurs within 4 to 30 days of receipt of the vaccine in these cases or within 4 to 75 days after contact with a vaccine recipient.

Vaccine

Neurologic events like encephalitis

Measles/MMR

Febrile seizures, arthralgia, thrombocytopenia

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes with complaints of progressive weakness as the day progresses. He is found to have antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Which is the most common ocular finding in this disease?
questions.solution:
Ptosis is the most common ocular feature in myasthenia gravis (MG).

The cranial muscles, particularly the lids and extraocular muscles (EOMs), are typically involved early in the course of myasthenia gravis; ptosis and diplopia are common initial complaints.

If weakness remains restricted to the EOMs for 3 years, it is likely that it will not become generalized. These patients are said to have ocular MG.

Diplopia is frequently vertical. A pseudo-internuclear ophthalmoplegia may be seen. Patients with stable deviations may benefit from muscle surgery, botulinum toxin injection or a combination of both.

Nystagmoid movements may be present on extremes of gaze.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following tumors are best treated with radiotherapy?
questions.solution: Patients diagnosed with seminoma are best treated with radiotherapy, as it is a highly radiosensitive tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media?
questions.solution:
Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media.

Tuberculosis of the ear is usually secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. It presents as a painless condition, with foul-smelling discharge from the ear. Multiple perforations in pars tensa of the tympanic membrane and pale granulations in the middle ear cleft are seen.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presented with complaints of pain in the right leg right for a day. He has a history of recurrent episodes of atrial fibrillation. Which of the following statements are false regarding his condition?

choices.text: Ischemia beyond 6 hours is usually irreversible
Pain, pallor, pulselessness, and paresthesia/anesthesia are characteristic
Movement of the digits is not affected
Embolectomy and thrombolysis are treatment options

questions.solution:
The patient most likely has acute arterial occlusion and atrial fibrillation can predispose to emboli formation. In acute arterial occlusion, the movement of the digits will be affected, and the limb will be cold. However, in venous occlusion, muscle function is not affected.

The leg is often affected with

  • Pain
  • Pallor
  • Paralysis
  • Loss of pulsation
  • Paresthesia (or anesthesia).

Embolic arterial occlusion is an emergency that requires immediate treatment. Ischemia beyond 6 hours is usually irreversible and results in limb loss.

The diagnosis can be made clinically in a patient who has no history of claudication and has a source of emboli, who suddenly develops severe pain or numbness of the limb, which becomes cold and mottled.

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady comes with abnormal uterine bleeding. Hysterectomy was performed, and the following specimen was retrieved. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The specimen is that of a leiomyoma.

The uterine body/corpus is enlarged and deformed. The cut surface shows multiple nodules, well-circumscribed, firm, greyish-white, with a whorled appearance formed by the intersecting bundles of brown muscle fibers and white fibrous tissue. Leiomyomas can also present bleeding areas, cystic degeneration, and calcifications. The uterine cavity is compressed.

Leiomyoma:

Leiomyoma or fibroid uterus are slow-growing, benign tumors of the uterus that affect women of reproductive age. They occur due to smooth muscle proliferation in response to estrogen and progesterone produced by the body. 

Conditions with hormone excess such as reproductive age group, hyperestrogenism, pregnancy, and oral contraceptives are associated with increased growth of fibroids. 

Fibroids are formed in the intramural (interstitial), submucous, and subserous parts of the uterus. They can also form in the extrauterine structures such as round ligament, uterosacral ligament, vagina, and vulva. 

Patients usually present with menorrhagia, metrorrhagia, infertility, recurrent abortions, pain, pressure symptoms, abdominal mass, and vaginal discharge. However, many women are asymptomatic. 

Fibroids can undergo secondary changes such as atrophy, calcareous degeneration, and red degeneration.

questions.text: A woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of amenorrhea for the past year. She has a history of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome. 

When postpartum hemorrhage causes vascular thrombosis of the pituitary vessels, it causes panhypopituitarism. This condition is known as Sheehan's syndrome. It may present acutely as pituitary apoplexy, an endocrine emergency.

It can also present late with the following features:

  • Lactation failure - due to prolactin deficiency
  • Amenorrhea - due to anovulation caused by reduced gonadotropin activity
  • Hypothyroidism - due to decreased TSH secretion 
  • Adrenal insufficiency - due to low ACTH

Option B: Rotor syndrome is a type of hereditary hyperbilirubinemia with autosomal recessive inheritance. Affected individuals have mild jaundice and hyperbilirubinemia. 

Option C: Prolactinoma or pituitary adenoids is the condition of hyperprolactinemia diagnosed by a prolactin level >200 μg/L. It usually presents with infertility, amenorrhea, and galactorrhea.

Option D: Acromegaly is characterized by the signs and symptoms pertaining to excessive growth hormone secretion.

questions.text: A 25-year-old construction worker sustained an injury to his neck after falling from the tenth floor of a construction site. The first aid team that rushed to his rescue log-rolled him. According to  ATLS, what is the minimum number of people required for log-rolling this patient?
questions.solution:
The 10th edition of ATLS recommends at least 4 people for the safe maneuver of log-roll in trauma patients.

  • The first person is assigned to restrict the motion of the head and neck.
  • The second person is positioned on the same side of the patient’s torso. This person manually prevents segmental rotation, flexion, extension, lateral bending, or sagging of the chest or abdomen while transferring the patient.
  • The third person is responsible for moving the patient’s legs.
  • The fourth person removes the backboard and examines the back.

Note: In a patient known to have a fracture of the extremities, a minimum of 5 people are required to safely perform the log-roll maneuver.

questions.text: A medical student is studying about the double Bohr effect. This occurs in which of the following types of circulation?
questions.solution:
The double Bohr effect occurs in placental circulation.

The Bohr effect explains the shift of the oxygen hemoglobin association curve with respect to changes in the PCO2 and H+ levels.

The production of CO2 increases as the metabolic activity of tissues increases. This CO2 diffuses into the blood and in turn, raises the blood H2CO3 and causes an increase in the H+ concentration and a decrease in pH.

This decreases the affinity of Hb for O2, shifting the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve to the right. This facilitates the delivery of O2 in the tissues. This effect of PCO2 and pH on the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve is called the Bohr Effect.

Conversely, in the lungs, CO2 diffuses from the blood to the alveoli, the H+ concentration decreases, and the O2 hemoglobin dissociation curve shifts to the left increasing the affinity of Hb to O2.

Oxygen–hemoglobin dissociation curve (OHDC) of fetal blood and maternal blood move in opposite directions. 

In the placenta, the fetal blood entering the placenta carries large amounts of carbon dioxide, but most of it diffuses from the fetal blood into the maternal blood. This loss of CO2 makes a reduction in H+ that leads to a shift of OHDC to left. This enhances the uptake of oxygen by the fetal blood from the maternal blood. 

The increase in CO2 in maternal blood makes it more acidic. This results in releasing of oxygen from the maternal blood to the fetal blood due to the shift of OHDC to right. 

The above two effects make the Bohr shift twice in the placenta as it is for oxygen exchange in the lungs, and it is called the double Bohr effect.

questions.text: A 40-year-man presents with hematuria, polyuria, and hypertension. The resected kidney is as seen below. All are associated with this condition, except ________.

choices.text: Cysts in liver, pancreas, and spleen

questions.solution:
Clinical history of hematuria, polyuria, and hypertension and gross image together suggest that the patient has autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). They are not associated with hepatic fibrosis. 

However, patients with autosomal recessive (childhood) polycystic kidney disease have congenital hepatic fibrosis.

ADPKD:

  • Autosomal-dominant disorder
  • Multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys that ultimately destroy the renal parenchyma and cause renal failure
  • 40% have one to several cysts in the liver (polycystic liver disease)
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms arise in the circle of Willis, subarachnoid hemorrhages
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Mutations in PKD1, encoding polycystin 1, and PKD2, encoding polycystin 2
  • Cysts arise from the tubules throughout the nephron and, therefore, have variable lining epithelia
  • Occasional cysts have been reported in the spleen, pancreas, and lungs

Extra-renal cysts in autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD):

  • Hepatic cysts
  • Pancreatic cysts
  • Seminal vesicle cysts
  • Arachnoid membrane cysts

There is a three-fold increase in the incidence of bronchiectasis in ADPKD patients.

Note:

There are very few case reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but an association between ADPKD and those cysts are not proved. No other literature other than Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 9th ed mentions about cysts in the lungs.

Reference: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/extrarenal-manifestations-of-autosomal-dominant-polycystic-kidney-disease#H13

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

questions.text: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shows the caudal regression sequence/sacral agenesis. The maternal condition that can give rise to this condition in the baby is pregestational diabetes. It is the most specific anomaly seen in diabetes.

Poorly controlled diabetes, both preconceptionally and in early pregnancy, is thought to cause this malformation. HbA1c levels correlate with the malformations. Instead, a macrosomic infant is commonly seen in gestational diabetes.

Other options:

Option B- In gestational diabetes, the risk of fetal anomalies is not increased. This is due to the absence of metabolic disturbance during organogenesis

Option C- Valproate leads to neural tube defects and not sacral agenesis.

Option D- ACE inhibitors can cause oligohydramnios.

questions.text: A man presents with pain and swelling of right knee joint since one week. His ankle joint and feet also started paining since past 2 days. He gives history of diarrhea 4 weeks ago. He also complains of the following lesions on his soles. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of acute arthritis following a recent infection and additive pattern (involvement of new joints within few days) and examination finding of keratoderma blennorrhagica (image) are suggestive of reactive arthritis. 

Keratoderma blennorrhagica is a mucocutaneous manifestation of reactive arthritis. It presents as vesicles and pustules that lead to hyperkeratotic lesions or crusting on the palms and soles.

Other mucocutaneous manifestations of reactive arthritis include:

  • Oral ulcers - superficial, transient, and often asymptomatic
  • Circinate balanitis - consists of vesicles that rupture to form painless superficial erosions on the glans penis

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is not formed after post-translational modification?
questions.solution:
Selenocysteine, the 21st amino acid, is formed by co-translational modification. It is coded by the UGA codon, which is normally a stop codon. The protein synthetic apparatus can identify a selenocysteine-encoding UGA by the presence of the selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS) in the untranslated region of mRNA.

Selenocysteine is present at the active site of several human enzymes that catalyze redox reactions such as thioredoxin reductase, glutathione peroxidase, and deiodinase.

Impairment in human selenoproteins have been implicated in tumorigenesis and atherosclerosis and are associated with selenium deficiency cardiomyopathy (Keshan disease).

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling and tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox after sustaining a fall onto an outstretched hand. Identify the cast given below that was used to manage the patient's injury.
questions.solution:
The cast applied to a patient in the glass-holding position is known as the scaphoid cast/glass-holding cast. It is used to treat scaphoid fractures.

To apply a scaphoid cast, the wrist is held in slight dorsiflexion and the thumb is in abduction and slight flexion, as if a glass is being held between the index finger and thumb. It extends from just below the elbow to just proximal to the metacarpal necks of the digits. On the thumb, the cast extends to just proximal to the interphalangeal joint.

Scaphoid fracture presents with pain and swelling over the radial aspect of the wrist. A fall on an outstretched hand could result in such a fracture. The fracture can be confirmed (when an x-ray does not show a fracture) if there is pain elicited in the anatomical snuff box on the radial border of the wrist.

An oblique x-ray of the wrist should be able to show a scaphoid fracture.

 Scoliosis

questions.text: The largest part of cerebellum is:
questions.solution:
The largest part of the cerebellum is the middle lobe, also known as the posterior lobe.

The cerebellum consists of two hemispheres (right and left) joined by a median vermis. It is divided into three lobes:-

  • Anterior lobe - lies superiorly above the primary fissure.
  • Middle lobe - lies inferiorly below the primary fissure. It is the largest lobe. It is also called the posterior lobe.
  • Flocculonodular lobe - lies posterior to the uvulonodular fissure.

The cerebellum also has two surfaces - superior and inferior separated by a horizontal fissure. It is connected to the other parts of the central nervous system via three peduncles-

  • Superior cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the midbrain
  • Middle cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the pons
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the medulla oblongata

questions.text: In laryngeal cancer, hoarseness of voice results from______.
questions.solution:
• Hoarseness in glottis Ca is early because lesions of cord affect its vibratory capacity. 
  • Hoarseness in supraglottic and subglottic cancer indicates spread of disease to:
    • Vocal cords with infiltration of thyroarytenoid muscle or
    • Involvement of recurrent laryngeal nerve or
    • Cricoarytenoid joint involvement.
  • Though this is a late feature, it is usually present at first presentation since patients usually come late.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate definition of stress?

choices.text: The body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain

questions.solution: According to the WHO, stress can be defined as any type of change that causes physical, emotional, or psychological strain. Stress is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action. Everyone experiences stress to some degree.

questions.text: While doing a subclavian venous catheterization, the patient developed sudden desaturation, and on examination of the chest, hyper-resonance was noted in the apical area of the right lung. What is the most likely diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
A common complication of subclavian vein catheterization is pneumothorax, which is the possible diagnosis in this case since there is hyper-resonance and sudden desaturation. 

The most common complication of a central line insertion is an arterial puncture.

Complications of central vein catheterization:

  • Arterial puncture - This is the most common complication. 
  • Cardiac tamponade is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle.
  • Pneumothorax - Injury to the underlying pleura may lead to pneumothorax. This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization.
  • Chylothorax can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common.
  • Injury to the associated nerves like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords.
  • Thromboembolism, leading to venous thrombosis; pulmonary embolism is more common with femoral veins.
  • Infections

Central venous catheterization is the insertion of the catheter into a large central vein. The veins preferred largely depend on the underlying disease in the patient, the clinical setting, and the expertise of the doctor. 

The internal jugular vein is preferred when the patient has

  • Bleeding diathesis - Bleeding from this vein can be easily detected and can be controlled with pressure. 
  • Pneumothorax - The lesser risk of injury to the lung
  • Needs cardiac pacing - right internal jugular vein is used.

Femoral or subclavian veins can be used in patients when the neck is immobilized using a cervical collar.

The below image shows a central vein catheter.

The below image shows subclavian vein catheterization.

The below image shows catheterization of the jugular vein.

Below image shows a radiograph of subclavian vein catheterization.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the middle ear cleft?
questions.solution:
The cochlea is not a part of the middle ear cleft.

The middle ear cleft is a single functional unit for the conduction of sound from air into the inner ear fluids. It is made up of 3 distinct anatomic parts:

  • Middle ear/tympanic cavity
  • Mastoid air cells
  • Eustachian tube
