questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV-positive​ patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is oral candidiasis.

Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that can be scraped off and it develops over the tongue, lips, gum, or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae.

It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include high levels of glucose, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics.

It is treated with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole or fluconazole.

Other options:

  • Option B: Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by Epstein Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue and cannot be scraped off.
  • Option C: Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions.
  • Option D: Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudomembrane covering the tonsils and pharynx.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Menopause?

choices.text: Premature menopause is before the age of 38
Menopause setting after 55 years is delayed menopause
Average age of menopause is 47 years

questions.solution:
Menopause seting before the age of 40 is termed as premature menopause.

Other features of menopause :

  • The average age of menopause is 47 years. (Option D)
  • The range of menopause age is 45 to 50 years. 
  • Menopause setting after 55 years is delayed menopause. (Option C)
  • Menopause sets in when follicle number falls below 1000.
  • Menopause age is not related to age at menarche, race, number of pregnancy, socio-economic status, or oral contraceptive pills.
  • Menopause is directly related to smoking and genetic disposition. 
  • Smoking induces premature menopause. (Option A)

questions.text: The incision preferred during autopsy in case of asphyxial death due to neck compression is?
questions.solution:
The incision preferred in the case of asphyxial death due to neck compression is the modified Y-shaped incision.

In strangulation, hanging, and any condition where the larynx might be damaged, modified Y-shaped incision is to be preferred, as the skin of the upper neck can then be dissected off the mandible and raised clear to give a wide approach to the neck structures.

Y-Shaped Incision: Commences at anterior axillary fold on the chest on either side, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at xiphisternum in the midline and then run downwards as in I-shaped incision to the symphysis pubis. It is preferred in females. It is more cosmetically accepted as the incision and the stitches are minimally seen after the autopsy. 

Modified Y-shaped incision: An incision is made in the midline from the suprasternal notch to the symphysis pubis. The incision extends from suprasternal notch over the clavicle to its center on both sides and then passes upwards over the neck behind the ear. Indicated in cases of strangulation or death due to compression of the neck. 

I-Shaped Incision: Extends from symphysis mentii to symphysis pubis taking curve towards left around the umbilicus. It is used routinely in practice. It is simple and convenient.

Elongated X-shaped Incision: This is a special incision used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries, which are usually missed where superficial imprints are faint, particularly when present on skin not overlying bone. This is helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death and should be practiced in cases of custodial death.

Note: This MCQ has been revised for factual accuracy. For a detailed explanation about the incisions, refer to the link - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539901/ .

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for rescue analgesia?
questions.solution:
Fentanyl is the drug of choice for rescue analgesia.

Rescue analgesia involves the use of medications to minimize postoperative pain. Mild pain can be controlled with oral analgesics, but severe pain requires opioids like fentanyl.

Fentanyl is preferred over morphine or oxycodone due to its rapid onset of action, lesser incidence of postoperative nausea, vomiting, and other adverse effects.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought with recurrent episodes of blood in his stool. Meckel’s diverticulum is suspected. Which of the following can be used to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tc-99m pertechnetate scanning is used to confirm the diagnosis of Meckel's diverticulum.

Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital anomaly of the gastrointestinal tract, resulting from incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct during embryonic development. It is a true diverticulum, meaning it contains all layers of the intestinal wall (mucosa, submucosa, and muscularis).

Rule of Twos:

2% prevalence.
2 feet from the ileocecal valve.
2 inches in length.

Other uses of Tc-99m pertechnetate include

  • Thyroid imaging
  • Parathyroid imaging for distinguishing from the thyroid gland
  • Testicular imaging
  • Gastric emptying studies; intestinal and rectal functional studies

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy with a known diagnosis of sickle cell disease presents with fever and painful swelling of hands and feet. Which of the following is the drug of choice to prevent painful crisis in sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution:
Hydroxyurea is the drug of choice for the prevention of painful crisis in sickle cell anemia.

Hydroxyurea is a myelosuppressive agent that is effective in reducing the frequency of painful episodes, rate of hospitalization, and requirement for blood transfusion. It is safe and well-tolerated in children and infants.

Other options:

Option A: Hydrocodone is used in the treatment of pain crisis in sickle cell anemia.

Option C: Corticosteroids are one of the first-line drugs for acute idiopathic thrombocytic purpura (ITP) with risk factors for bleeding.

Option D: Ruxolitinib is the drug of choice for the treatment of polycythemia vera.

questions.text: According to the WHO Labour Care guidelines, which among the following is recommended during the second stage of labor?

choices.text: Guard the perineum during delivery of the fetal head
Never give warm compress to the perineum

questions.solution:
According to the WHO Labour Care guidelines, guarding the perineum during delivery of the fetal head is recommended during the second stage of labor to prevent a perineal tear.

The fingers of one hand support the perineum, while the second hand applies pressure to the fetal head to control the speed of crowning.

 

The following are the guidelines to be followed in the second stage of labor according to the recent WHO Labour Care guidelines:

  • In order to reduce perineal trauma and facilitate spontaneous birth, manual massage and warm compression of the perineum are recommended during the second stage of labor based on a woman’s preferences and options available. 
  • Routine use of episiotomy is not recommended for women undergoing spontaneous vaginal birth.
  • For women with/without epidural analgesia, the adoption of a birth position of the individual woman’s choice, including upright positions, is recommended.

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle does the demographic gap start increasing?
questions.solution:
The demographic gap starts increasing and attains maximum level during the early expanding phase.

The demographic gap refers to the difference between birth rates and death rates within a population, leading to changes in population size and age structure.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text: What is the Battle sign?
questions.solution:
Battle sign refers to the retroauricular or mastoid ecchymosis that typically results from a fracture of the middle cranial fossa, following head trauma. It is prominent when there is a fracture of the petrous temporal bone. 

 An image showing Battle sign is given below:

Related Pearl: Signs of base of skull fracture

Signs of Base of Skull Fracture

  • Bilateral periorbital haematoma (raccoon eyes)
  • Battle’s sign (bruising over mastoid)
  • CSF rhinorrhoea or otorrhoea
  • Haemotympanum or bleeding from ear

questions.text: A male had a vasectomy 1 month ago and the couple asks the doctor if they have to take any precautions while having sex. What advice should be given?

choices.text: Oral contraceptive pills for 1 month for the woman
Hormonal treatment given for 2 more months for the man

questions.solution:
The best advice is to use condoms for 3 months as the sperms are stored in the reproductive tract for upto 3 months. 

Vasectomy

  • Vasectomy consists of dividing the vas deferens and disrupting the passage of sperms.
  • It is done through a small incision in the scrotum, under local anesthesia. The sterility is not immediate. The sperms are stored in the reproductive tract for up to 3 months. The couple must therefore abstain from intercourse during this period or use other methods of contraception.
  • Approximately, 20 ejaculates clear the semen of all sperms. Two semen analysis reports must confirm the absence of sperms before the man can be declared sterile.
  • No-scalpel technique has been now adopted. One single incision is made with a special forceps, and skin stitch is not required. Clips and plugs can be applied over the vas instead of cutting. Vasectomy is cheaper than tubectomy

questions.text: A patient requires the shortest acting formulation of insulin to prevent postprandial hyperglycemia. Which of the following formulations would you choose?
questions.solution:
Inhaled insulin is the shortest-acting formulation of insulin.

questions.text: A patient was brought in after a road traffic accident and was suspected to have a vertebral fracture. Which of the following is a characteristic difference between a typical cervical and thoracic vertebra?

choices.text: Cervical vertebrae have longer spinous processes
Thoracic vertebrae  foramina are bigger than the body
Thoracic vertebrae have tubercles on transverse processes

questions.solution:
Typical cervical vertebrae are characterized by a foramen in the transverse process called the foramen transversarium. This foramen transversarium transmits the vertebral artery and vein, along with a branch from the cervicothoracic ganglion (vertebral nerve). 

Foramen transversarium is not present in typical thoracic vertebrae. 

Feature Typical cervical vertebrae Typical thoracic vertebrae
Vertebral body Smaller and thinner

Intermediate in size between cervical and lumbar

Costal facets for the ribs seen on either the vertebral body, the transverse process, or both
Vertebral foramina Larger and wider than the vertebral body Smaller than the size of the vertebral body
Transverse processes Small and have transverse foramen, and 2 tubercles (anterior and posterior) Longer, larger, and stronger; no transverse foramina 
Spinous processes Horizontally behind the body and usually bifid (C1-C5) Longer and slender; terminates in a distinct tubercle

 The images given below illustrate a typical cervical and thoracic vertebrae, respectively.

The anterior tubercle of the 6th cervical vertebra is the longest and is known as the carotid tubercle of Chassaignac. The carotid artery can be compressed against the groove formed by the anterior tubercles and the vertebral bodies.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a component of CHADS2-VASc score?
questions.solution:
Age > 60 years is not a component of the CHADS2-VASc score. Age > 75years and age group 65-75 yrs are the two age criteria considered in the score.

The CHADS2-VASc score is used to assess the risk of stroke in patients who have atrial fibrillation. Anticoagulation therapy is given when the score is ≥2. Patients with a score of 1 may also be considered for anticoagulation therapy.

Anticoagulation therapy is given for all the patients of AF having mitral stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, or a history of stroke.

Related Pearl: CHA2DS2-VASC scoring for risk of stroke & need for oral anticoagulation in AF

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy is rushed to the ER after having choked on a bone while eating. He is responsive but unable to speak. What is to be done next?
questions.solution:
In a choking child (more than 1 year old) or an adult, the first step to be done is to perform Heimlich maneuver, which involves delivering abdominal thrusts.

The rescuer should stand or kneel behind the patient and wrap his arms around the patient’s waist. A fist is made with one hand and using the other hand, the fist is driven into the patient’s abdomen with a rapid, forceful upward thrust so as to dislodge the foreign body. This is continued until the foreign body is expelled or if the patient becomes unresponsive.

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

 

In a choking infant who is responsive, 5 back slaps between the shoulder blades and 5 downward thrusts on the chest are given in order to dislodge the foreign body.

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

questions.text: In Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON), the defect is______.
questions.solution:
In Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON), the defect is a mutation of maternal mitochondrial DNA. It is transmitted by maternal inheritance.

Clinical features:

  • It typically affects males between the ages of 15 and 35 years.
  • It causes bilateral, subacute painless loss of vision.
  • Pupillary light reflex is relatively preserved until the late stage of disease.
  • Optic neuritis in one eye is followed by the involvement of the other eye.
  • Optic atrophy in one eye is followed by involvement of the other eye
  • Centrocecal scotoma
  • The diagnosis of LHON should be considered in any patient with bilateral optic neuropathy, irrespective of age.
  • LHON plus refers to rare variants with additional manifestations such as neuromuscular dysfunction.
  • Prognosis is poor, although some visual recovery may occur in a minority of cases even years later.
  • The condition cannot be controlled by drugs since it is genetically controlled.

questions.text: A scientist is conducting a sleep study. He induced a volunteer into slow-wave sleep. Which of the following would be seen on the EEG of this volunteer?
questions.solution:
In slow wave sleep (Stages 3 and 4 of NREM), delta waves predominate the EEG.

Related Pearl: Stages of Arousal and Sleep

Stage

EEG

Awake, alert with eyes open

Beta rhythm(14-30 Hz)

Awake, relaxed with eyes closed

*Mainly alpha rhythm (8–13 Hz)

* Changes to the beta rhythm in response to internal or external stimuli.

Relaxed drowsiness

*Fatigued & tired

*The head droops,momentary lapses of attention

*Sleepy but not asleep

Decrease in alpha-wave amplitude and frequency

NREM 1 (N1) (5%)

*Light sleep-easily aroused by moderate stimuli or even by muscle jerks

*Continuous lack of awareness

*Mixed frequency waves  (predominantly 2-7 Hz).

*Gap in alpha rhythm is filled with theta (4–8 Hz) and delta (slower than 4 Hz) activity

*Vertex waves

NREM 2 (N2) (50-60%)

Predominant theta activity (4-7 Hz)

*Deep sleep

*Arousal only with vigorous stimuli

sleep-arousal most difficult

*50–90 min after sleep onset, episodes repeated every 60–90 min, each episode lasting about 10 min

*dreaming occurs, rapid eye movements, increase in brain O2 consumption

*EEG resembles that of alert awake state.

*Saw tooth waves

Note- According to new classification Stage 3 and 4 of NREM are grouped together as N3. So as per recent staging NREM has 3 stages (N1, N2, N3)

questions.text: Steroids impair wound healing by _____
questions.solution:
Steroids impair wound healing by decreasing angiogenesis and macrophage migration.

The major effect of steroids is to inhibit the inflammatory phase of wound healing (angiogenesis, neutrophil and macrophage migration and fibroblast proliferation) and the release of lysosomal enzymes. The stronger the anti-inflammatory effect of the steroid compound used, the greater the inhibitory effect on wound healing.

Steroids also inhibit epithelialization and contraction and contribute to increased rates of wound infection, regardless of time of administration. In the case of delayed healing of cutaneous wounds, epithelialization can be stimulated by the topical application of vitamin A.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents with an enlarged, hard, nodular prostate. Further investigations reveal a tumor that has extended through the prostatic capsule to the seminal vesicle. Other adjacent structures are not involved. What is the stage of his disease?
questions.solution:
The stage of the tumor that has extended through the prostatic capsule to the seminal vesicle and not to other adjacent structures is T3b.

Staging of prostate carcinoma:
Tx Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0 No evidence of primary tumor
T1 Clinically inapparent tumor. Neither palpable nor visible on imaging
T1a Incidental histologic finding in 5% or less of tissue resected
T1b Incidental histologic findings in more than 5% of tissue resected
T1c Tumor identified by needle biopsy (for example, because of elevated PSA level)
T2

Tumor confined within the prostate
T2a

Tumor involves one-half of one lobe or less
T2b

Tumor involves more than one-half of one lobe but not both lobes
T2c

Tumor involves both lobes
T3

Tumors extend through the prostate capsule
T3a Extracapsular extension (unilateral or bilateral)
T3b

Tumor invades seminal vesicle(s)
T4 Tumor is fixed or invades adjacent structures other than seminal vesicles, such as external sphincter, rectum, bladder, levator muscles, and/or pelvic wall

questions.text: Which of the following findings do you expect to see in a patient with central diabetes insipidus?

choices.text: Low plasma osmolality  and low urine osmolality
High plasma osmolality and high urine osmolality
Low plasma osmolality and high urine osmolality
Low urine osmolality and high plasma osmolality

questions.solution:
Diabetes insipidus of central or nephrogenic origin are characterized by low urine osmolality and high plasma osmolality.

Diabetes insipidus (DI) is a syndrome characterized by the excretion of abnormally large volumes of dilute urine. The 24-hour urine volume exceeds 40 mL/kg body weight, and the 24-hour urine osmolarity is <280 mOsm/L. There will be a slight increase in plasma osmolarity/sodium that stimulates thirst (polydipsia). Hence, clinical symptoms and signs of dehydration are uncommon unless thirst and/or water intake are also impaired.

It can be central or nephrogenic.

  • Central DI occurs due to damage to the neurohypophysis in the posterior pituitary. It is characterized by decreased ADH. It can be treated with desmopressin, an ADH analogue. 
  • In nephrogenic DI, ADH levels may be normal or increased because the kidney has become resistant to its effects. Nephrogenic DI requires treatment with a thiazide diuretic, amiloride, low sodium diet, and indomethacin. 

Condition

Plasma osmolality

Urine osmolality

Sodium concentration

Central and nephrogenic DI

High

Low

Hypernatremia

Psychogenic polydipsia

Low

Low

 Hyponatremia

SIADH

Low

High

Hyponatremia

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality. 

  Urine osmolality before water deprivation Urine osmolality after water deprivation Urine osmolality after desmopressin administration
Normal  Normal  Increases No change
Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

Related Pearl: Causes of Central Diabetes insipidus

Acquired

  • Head trauma (closed and penetrating) including pituitary surgery
  • Neoplasms
  • Granulomas
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Histiocytosis
  • Infectious
  • Viral encephalitis
  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Inflammatory
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
    • Lupus erythematosus
    • Scleroderma
  • Vascular
    • Sheehan’s syndrome
    • Aneurysm (internal carotid)

Congenital

  • Malformations
  • Genetic
    • Wolfram syndrome

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done using _______.
questions.solution:
Personal monitoring of radiation is done by a thermoluminescent dosimeter (TLD) badge.

A TLD badge is made up of lithium fluoride or dysprosium.

The badge should be positioned according to local or national practices. In India, one TLD badge has to be worn at the chest level inside the lead apron, if the apron is used. An additional wrist badge has to be worn for procedures requiring hands close to the primary beam. 

The given image shows a TLD badge.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about pterygium?

choices.text: Abnormal activity of p53 is seen in the pterygium tissue.
Decreased activity of tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases is seen.
Destruction of Bowman's layer occurs when the pterygium invades the cornea.
Elastotic degeneration and hyalinization of the connective tissue of the conjunctiva occur.

questions.solution:
Elastotic degeneration and hyalinization of the conjunctival connective tissue occur in pinguecula (and not pterygium). 

In pterygium, there is elastotic degeneration of collagen with fibrovascular proliferation.

It is important to distinguish a pterygium from a pinguecula. A pterygium, while being histologically similar to a pinguecula, is distinguished by fibrovascular tissue that grows onto the cornea. Pingueculae do not have vascularized tissue and do not cross the limbus.
